The results show that you carry a de novo pathogenic variant in COL1A1 c.2282G>A in exon 33/34. This confirms your clinical diagnosis of OI.
Patient: So, it's definitely OI then?
Doctor: Yes, the genetic testing confirms your clinical diagnosis of Osteogenesis Imperfecta.
Patient's Family: Thank you for explaining everything, Doctor. We appreciate your help in understanding and managing his condition.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, when my mom was 16 weeks pregnant, they found out that I had shortened long bones through a scan
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a child with a history of severe Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI), diagnosed antenatally, reports multiple lifelong fractures and surgeries, including bilateral femoral and tibial rodding. The patient was born prematurely at 37 weeks via caesarean section, required initial ventilation, and was fed through a nasogastric tube due to gastroesophageal reflux. Developmental milestones were delayed; the patient began speaking around 2.5-3 years and never achieved the ability to walk. The patient has been receiving 3-monthly infusions of pamidronate for bone fragility.

Objective.Observations: Examination reveals short stature, blue sclerae, triangular face, and dentinogenesis imperfecta with marked deformities of long bones and pes cavus appearance. Genetic testing identified a de novo pathogenic variant in COL1A1 c.2282G>A in exon 33/34, confirming the diagnosis of Osteogenesis Imperfecta.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is severe Osteogenesis Imperfecta, confirmed by genetic testing. The patient's history of multiple fractures, surgical interventions, and characteristic phenotypic features are consistent with this diagnosis. The prognosis involves ongoing management of symptoms and prevention of further complications.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current regimen of 3-monthly pamidronate infusions. Monitor bone density and growth patterns regularly. Address gastroesophageal reflux as needed to prevent complications. Physical therapy should be maintained to optimize mobility and prevent contractures. Regular follow-ups with orthopedics, genetics, and gastroenterology are recommended. Educate the patient and family about the nature of the disease, genetic implications, and importance of careful handling to prevent fractures.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, can you tell me what brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, I've had a fever for the past two days, along with chills, rigors, arthralgia, myalgia, a frontal headache, faintishness, lower back pain, loss of appetite, vomiting, and loose stool about 3-4 times a day.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you had any significant exposure to leptospirosis or contact with someone who has a fever?
Patient: No, I don't think so. I work as a manual worker, but I don't remember being exposed to anything like that.
Doctor: Okay, let's check your vitals. On admission, you appear to be ill looking, febrile with a temperature of 104 F, dehydrated, and mildly dyspnoeic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Your SpO2 is 98% on air, and you have conjunctival suffusion. Your pulse rate is 124 bpm, and your blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Other system examinations seem to be unremarkable.
Patient: That doesn't sound too good.
Doctor: We performed an ultrasound scan of your abdomen, which showed acute renal parenchymal changes, but there was no evidence of free fluid in your abdomen. Initial investigations revealed neutrophil leukocytosis with thrombocytopenia, high C-reactive protein (360 mg/L), high blood urea (172 mg/dL), and serum creatinine (355 micromol/L), marginally elevated liver transaminases (AST > ALT), microscopic hematuria, and an ECG that showed sinus tachycardia with mild T inversions in V4-V6. Your chest X-ray appears normal.
Patient: That's a lot of information. What does it all mean?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, we believe you may have leptospirosis. We started you on intravenous cefotaxime as a treatment. Your blood pressure improved after fluid resuscitation, and you had good urine output. A 2D echocardiogram was also performed, which came back normal, but your troponin titer increased and then came down.
Patient: So, am I getting better?
Doctor: Yes, you were discharged from the ward on day 7 of your illness with complete recovery and normal full blood count, renal, and liver function tests. Your CRP and trop I titer were also coming down, and a 2D echocardiogram performed after three weeks of recovery was normal.
Patient: That's a relief! What about other tests like dengue and stuff?
Doctor: Your dengue antigen test, blood, and urine cultures were negative. The Leptospirosis qPCR test performed on day three of the illness was reported as not detected, though one out of triplicate samples.
Patient: So, everything is looking okay now?
Doctor: Yes, it seems that you have made a full recovery. Just make sure to follow up with any necessary appointments and take care of yourself. If you have any concerns or if your symptoms return, don't hesitate to contact us.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've had a fever for the past two days, along with chills, rigors, arthralgia, myalgia, a frontal headache, faintishness, lower back pain, loss of appetite, vomiting, and loose stool about 3-4 times a day
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Patient, a manual worker, presented with a 2-day history of fever, chills, rigors, arthralgia, myalgia, frontal headache, faintishness, lower back pain, loss of appetite, vomiting, and loose stool occurring 3-4 times daily. Denies significant exposure to leptospirosis or contact with febrile individuals.

Objective.Observations: On examination, patient appeared ill, febrile (104 F), dehydrated, mildly dyspnoeic (RR 24/min), with conjunctival suffusion. Vitals showed tachycardia (PR 124 bpm), hypotension (BP 80/50 mmHg), and normal oxygen saturation (SpO2 98% on air). Ultrasound revealed acute renal parenchymal changes; no free fluid. Labs indicated neutrophil leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, elevated CRP (360 mg/L), high blood urea (172 mg/dL), serum creatinine (355 micromol/L), marginally elevated liver transaminases, microscopic hematuria, and sinus tachycardia with mild T inversions in V4-V6 on ECG. Chest X-ray was normal. Negative results for dengue antigen, blood, and urine cultures. Leptospirosis qPCR was not detected in one out of triplicate samples.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis of leptospirosis considered despite negative qPCR, based on clinical presentation and supportive lab findings. Differential diagnosis included other causes of acute febrile illness with multiorgan involvement.

Plan.Treatment: Initiated treatment with intravenous cefotaxime. Patient underwent fluid resuscitation, resulting in improved blood pressure and good urine output. Discharged on day 7 with complete recovery; normal full blood count, renal, and liver function tests. CRP and troponin titer decreased. Follow-up includes a 2D echocardiogram after three weeks, which was normal. Advised to follow up with necessary appointments and monitor for recurrence of symptoms.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I wanted to discuss your recent diagnosis. During your health screening, you were diagnosed with early-stage gastric cancer. We need to admit you to our hospital for radical surgical treatment. 
Patient: Oh no, that's concerning. What did the tests show?
Doctor: Your physical examinations and blood tests revealed nothing of note, including tumor markers. We performed an Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGDS) and found that the type 0-IIc gastric cancer is located in the posterior wall of the mid-body of your stomach (Fig. a). The histological type is poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.
Patient: Hmm, okay. So what's the plan for treatment?
Doctor: Based on your preoperative examinations, we planned to perform a laparoscopic distal gastrectomy with D1+ lymph node dissection and Billroth-I reconstruction. The tumor invasion is at the submucosal layer without lymph node swelling. Your clinical stage according to the TNM 7th edition is cT1b N0 M0, cStage I.
Patient: Alright, I understand. How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The surgery progressed without any problems on dissection around the left gastroepiploic vessels. However, during the dissection of the infrapyloric area (Fig. a), a part of the pancreatic head showed unusual adherence to the first part of the duodenal wall (Fig. b). This made it difficult to safely separate the pancreatic head from the first part of the duodenal wall (Fig. c).
Patient: Oh, so what did you do next?
Doctor: Since we needed to dissect and mobilize the duodenal bulb as much as possible for Billroth-I anastomosis (delta-shaped anastomosis using linear staplers), we decided to change our reconstruction plan of the Billroth-I method to Roux-en-Y. To avoid causing pancreatic injury during the lymphadenectomy, we focused on tracing the dissectible layer between the pancreatic parenchyma and fatty tissues, including lymph nodes (Fig. d).
Patient: I see. Was there anything else unusual during the surgery?
Doctor: Yes, after the distal gastrectomy, we couldn't find the ligament of Treitz or jejunum on the left side, below the transverse colon. Furthermore, the right-side colon had been completely mobilized to the left-side abdomen (Fig. a).
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. What are the next steps for my treatment and recovery?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your recovery and provide appropriate postoperative care. You may need additional treatments, depending on how well you recover from the surgery. We'll keep you informed throughout the process and ensure you receive the necessary support during your recovery journey.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Oh no, that's concerning
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient was

Objective.Observations: Physical examinations and blood tests, including tumor markers, were unremarkable. The EGDS confirmed the presence of gastric cancer. During the laparoscopic distal gastrectomy with D1+ lymph node dissection and initially planned Billroth-I reconstruction, difficulties were encountered due to unusual adherence of the pancreatic head to the duodenal wall. The surgical team opted for a Roux-en-Y reconstruction instead. The clinical stage of the cancer is cT1b N0 M0, cStage I.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is early-stage poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically type 0-IIc located at the mid-body on the posterior wall. The patient underwent successful laparoscopic distal gastrectomy with a change in the surgical plan to Roux-en-Y reconstruction due to anatomical challenges. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the early stage of cancer and successful surgical intervention, although close monitoring is required.

Plan.Treatment: The patient will be closely monitored during the postoperative period to manage recovery and detect any complications early. The surgical team will provide appropriate postoperative care and consider additional treatments based on the patient's recovery progress. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to ensure proper healing and to discuss further therapeutic options if necessary. The patient will also receive education on symptoms to watch for and lifestyle adjustments to aid in recovery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I had a motorcycle accident back in July 2016 and I was treated with open reduction and internal fixation with a locking plate and single compression screw, along with a split-thickness skin graft in Bulgaria.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the fracture pattern?
Patient: Sure, I had a proximal tibial fracture, an open fracture, and a proximal fibula fracture with a lesion of the peroneal nerve.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. When were you admitted to our hospital?
Patient: I was admitted in September 2016.
Doctor: Alright. Our initial diagnostics, including plain radiographs and a pan CT/MRI scan, revealed an onset of septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, and a large abscess zone with contrast agent capturing 30 cm in the dorsal compartment. We also found necrotic avascular muscle areas, a loss of the anterior tibial artery, and a large anterolateral soft tissue defect covered with necrotic split-thickness graft that was transplanted onto bone and osteosynthesis material at the primary hospital in Bulgaria.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a complicated situation. How has your mobilization been?
Patient: It has been painful due to the unstable osseous situation, so I haven't been moving around much.
Doctor: I understand. Our laboratory tests showed that your infection parameters were slightly increased, with CRP at 2.7 mg/dl and leukocytes at 6.9 G/l. We also found Acinetobacter baumannii (Carbapenem resistant) and Enterobacter cloacae complex (overexpression of AmpC-Betalactamase and fluoroquinolone resistant) in the wound smears from the anterolateral defect zone and intramedullary in the proximal tibia to the distal third of the tibial shaft.
Patient: Wow, that's a lot of information.
Doctor: Yes, it's important to understand the complete clinical course of your situation. Now, let me explain our initial surgical management plan. We will remove the osteosynthesis material and necrotic split-thickness graft, followed by aggressive extensive osseous debridement and resection of necrotic muscles of the anterior lower leg.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any more questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We will do our best to help you through this process.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I had a motorcycle accident back in July 2016 and I was treated with open reduction and internal fixation with a locking plate and single compression screw, along with a split-thickness skin graft in Bulgaria
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a history of a motorcycle accident in July 2016, treated initially with open reduction and internal fixation and a split-thickness skin graft in Bulgaria. He describes having a proximal tibial fracture, an open fracture, and a proximal fibula fracture with a lesion of the peroneal nerve. He mentions painful mobilization due to the unstable osseous situation.

Objective.Observations: Initial diagnostics at our hospital showed septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, and a large abscess zone with contrast agent capturing 30 cm in the dorsal compartment. Necrotic avascular muscle areas, loss of the anterior tibial artery, and a large anterolateral soft tissue defect covered with necrotic split-thickness graft were also noted. Laboratory tests indicated slightly elevated infection parameters with CRP at 2.7 mg/dl (normal <0.5 mg/dl) and leukocytes at 6.9 G/l (normal range 4.0-10.0 G/l). Cultures grew Acinetobacter baumannii (Carbapenem resistant) and Enterobacter cloacae complex (overexpression of AmpC-Betalactamase and fluoroquinolone resistant).

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with chronic osteomyelitis associated with septic pseudarthrosis and a complicated soft tissue infection due to resistant organisms. The presence of necrotic tissue and loss of vascular integrity complicates the prognosis, requiring aggressive surgical and antimicrobial management.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes removal of the osteosynthesis material and necrotic graft, followed by extensive osseous debridement and resection of necrotic muscles of the anterior lower leg. Antibiotic therapy will be tailored based on sensitivity patterns, focusing on treating the resistant strains identified. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the healing process and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and mobility restrictions will be emphasized to prevent further complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, Patient 1. Can you please tell me about your medical history and the symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient 1: Hi, Doctor. I'm a 31-year-old woman and I've been having this itchy eruption on my mid- to lower back, lateral chest wall, and the nape of my neck.
Doctor: I see. How long has this been going on?
Patient 1: It's been recurrent, but I've noticed that it usually happens when I'm fasting during Ramadan or when I travel to North America.
Doctor: Interesting. Can you describe the appearance of the eruption after it resolves?
Patient 1: Yes, after the itching goes away, it leaves behind a net-like pigmentation.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Based on your description, it seems like the eruptions are linked to fasting and your travels. Have you experienced any other medical problems recently?
Patient 1: No, I haven't had any other medical issues.
Doctor: That's good to know. It's important to identify any potential underlying conditions that could be contributing to these eruptions. Since you haven't had any other medical problems, we can focus on managing the symptoms and trying to prevent future occurrences.
Patient 1: Okay, what should I do to manage the symptoms and prevent them from happening again?
Doctor: First, I recommend keeping your skin moisturized and avoiding irritants that could exacerbate the itching. Also, try to minimize stress, as it can trigger flare-ups. You may want to consider adjusting your fasting practices during Ramadan or adjusting your travel plans to reduce the likelihood of eruptions.
Patient 1: Alright, I'll try to follow your suggestions. Is there anything else I need to do or watch out for?
Doctor: Keep an eye on the affected areas and monitor any changes in the eruptions or pigmentation. If you notice any worsening or new symptoms, please don't hesitate to come back for a follow-up appointment.
Patient 1: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to follow your advice and keep an eye on my skin.
Doctor: You're welcome, Patient 1. I hope these recommendations help you manage your symptoms better. If you have any concerns or questions, feel free to reach out.
Patient 1: I appreciate your help, Doctor. Have a great day!
Doctor: You too, take care and stay healthy!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No chief complaint documented
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Patient is a 31-year-old female presenting with recurrent itchy eruptions on her mid- to lower back, lateral chest wall, and nape of her neck. She reports that these eruptions are associated with fasting during Ramadan and travel to North America. The eruptions resolve with net-like pigmentation. No other recent medical issues reported.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination was not detailed in the dialogue. No laboratory or imaging results were provided.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms are suggestive of a recurrent dermatological condition possibly triggered by environmental or lifestyle factors such as fasting and travel. Differential diagnoses could include chronic urticaria or a form of physical urticaria. The net-like pigmentation following resolution may suggest post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.

Plan.Treatment: Management plan includes keeping the skin moisturized and avoiding known irritants. The patient is advised to minimize stress and consider adjusting fasting practices and travel plans to mitigate triggers. Monitoring of the skin for any changes or worsening of symptoms is recommended, with a follow-up appointment if new symptoms arise. Further diagnostic evaluation may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm here because I'm pregnant and have an unspecified bleeding disorder. I'm currently at 37-6/7 weeks gestational age.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any issues related to your bleeding disorder during this pregnancy or previously?
Patient: Yes, before my diagnosis, I had a history of easy bruising, gingival bleeding, heavy menstrual bleeding, and some complications after surgeries. I had hemorrhagic compartment syndrome after an ankle surgery and bleeding complications with all three of my prior deliveries.
Doctor: That sounds concerning. Were there any other complications during your prior deliveries?
Patient: Yes, I had persistent vaginal bleeding after my first two CDs and intra-abdominal hemorrhage after my third CD. I also had epidurals during those pregnancies, but I don't have the anesthetic records.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Do you have any family history of bleeding disorders?
Patient: My family history is positive for mucocutaneous bleeding, like my mom's heavy menstrual bleeding. My maternal grandmother also died due to postpartum hemorrhage.
Doctor: I understand. Were you referred for evaluation of your bleeding disorder before this pregnancy?
Patient: Yes, I was referred for evaluation before my cervical spine surgery. They did an extensive coagulation laboratory evaluation, and everything came back normal, including complete blood count, smear, activated partial thromboplastin time, prothrombin time, thrombin time, von Willebrand factor parameters, fibrinogen activity, platelet aggregation studies, platelet function assay, factor XIII level, and rotational thromboelastography.
Doctor: With all those normal results, it seems like your bleeding disorder is unspecified. The differential diagnosis could include rare congenital bleeding disorders such as undetected VWF qualitative dysfunction or undetected defects in fibrin, fibrinolysis, or platelet function.
Patient: So, what was done to prevent any complications during my cervical spine surgery?
Doctor: You received prophylactic fresh frozen plasma (FFP), cryoprecipitate, platelets, and anti-fibrinolytic treatment as prophylaxis, which helped you achieve good hemostasis without any complications.
Patient: That's good to know. Now, what about my current pregnancy and delivery?
Doctor: Upon presentation for delivery, your laboratory values were unremarkable: hematocrit (Hct) 30%, platelets 169 × 10^3/ml. We will closely monitor you and your baby, considering your history of bleeding complications and the fetal macrosomia in this pregnancy. We may need to take similar precautions as with your cervical spine surgery to ensure a safe delivery.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and attentiveness to my condition.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I'm here because I'm pregnant and have an unspecified bleeding disorder
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 37-6/7 weeks pregnant female, reports a history of an unspecified bleeding disorder characterized by easy bruising, gingival bleeding, heavy menstrual bleeding, and hemorrhagic complications post-

Objective.Observations: Current hematocrit is 30% and platelet count is 169 × 10^3/ml, both within normal limits. Previous extensive coagulation tests including CBC, smear, aPTT, PT, TT, VWF parameters, fibrinogen activity, platelet aggregation studies, platelet function assay, factor XIII level, and ROTEM were normal. Prophylactic measures during previous surgery (FFP, cryoprecipitate, platelets, anti-fibrinolytic treatment) were successful in achieving hemostasis.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is an unspecified bleeding disorder with a differential diagnosis including rare congenital disorders such as undetected VWF qualitative dysfunction or defects in fibrin, fibrinolysis, or platelet function. The patient's history of bleeding complications during surgery and delivery poses significant risks for her current pregnancy.

Plan.Treatment: Close monitoring of the patient and fetal condition will be necessary during delivery, with preparedness to administer prophylactic treatments similar to those used during her cervical spine surgery. This includes potential use of FFP, cryoprecipitate, platelets, and anti-fibrinolytic agents. Patient education regarding signs of bleeding and when to seek immediate care will be reinforced. Coordination with obstetrics, hematology, and anesthesiology is crucial to manage delivery and potential complications effectively.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I'll be conducting your evaluation today. Can you please tell me the main concerns you have with your child?
Parent: Hi, Doctor. Our five-month-old son has had global developmental delay since birth, and he's been experiencing remittent fever, recurrent seizures, and vomiting for the past three months.
Doctor: I see. Let's talk about the pregnancy first. Was it planned or unplanned?
Parent: The pregnancy was unplanned.
Doctor: Okay. I understand that your child had a low birth weight of 2.2 kg and symmetrical intrauterine growth retardation. Has he had any issues with weight gain since then?
Parent: Yes, he's had recurrent vomiting since he was two months old, and his weight gain has been poor.
Doctor: That must be concerning for you. Has he experienced any regression in his development, such as loss of visual fixation or social smile?
Parent: Yes, he lost his social smile, and his visual fixation has become poor as well.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Has he had any fevers, and if so, were there any negative septic screens conducted?
Parent: He's had remittent fevers for several months, but all the septic screens came back negative.
Doctor: Alright. Given the negative screens, it's possible that there may be a central cause related to irregularities in thermoregulation. Has he developed any unusual movements, such as dystonia or dyskinetic movements?
Parent: Yes, he has developed marked dystonia and dyskinetic movements lately.
Doctor: It seems like there might be involvement of the extrapyramidal nervous system. Has your elder child experienced similar issues, such as epileptic encephalopathy?
Parent: Yes, our elder child had developmental regression and epileptic encephalopathy. He passed away at 1 ½ years of age due to aspiration pneumonia while being evaluated for a neuro-metabolic disorder.
Doctor: I'm very sorry to hear that. During the clinical examination of your younger child, we found severe growth retardation and spasticity in all four limbs, with exaggerated reflexes. The Electroencephalography (EEG) revealed encephalopathy.
Parent: That sounds really concerning, Doctor.
Doctor: Yes, it is. The Brain MRI showed multiple areas of increased T2 signal intensity with diffusion restriction involving the brain stem, basal ganglia, and white matter tracts, suggesting widespread demyelination. The urine FeCl3 test came back positive for phenylketonuria.
Parent: What does that mean for our child?
Doctor: Phenylketonuria is a metabolic disorder that could explain some of your child's symptoms. Our tests also showed an elevated Phenylalanine level of 1245.71 μM, with a normal range being 25-120 μM, and a Phenylalanine/Tyrosine ratio of 21.87, where the normal range is 0.4-2.2. Additionally, his blood Neopterin levels were very low at 0.01 nmol/g Hb.
Parent: What do these results mean for our son's condition and treatment?
Doctor: The results indicate a possible metabolic disorder, which could be contributing to your child's symptoms. We'll need to discuss further tests and potential treatment options to manage his condition. It's important to closely monitor his progress and follow up with regular appointments.
Parent: Thank you, Doctor. We appreciate your help and guidance during this difficult time.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No chief complaint documented
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a five-month-old male, presents with global developmental delay, remittent fever, recurrent seizures, vomiting, poor weight gain, loss of social smile, poor visual fixation, marked dystonia, and dyskinetic movements. The pregnancy was unplanned, and the patient had a low birth weight of 2.2 kg with symmetrical intrauterine growth retardation. The patient's elder sibling had similar symptoms and passed away from complications related to a neuro-metabolic disorder.

Objective.Observations: Clinical examination revealed severe growth retardation and spasticity in all four limbs with exaggerated reflexes. EEG indicated encephalopathy. Brain MRI showed multiple areas of increased T2 signal intensity with diffusion restriction in the brain stem, basal ganglia, and white matter tracts, suggesting widespread demyelination. Laboratory tests revealed a positive urine FeCl3 test for phenylketonuria, elevated Phenylalanine level at 1245.71 μM (normal range 25-120 μM), Phenylalanine/Tyrosine ratio of 21.87 (normal range 0.4-2.2), and very low blood Neopterin levels at 0.01 nmol/g Hb.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is phenylketonuria with associated severe neurological manifestations including encephalopathy and widespread demyelination. Differential diagnoses include other neuro-metabolic disorders, considering the family history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded given the severity of symptoms and the outcome of the elder sibling.

Plan.Treatment: Initiate dietary management specific for phenylketonuria, including a low-phenylalanine diet. Begin neurological supportive care and symptomatic treatment for dystonia and seizures. Schedule regular follow-ups for monitoring metabolic and neurological status. Refer to a metabolic specialist for further evaluation and management. Educate the parents about the nature of the disorder, treatment strategies, and the importance of adherence to dietary restrictions. Discuss genetic counseling for the family to assess the risk for future pregnancies.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, I've been reviewing your case and I see that you've had some risk factors associated with your lifestyle, such as marijuana and tobacco abuse. However, there's no history of alcohol excess or other illicit drug use. Can you tell me more about your smoking habits?
Patient: Yeah, I've been smoking marijuana and tobacco for quite some time now. I don't really drink alcohol or use any other drugs, though.
Doctor: I understand. Unfortunately, you recently suffered an acute thalamomesencephalic stroke which has rapidly worsened, leading you to a comatose state. Your personal medical history and familial history show no association with cardiocerebrovascular pathology or other specific risk factors. 
Patient: Oh no, that's terrible...
Doctor: Yes, it is quite concerning. On the evening before this cerebral infarction, you had a large tattoo done on your left hypochondrium and abdominal flank, and you smoked a few cigarettes with cannabis. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I got the tattoo and smoked some joints afterward.
Doctor: The next morning, you experienced acute onset of dizziness, visual, speech, and gait disturbances. Can you describe those symptoms?
Patient: I was feeling really dizzy, had trouble seeing, speaking, and walking properly.
Doctor: You were then admitted to the emergency room with walking difficulties, disturbed balance and coordination of movements, slurred speech, diplopia, confusion, and left palpebral ptosis. Our neurological examination revealed right-sided severe ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria, left palpebral ptosis and mydriasis, divergent strabismus, and fluctuating consciousness, with a Glasgow coma scale of 10/15.
Patient: That sounds really bad...
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. We also conducted blood tests, including white blood cells count, hemoglobin, electrolytes, liver, and renal function, all of which revealed normal results. However, your urine toxicology at admission was positive for tetrahydrocannabinol. No other illicit drugs were present on the tox screen. Your Electrocardiogram (EKG) and chest X-ray findings were also normal.
Patient: I see. So, it's just the marijuana that was found in my system?
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. Clotting tests were performed as well, with antithrombin III at 108% (>80%), homocysteine at 7.5 μmol (≤ 12), lupus anticoagulant negative, antinuclear antibodies at 0.3 UM (<0.7), and C protein at 117% (70-130). These results are within the normal range.
Patient: Okay, so what did the scan show?
Doctor: An emergent computed tomography (CT) scan on the day of admission showed no gross abnormality and no evidence of cerebral hemorrhage or encephalitis. However, within a few hours, you became comatose with a Glasgow coma scale of 7/15 and were transferred to the intensive therapy unit. Fortunately, intubation and ventilation support were not necessary.
Patient: So, what's the plan now, doc?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your condition and provide appropriate medical care to manage your symptoms and support your recovery. It is crucial to address your risk factors, such as marijuana and tobacco abuse, to prevent any further complications.
Patient's Family: Thank you, doctor. We appreciate your help and will make sure to support our loved one during this difficult time.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been smoking marijuana and tobacco for quite some time now
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a chronic smoker of marijuana and tobacco, reported no use of alcohol or other illicit drugs. He experienced acute onset of dizziness, visual disturbances, speech difficulties, and gait disturbances following an evening of smoking and getting a tattoo. Symptoms escalated to severe ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria, left palpebral ptosis, mydriasis, divergent strabismus, and fluctuating consciousness, leading to a comatose state with a Glasgow coma scale of 10/15, later worsening to 7/15.

Objective.Observations: Neurological examination confirmed right-sided severe ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria, left palpebral ptosis, mydriasis, divergent strabismus, and fluctuating consciousness. Blood tests including WBC count, hemoglobin, electrolytes, liver, and renal function were normal. Urine toxicology was positive for tetrahydrocannabinol; other illicit drugs were negative. Clotting tests were within normal limits. EKG and chest X-ray were normal. Initial CT scan showed no gross abnormalities or evidence of cerebral hemorrhage or encephalitis.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is acute thalamomesencephalic stroke, likely exacerbated by lifestyle choices, specifically marijuana and tobacco use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of stroke not evident in imaging or initial tests. The prognosis is guarded given the rapid progression to a comatose state.

Plan.Treatment: The patient will be closely monitored in the intensive therapy unit with supportive care to manage symptoms and support recovery. Addressing lifestyle risk factors, particularly cessation of marijuana and tobacco use, is crucial. Family education on stroke risks and prevention will be provided, along with regular updates on the patient's status and progress.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you had an injury to your left hand about a year ago, involving a meat chopper. Can you tell me what happened?
Patient: Yeah, I'm a chef at an Indian restaurant, and I accidentally chopped my middle, ring, and little fingers on my left hand. The fingers couldn't be replanted, so they had to be amputated.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. So you had amputations of the middle and ring fingers at the level of the proximal phalanx and of the little finger at the middle phalanx. And now, six months after the injury, you've been referred to our hospital for hand reconstruction, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I have reviewed your radiographic images which confirmed the clinical findings. Your preoperative visual analogue scale (VAS) score was 4/10, indicating some phantom pain after the amputations, and your Quick-DASH was 81.82/100.00. Have you experienced any changes in pain or function since then?
Patient: No, it's been pretty consistent.
Doctor: We performed an examination of your foot vascularity with contrast-enhanced computed tomography and found that bilateral STT was compatible for the reconstruction of two fingers. Therefore, we can proceed with transferring your bilateral second toes to the middle and ring fingers.
Patient: Okay, what does that involve?
Doctor: First, we'll make a curved incision over the volar surface of the distal middle and ring fingers. We'll then identify and isolate the digital artery, digital nerve, and flexor digitorum profundus on the volar side to provide for inflow and reinnervation.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: Next, we'll mark the dorsalis pedis artery and superficial dorsal vein under ultrasound guidance, then create a v-shaped incision at the base of the second toe and extend it proximally. We'll perform dissections on both the dorsal and plantar sides to identify key structures like the extensor digitorum longus, flexor digitorum longus, and proper palmer digital nerves.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We'll then disarticulate the second metatarsophalangeal joint and harvest the second toe with a long pedicle to facilitate vascular anastomosis and avoid kinking of the artery. Finally, we'll transfer the second toe to your middle and ring fingers, reconnecting the blood vessels, nerves, and tendons.
Patient: I understand. What will the recovery process be like?
Doctor: Recovery will involve some physical therapy to regain function and manage any pain. It may take several months, but we'll monitor your progress closely and make adjustments as needed.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help you through this process.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I'm a chef at an Indian restaurant, and I accidentally chopped my middle, ring, and little fingers on my left hand
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a chef, reports a traumatic amputation of the middle, ring, and little fingers on the left hand due to an accident involving a meat chopper approximately one year ago. The amputations were at the level of the proximal phalanx for the middle and ring fingers and at the middle phalanx for the little finger. The patient experiences consistent phantom pain with a preoperative visual analogue scale (VAS) score of 4/10 and significant functional impairment with a Quick-DASH score of 81.82/100.00.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Bilateral STT was compatible for the reconstruction of two fingers
Objective.Observations: Radiographic imaging confirmed the clinical findings of finger amputations. Examination of foot vascularity using contrast-enhanced computed tomography indicated suitability of bilateral second toes for reconstruction of the middle and ring fingers. No changes in pain or function have been reported since the initial assessment.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is traumatic amputation of the middle, ring, and little fingers on the left hand with subsequent phantom pain and functional impairment. The patient is a candidate for hand reconstruction using bilateral second toe transfer.

Plan.Treatment: The plan includes surgical reconstruction of the middle and ring fingers using bilateral second toe transfer. The procedure will involve detailed dissections and vascular anastomosis to ensure functionality and sensation in the reconstructed fingers. Postoperative care will include physical therapy to regain function and manage pain, with close monitoring of the patient's progress and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and address any complications.
Plan.Follow-Up: Transferring your bilateral second toes to the middle and ring fingers

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been diagnosed with stage IIIB lung adenocarcinoma.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. According to the Union for International Cancer Control 8th edition, it's classified as T1bN3M0, with the primary tumor in your left lower lobe and multiple lymph node metastases in 2R, 4R, 7, and 10L. Can you tell me if you have any past medical history or complications?
Patient: No, I don't have any past medical issues or complications.
Doctor: That's good. I see that both your epidermal growth factor receptor mutations and anaplastic lymphoma kinase status are negative, and your PD-L1 expression is 0%. Have you already received any treatment for your lung adenocarcinoma?
Patient: Yes, I've received chemotherapy as the initial treatment because CRT wasn't suitable due to the wide extent and size of the tumor. I was given four cycles of carboplatin, pemetrexed, and bevacizumab.
Doctor: I understand. And after that, you were treated with pemetrexed and bevacizumab as maintenance therapy, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: It looks like your tumor decreased in size once, but then it regrew. However, the tumor size is now smaller than before the initial treatment, which makes CRT possible at this timing. We've decided to perform CRT followed by durvalumab as the next treatment for you on the cancer board.
Patient: Okay, I see.
Doctor: CRT was performed one month after your last administration of pemetrexed and bevacizumab. For the large tumor lesions, we prescribed up to 50 Gy in 2 Gy fractions with involved-field radiotherapy to avoid the occurrence of adverse effects. The dose was given through parallel-opposed anteroposterior portals up to 30 Gy, and multiportal beams were used to reduce the dose in the spinal cord from 30 to 50 Gy. Weekly carboplatin (area under the curve, 2.0) and paclitaxel (40 mg/m2) were administered concomitantly.
Patient: Were there any major adverse events during CRT?
Doctor: No, there were no major adverse events observed during CRT. One month after CRT, your tumor decreased in size, and there were no new lesions or adverse effects, such as esophagitis and pneumonitis.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: Yes, it's positive progress. As a result, we started durvalumab (10 mg/m2, every 2 weeks) after confirming the absence of new lesions and adverse effects.
Patient: How long will I be on durvalumab?
Doctor: You'll receive three courses of durvalumab, which will be 2.5 months after the completion of CRT. We'll closely monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan accordingly.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. We're here to support you through your treatment journey.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient,

Objective.Observations: The patient's epidermal growth factor receptor mutations and anaplastic lymphoma kinase status are negative, and PD-L1 expression is 0%. Recent treatment included CRT with 50 Gy in 2 Gy fractions and concomitant weekly carboplatin and paclitaxel, followed by durvalumab (10 mg/m2 every 2 weeks). No major adverse events were observed post-CRT, and the tumor size decreased with no new lesions.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is stage IIIB lung adenocarcinoma. The patient responded to initial chemotherapy and CRT, with a current decrease in tumor size and no new lesions. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic, pending response to ongoing durvalumab treatment.

Plan.Treatment: Continue durvalumab for three courses, totaling 2.5 months post-CRT. Monitor the patient closely for any new lesions or adverse effects. Provide supportive care and address any concerns or symptoms that arise during treatment. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, sir. I see here that you have no apparent past medical history. What brings you in today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I've been experiencing abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting lately.
Doctor: I see. We'll need to do a physical examination and run some tests to determine the cause. I'll start with the physical examination. *After examination* Everything seems to be normal with the physical examination. Now, let's review your lab results.
Doctor: Your lab results show that you have anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 11.6 g/dL, hematocrit at 32.2%, and lipase at 164 U/L. Your comprehensive metabolic panel is unrevealing, so we performed a CT of your abdomen and pelvis with contrast to get a better look.
Doctor: The CT scan revealed an enlarged pancreas without a focal mass, diffuse surrounding mesenteric edema, mild retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, mild mesenteric lymphadenopathy, rectal wall thickening with perirectal lymphadenopathy, left renal mass measuring 3.7 × 1.4 × 1.4 cm, right renal mass measuring 2.3 × 4.3 × 5.2 cm, marked diffuse urinary bladder wall thickening, and trace pericardial effusion. This raised concern for peritoneal carcinomatosis and/or mesenteric tumor.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We wanted to be thorough, so we invited urology and oncology services to evaluate you. They both agreed that a biopsy of the lymph node was necessary, along with urine cytology and HIV testing.
Doctor: Your urine cytology revealed atypical lymphocytes. The renal biopsy showed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). A bone marrow biopsy was also performed and was consistent with involvement of B-cell lymphoma.
Patient: That's scary. What about the HIV test?
Doctor: Your HTLV-I/II antibody test came back negative, but your HIV screening was positive. Your initial CD4 count was 440/μl with a percentage of 14%, and your HIV RNA viral load by PCR was 61,800 copies/mL.
Patient: Oh no. What about hepatitis?
Doctor: Your hepatitis C virus screening was negative. Your hepatitis B screening showed that you were positive for the core antibody and surface antibody, but negative for the surface antigen.
Doctor: Your lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level was also above the upper limit of detection for our lab, at >2500 U/L. Cerebrospinal fluid testing showed the presence of atypical lymphocytes. Finally, the biopsy of your kidney mass revealed atypical lymphocytes positive for CD45, CD20, PAX-5, and CD10, while negative for other markers.
Patient: So, what's the plan, doctor? What do we do now?
Doctor: We'll need to consult with specialists in oncology and infectious diseases to determine the best course of action for your treatment. They will guide us on how to manage both your lymphoma and HIV. We'll also closely monitor your hepatitis B status. Rest assured, we will work together to provide you with the best care possible.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Good morning, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a male with no significant past medical history, presents with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports recent concerning symptoms prompting medical evaluation.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination was unremarkable. Laboratory findings indicated anemia with hemoglobin at 11.6 g/dL (normal: 13.8-17.2 g/dL), hematocrit at 32.2% (normal: 40.7-50.3%), and elevated lipase at 164 U/L (normal: 0-160 U/L). Comprehensive metabolic panel was normal. CT abdomen and pelvis showed an enlarged pancreas, diffuse mesenteric edema, lymphadenopathy, bilateral renal masses, bladder wall thickening, and trace pericardial effusion. Urine cytology revealed atypical lymphocytes. Renal biopsy confirmed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Bone marrow biopsy was consistent with B-cell lymphoma involvement. HIV screening positive with a CD4 count of 440/μl and viral load of 61,800 copies/mL. Hepatitis B core antibody positive, surface antibody positive, surface antigen negative. LDH >2500 U/L. Cerebrospinal fluid testing showed atypical lymphocytes.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with secondary diagnoses of HIV infection and chronic hepatitis B carrier state. The imaging and lab results suggest advanced disease with systemic involvement including potential central nervous system engagement.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes referral to oncology for chemotherapy and to infectious disease for antiretroviral therapy management. Further consultations with urology due to renal masses are necessary. Regular monitoring of hepatitis B status and LDH levels will be conducted. Patient education regarding the diagnosis, treatment options, and importance of follow-up will be provided. Coordination of care among the various specialties involved is crucial for comprehensive management.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you came in for a routine preventative care visit. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi doc, I recently noticed some swelling in my left armpit and wanted to get it checked out.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent screenings or tests done?
Patient: Yes, I had a screening mammogram and a breast ultrasound. They found a 5 mm left breast nodule and left axillary adenopathy up to 3.2 cm.
Doctor: Given the concern for breast cancer, I believe you underwent a core needle biopsy of the left axillary node. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. After the biopsy, I was diagnosed with classical Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Doctor: I have your immunostaining results here. It shows large atypical cells that were CD30+, CD15+ (subset), CD20+ (strong), and PAX5+. No flow cytometric analysis was performed. The local pathologist read the specimen as most likely representing a cHL, although they considered alternatively that it could represent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) of the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) subtype. You were then referred to a medical oncologist, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: During your visit with the oncologist, did you have any B symptoms or any other issues during your physical exam?
Patient: No B symptoms, but I did mention my diminished hearing in my left ear.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Your lab results show a hemoglobin of 11.9 g/dL, leukocytes 7,600/μL, absolute neutrophil count 5,400/μL, absolute lymphocyte count 1,500/μL, platelets 261,000/μL, albumin 4.6 g/dL, and LDH 198 U/L (upper limit of normal 243 U/L). You also underwent a PET/CT scan and a bone marrow biopsy of the right posterior superior iliac crest, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: The bone marrow morphology showed normocellular marrow (30%) with maturing trilineage hematopoiesis and no evidence of cHL. The flow cytometric analysis also showed no evidence of a B- or T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. The PET/CT scan from the skull base to the midthigh revealed hypermetabolic adenopathy within the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis with the largest area of bulky adenopathy in the left axilla. 
Patient: So, what does all this mean for me, doc?
Doctor: Based on these findings, it appears that you have classical Hodgkin's lymphoma, which is a type of cancer. The good news is that there is no evidence of the cancer in your bone marrow. Your oncologist will discuss treatment options and next steps with you.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll follow up with my oncologist and proceed with the recommended treatment.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important to stay proactive and follow your oncologist's recommendations. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi doc, I recently noticed some swelling in my left armpit and wanted to get it checked out
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, who came in for a routine preventative care visit, reported noticing swelling in the left armpit. The patient had a screening mammogram and breast ultrasound, which identified a 5 mm left breast nodule and left axillary adenopathy up to 3.2 cm. The patient underwent a core needle biopsy of the left axillary node, leading to a diagnosis of classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The patient denied having any B symptoms but reported diminished hearing in the left ear.

Objective.Observations: Immunostaining results showed large atypical cells positive for CD30, CD15 (subset), CD20 (strong), and PAX5. Hemoglobin was 11.9 g/dL, leukocytes 7,600/μL, absolute neutrophil count 5,400/μL, absolute lymphocyte count 1,500/μL, platelets 261,000/μL, albumin 4.6 g/dL, and LDH 198 U/L (upper limit of normal 243 U/L). A PET/CT scan and bone marrow biopsy of the right posterior superior iliac crest showed hypermetabolic adenopathy in multiple regions, with the largest area in the left axilla. Bone marrow morphology was normocellular with maturing trilineage hematopoiesis and no evidence of classical Hodgkin's lymphoma or other lymphoproliferative disorders.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is classical Hodgkin's lymphoma, with differential diagnoses including non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) of the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) subtype. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of cancer in the bone marrow and localized hypermetabolic adenopathy.

Plan.Treatment: The patient will follow up with the medical oncologist to discuss treatment options, which may include chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any new symptoms or concerns. Regular follow-ups with the oncologist and primary care physician are recommended to monitor the patient's response to treatment and manage any side effects. The patient should also consider a consultation with an audiologist for the diminished hearing in the left ear.
Plan.Follow-Up: I'll follow up with my oncologist

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, what brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing impaired vision in both of my eyes for more than a year now.
Doctor: I see. Let's start with an ocular examination to assess your eyes. 
(After the examination)
Doctor: Based on the examination, the vision in your right eye is FC/20 cm and in your left eye is 0.02. Your intraocular pressure is 18 mmHg in both eyes. I also noticed ptosis of both upper eyelids and your lateral eyelashes are touching the cornea. The corneas are transparent in both eyes, with a central corneal thickness of 547 μm in the right eye and 540 μm in the left eye. The central anterior chamber depth is 3.25 mm in the right eye and 3.03 mm in the left eye. Your pupils are round and about 3 mm in diameter.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: Your lenses are milky and opaque in both eyes, which might be causing the impaired vision. The right eye lens has a thickness of 3.30 mm, and the left eye lens is 3.32 mm thick. Due to the occlusion of these cloudy lenses, the fundus of both eyes is not clear. However, no obvious vitreoretinal abnormalities were found on ultrasonography. 
Patient: I see. 
Doctor: Can you tell me about your family history? Any history of genetic diseases or vision problems?
Patient: My parents were first cousins, but I don't know of any genetic diseases in the family. My father died in a traffic accident at 40 years old, and my mother and other family members are in good health.
Doctor: Thank you. Have you experienced any developmental issues in the past?
Patient: Yes, I had developmental retardation when I was 8 years old, and I had Achilles tendon elongation due to tendon contracture.
Doctor: Alright. I'm going to perform a physical examination and check your vital signs.
(After the physical examination)
Doctor: Upon admission, you have a spare figure, weigh 40 kg, and are 150 cm tall. Your vital signs showed a temperature of 36.7 °C, pulse of 98 b/min, respiratory rate of 19/min, and blood pressure of 108/65 mmHg. Heart and lung auscultation found no obvious abnormalities.
Patient: Okay, what's next?
Doctor: I'm going to discuss your case with a specialist to determine the best course of action for your impaired vision. In the meantime, please make sure to attend follow-up appointments as needed so we can monitor your condition closely.
Patient: Understood. Thank you, doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been experiencing impaired vision in both of my eyes for more than a year now
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, experiencing impaired vision in both eyes for over a year, reports no known genetic diseases in the family despite parents being first cousins. The patient has a history of developmental retardation and Achilles tendon elongation.

Objective.Observations: Ocular examination reveals vision in the right eye at FC/20 cm and in the left eye at 0.02. Intraocular pressure is normal at 18 mmHg in both eyes. Both upper eyelids exhibit ptosis, and lateral eyelashes are touching the cornea. Corneas are transparent with a central corneal thickness of 547 μm in the right eye and 540 μm in the left eye. Anterior chamber depth is 3.25 mm in the right eye and 3.03 mm in the left eye. Pupils are round, 3 mm in diameter. Lenses are milky and opaque, with the right eye lens at 3.30 mm and the left at 3.32 mm thick, obscuring fundus visibility. Ultrasonography shows no vitreoretinal abnormalities. Physical examination shows a spare figure, weight of 40 kg, height of 150 cm, temperature of 36.7 °C, pulse of 98 b/min, respiratory rate of 19/min, and blood pressure of 108/65 mmHg. Heart and lung auscultation are normal.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is bilateral cataracts, indicated by milky, opaque lenses and significantly impaired vision. Differential diagnoses could include other genetic ocular conditions, considering the consanguinity of the patient's parents and developmental history. The prognosis depends on the timely surgical intervention and management of potential genetic factors.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to refer the patient to an ophthalmology specialist for further evaluation and potential cataract surgery. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's ocular health closely. Educate the patient on the importance of regular eye examinations and potential genetic counseling given the family history. Ensure compliance with scheduled visits and treatment plans.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been diagnosed with coronary artery disease and had a stent placement recently. But they found a lung nodule on my chest radiograph at that time.
Doctor: I see. Have you undergone any further tests to investigate the lung nodule?
Patient: Yes, I underwent a computed tomography (CT) scan and a bronchoscopy.
Doctor: What were the findings from those tests?
Patient: They found a 9 mm fatty endobronchial lesion in the bronchus intermedius above the middle lobe with a 2 cm extraluminal fatty lesion into the right hilum.
Doctor: Did they perform any additional procedures like an endobronchial ultrasound with biopsy of the mass?
Patient: Yes, they did. They found benign bronchial epithelial cells.
Doctor: That's good news. Since endobronchial resection of the mass would lead to a large defect in the right bronchus intermedius, we decided to perform robotic-assisted resection of the lesion. We used the Da Vinci Xi robot for the procedure. Have you seen the video of the operation?
Patient: No, I haven't. How did the operation go?
Doctor: We first performed a right lower lobe superior segmentectomy to get adequate exposure of the hilar mass. We then mobilized the superior segmental branch of the pulmonary artery and divided it with the vascular robot stapler. The same was done for the superior segmental branch of the right lower lobe bronchus.
Patient: Hmm, alright.
Doctor: We used indocyanine green angiography to define the borders of the superior segment of the right lower lobe, which was divided using the robot blue load stapler. This provided access to the hilar fatty tumor, allowing for its removal and subsequent resection of the endobronchial lesion with scissors.
Patient: Were the lesions cancerous?
Doctor: No, the frozen section on both lesions was negative for malignancy. We confirmed complete resection with intraoperative bronchoscopy, which also showed a large opening in the airway.
Patient: So, what's next?
Doctor: To reconstruct the airway, we placed two 3-0 vicryl stay sutures at the proximal and distal ends of the airway and pulled the airway posteriorly away from the suture line through the posterior ports.
Patient: I see. What do I need to do for follow-up care?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your recovery and schedule follow-up appointments to ensure the airway reconstruction is successful and no complications arise. It's important that you continue to follow a healthy lifestyle and report any new symptoms or concerns to your healthcare team.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, previously

Objective.Physical_Exam: A large opening in the airway
Objective.Observations: The patient underwent a right lower lobe superior segmentectomy, mobilization and division of the superior segmental branch of the pulmonary artery and bronchus using a vascular robot stapler, and removal of the hilar fatty tumor. Indocyanine green angiography was used to define the borders of the superior segment of the right lower lobe. Intraoperative bronchoscopy confirmed complete resection and revealed a large opening in the airway. Airway reconstruction was performed using 3-0 vicryl stay sutures.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is benign endobronchial and extraluminal fatty lesions in the right lung. The successful robotic-assisted resection and airway reconstruction indicate a positive immediate outcome. The absence of malignancy in the frozen section of both lesions is reassuring, though continued monitoring is necessary to ensure successful airway healing and to detect any potential complications early.

Plan.Treatment: The patient is scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and ensure successful airway reconstruction. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any new symptoms or concerns. Close monitoring by the healthcare team is essential to manage and prevent potential complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 46-year-old woman who has been treated for anaplastic oligoastrocytoma with radiation therapy and is currently taking temozolomide. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having a cough and palpitations recently.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me check your vital signs. On admission, your blood pressure is 115/83 mm Hg, heart rate is 117 beats/min, body temperature is 36.5°C, and SpO2 is 96% with an O2 2 L/min cannula. We'll also perform a 12-lead electrocardiogram to assess your heart function, which shows sinus tachycardia and SIQIII TIII, with negative T in V1–3.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean, doc?
Doctor: It indicates that your heart is beating faster than normal. We'll also perform an ultrasound cardiogram (UCG) which shows a distended right ventricle, D-shape (+), moderate tricuspid valve regurgitation, and moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension with a maximum pressure gradient of 59 mm Hg.
Patient: That sounds concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it's something we need to address. We'll also take a Chest X-ray, which shows distended pulmonary arteries and interstitial lung infiltrate. Given these findings, we suspect pulmonary embolism, so we'll have you undergo an emergency computed tomography (CT) scan.
Patient: What did the CT scan show?
Doctor: The enhanced chest CT showed no signs of thrombus in the major pulmonary arteries, but it did reveal nodular opacities with a tree-in-bud pattern. The abdominal CT showed a slightly distended gastric wall with some lymphadenopathies.
Patient: What about my blood test results?
Doctor: Your laboratory data showed decreased platelets (71 × 103/μL), activated partial thromboplastin time of 30.7 seconds, prothrombin time-international normalized ratio of 1.19, fibrinogen level of 100 mg/dL, and increased D-dimer (20.08 μg/mL). No signs of infection were detected, with a white blood count of 7450/μL, C-reactive protein of 0.24 mg/dL, and βd-glucan level below 2.4 pg/mL.
Patient: So, what's the plan, doctor?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we believe you may have temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated with disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure. We'll admit you to the hospital for further treatment.
Patient: What will the treatment involve?
Doctor: We'll start you on steroid pulse therapy with methylprednisolone 1 g/d to treat the interstitial pneumonia. Additionally, we'll administer recombinant thrombomodulin and continuous heparin infusion to manage your hypercoagulable state.
Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor. I hope this helps with my symptoms.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll closely monitor your progress and adjust the treatment as necessary. If you have any questions or concerns during your stay, please don't hesitate to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 46-year-old woman with a history of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma treated with radiation and temozolomide, presents with recent symptoms of cough and palpitations.

Objective.Observations: Vital signs show blood pressure at 115/83 mm Hg, heart rate at 117 beats/min, body temperature at 36.5°C, and SpO2 at 96% on 2 L/min O2 cannula. The 12-lead electrocardiogram indicates sinus tachycardia and SIQIII TIII pattern with negative T in V1–3. Ultrasound cardiogram reveals a distended right ventricle, D-shape (+), moderate tricuspid valve regurgitation, and moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension with a maximum pressure gradient of 59 mm Hg. Chest X-ray shows distended pulmonary arteries and interstitial lung infiltrate. Enhanced chest CT shows no thrombus but nodular opacities with a tree-in-bud pattern; abdominal CT shows a slightly distended gastric wall with lymphadenopathies. Laboratory data indicates decreased platelets (71 × 103/μL), activated partial thromboplastin time of 30.7 seconds, prothrombin time-international normalized ratio of 1.19, fibrinogen level of 100 mg/dL, and increased D-dimer (20.08 μg/mL). White blood count is 7450/μL, C-reactive protein is 0.24 mg/dL, and βd-glucan level is below 2.4 pg/mL.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated by disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure. Differential diagnoses include pulmonary embolism, which was ruled out by CT imaging.

Plan.Treatment: The patient will be admitted for inpatient care and started on steroid pulse therapy with methylprednisolone 1 g/d for interstitial pneumonia. Recombinant thrombomodulin and continuous heparin infusion will be administered to manage the hypercoagulable state. The treatment plan will be closely monitored and adjusted as necessary, with ongoing evaluation of cardiac and pulmonary status.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you are a 40-year-old primiparous woman and you were diagnosed with submucosal fibroids 5 years prior. Can you tell me about the symptoms you experienced at that time?
Patient: Yes, I had atypical genital bleeding and hypermenorrhea.
Doctor: I see that you underwent a hysteroscopic myomectomy for the removal of two fibroids. However, you developed secondary hypomenorrhea after the surgery. Can you describe your menstrual flow during that time?
Patient: It was really light and not like before.
Doctor: In order to investigate the cause, your previous doctor performed hysterosalpingography and magnetic resonance imaging. The findings suggested intrauterine adhesions and uterine cavity narrowing. Hysteroscopy revealed filmy adhesions at the excision site, and you were diagnosed with Asherman's syndrome.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Eight months after the diagnosis, you underwent hysteroscopic adhesiolysis. The adhesions on the left side of the fundus were easily separated with Hegar cervical dilators, and an intrauterine device was inserted after dilation. This treatment led to the improvement of your menstrual flow. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, my menstrual flow returned to normal after the operation.
Doctor: I understand that you have been trying to conceive for a long time. You pursued in vitro fertilization (IVF) and unfortunately experienced a miscarriage at 7 weeks of gestation, after which you underwent cervical dilatation and uterine curettage. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what happened.
Doctor: Six months after the miscarriage, you became pregnant again through IVF and were referred to our hospital at 7 weeks of gestation. At 19 weeks, we performed an obstetric ultrasound, and at 31 weeks, we used MRI to determine that there were amniotic sheets in the amniotic cavity. The pregnancy was uneventful after that. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, everything seemed to be going well.
Doctor: At 38 weeks and 2 days of gestation, due to the breech presentation, we performed an elective cesarean section. However, the placenta adhered to the uterine wall after childbirth and could not be easily removed. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what happened.
Doctor: I understand that this has been a challenging journey for you. We will continue to monitor your recovery and provide the necessary care. If you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your support and guidance.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, I had atypical genital bleeding and hypermenorrhea
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 40-year-old primiparous woman who initially presented with atypical genital bleeding and hypermenorrhea due to submucosal fibroids, diagnosed 5 years ago. Post-hysteroscopic myomectomy, she developed hypomenorrhea and was later

Objective.Physical_Exam: Intrauterine adhesions and uterine cavity narrowing
Objective.Observations: Previous interventions include hysteroscopic myomectomy, hysterosalpingography, MRI confirming intrauterine adhesions, and hysteroscopic adhesiolysis with insertion of an intrauterine device. Recent obstetric care involved an elective cesarean section at 38 weeks and 2 days due to breech presentation, with complications of placenta accreta noted during delivery.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is Asherman's syndrome post-myomectomy, with a history of submucosal fibroids and complications from IVF treatments, including a miscarriage and placenta accreta during the recent cesarean section. Differential diagnoses previously considered included other causes of abnormal uterine bleeding and infertility.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's postpartum recovery, particularly regarding the complications from placenta accreta. Continued support for emotional and physical aspects of postpartum recovery and infertility issues will be provided. Referral to a fertility specialist for further assessment and potential treatment options post-recovery is recommended. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms or concerns during her recovery period immediately.
Plan.Follow-Up: My menstrual flow returned to normal after the operation

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were hospitalized in January 2018 for a tumor of the tongue (Fig. a). Can you tell me more about the symptoms you experienced?
Patient: Yeah, I noticed a lump on the left side of my tongue and it was quite painful.
Doctor: I understand. In your records, it also mentions some comorbidity factors, such as a gastric ulcer in 1983, vein thrombosis in 2016, and smoking and alcohol abuse, which you stopped in 2015. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: In 2017, you were treated with radio-chemotherapy for an invasive carcinoma of the anal canal, stage T3NxM0. How was your recovery from that treatment?
Patient: It was quite tough, but I managed to get through it.
Doctor: Good to hear. Now, back to your tongue tumor. Upon examination, it was localized on the submucosal part of the tongue and measured 11 × 11 mm at MRI (Fig. b). You then had a surgical removal of the tumor (Fig. a). How have you been feeling since the surgery?
Patient: I've been feeling better, but still a bit uneasy about the whole situation.
Doctor: I understand your concerns. The histological analysis of the specimen showed that the bulk of the tumor was localized in the tongue muscle, and the upper part of the lesion was remaining at 0.5 mm of the basal membrane (Fig. b). The epithelium was normal, without ulceration or intra-epithelial neoplasia. At higher magnification, the tumor corresponded to a squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), keratinizing (Fig. c). The stroma presented moderate lymphocytic infiltration, but no vascular or peri-neural invasion was seen. Immunophenotyping revealed a strong p16 labeling (100% of the cells) (Fig. d). The tumor was well limited in the periphery and the surgical margins were clear. 
Patient: Okay, so what does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that the tumor was successfully removed and the surgical margins were clear, which is a good sign. However, considering your previous diagnosis of carcinoma of the anal canal, we compared the histological features of the two tumors and performed complementary virological analyses to check for a possible metastasis to the tongue from the original primary anal tumor.
Patient: And what did you find?
Doctor: Both the anal and lingual tumors corresponded to bona fide SCCs (Fig. c, e). The keratinization in the anal carcinoma was less pronounced, and a poorly differentiated component somewhat reminiscent of a basaloid carcinoma was also present, exhibiting necrotic foci. At the upper part of the anal tumor specimen, there was an ulceration edged by lateral extension of high-grade intra-epithelial neoplasia.
Patient: So, is there any connection between the two tumors?
Doctor: Based on the histological analysis and virological tests, it's not clear whether the lingual tumor is a metastasis from the anal carcinoma. However, we will continue to monitor your condition closely to ensure that any potential issues are addressed promptly.
Patient: I appreciate that, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please make sure to attend regular follow-up appointments and notify us if you experience any unusual symptoms.
Patient: Will do, thank you.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I noticed a lump on the left side of my tongue and it was quite painful
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reported a painful lump on the left side of the tongue, which led to the discovery and surgical removal of a tumor. The patient has a history of significant medical conditions including a gastric ulcer, vein thrombosis, and a previous invasive carcinoma of the anal canal treated with radio-chemotherapy. The patient has ceased smoking and alcohol abuse since 2015.

Objective.Physical_Exam: A lump on the left side of my tongue
Objective.Observations: Examination revealed a tumor localized on the submucosal part of the tongue, measuring 11 × 11 mm on MRI. Histological analysis post-surgery showed squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), keratinizing, with the tumor well-limited in the periphery and clear surgical margins. Immunophenotyping showed strong p16 labeling. No vascular or peri-neural invasion was observed. Virological tests and histological comparison with a previously treated anal carcinoma were inconclusive in determining if the lingual tumor was a metastasis.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue, surgically excised with clear margins. Differential diagnosis includes potential metastasis from previously diagnosed anal carcinoma, although current evidence does not definitively confirm this. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the clear surgical margins and absence of invasive features, but close monitoring is necessary due to the patient's complex oncological history.

Plan.Treatment: The patient will be scheduled for regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms immediately. Continued surveillance includes regular imaging and possibly further biopsies to ensure no metastatic spread or new tumor development. The importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle free from tobacco and excessive alcohol is emphasized to reduce the risk of recurrence.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, can you tell me what brought you in today?
Patient: Yeah, I came in because I've been having a headache, feeling really tired, and I've got a fever too.
Doctor: I see. When did these symptoms start?
Patient: They started around midnight, back in June 2014.
Doctor: Hmm, and did you experience any other symptoms after that?
Patient: Yes, about 150 minutes later, I developed some meningitis symptoms like nausea, drowsiness, confusion, a stiff neck, and a positive Kernig sign.
Doctor: That sounds concerning. What kind of treatment did you receive initially?
Patient: I was given 1000 mg of Amoxicillin, 1000 mg of Paracetamol, and an IV dose of Ringer's lactate solution.
Doctor: Okay, and were you transferred to another medical facility after that?
Patient: Yes, by 9:30 A.M. I was transferred to the emergency department of Military Hospital 108 because I started showing symptoms of blood sepsis.
Doctor: I see. So you were diagnosed with meningitis and sepsis, correct?
Patient: That's right.
Doctor: And how were you treated for these conditions?
Patient: They treated me with ceftriaxone at a dose of 1 g, four times a day.
Doctor: Good. I understand that your cerebrospinal fluid was collected and a N. meningitidis culture was grown. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, the culture they grew was designated as DuyDNT, and it was identified to belong to serogroup B.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that you recovered successfully after treatment. Now, on the topic of the DuyDNT isolate, it has been revealed to be a novel sequence type. It was assigned an ST 13074 by PubMLST, a public database that catalogs genetic data and isolate provenance of the Neisseria genus. Did you know that?
Patient: No, I didn't know that.
Doctor: By sequencing the seven housekeeping genes used in the MLST scheme, every N. meningitidis isolate can be assigned a sequence type (ST) and placed into groups and clonal complexes based on evolutionary relatedness. Besides DuyDNT, only two other isolates of ST 13074 have been found, both were carrier strains identified in Vietnam in 2017. ST 13074 shared ≥ 5 identical alleles at seven typed loci with three other STs (1576, 11013, and 13455), making it the central ST of this group by PubMLST group's definition.
Patient: Oh, I see. That's interesting.
Doctor: Yes, it is. Now, moving forward, it's essential that you continue monitoring your health and reporting any concerning symptoms to your healthcare provider. Keep up with any required follow-up appointments, and take care of yourself.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to keep an eye on my health and follow your advice.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I came in because I've been having a headache, feeling really tired, and I've got a fever too
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports experiencing headaches, fatigue, fever, nausea, drowsiness, confusion, a stiff neck, and a positive Kernig sign since midnight, June 2014. Symptoms escalated to include signs of meningitis and later, blood sepsis. The patient was initially treated with Amoxicillin, Paracetamol, and Ringer's lactate solution, followed by a transfer to a specialized facility for further management.
