Doctor: During the surgery, we will find that the innominate vein and superior vena cava are dilated. The right atrium and the right ventricle will also appear dilated. The vertical vein will be seen opening into the innominate vein, and the left pulmonary veins will be seen opening into the vertical vein. We will operate without cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) support.
Patient: I see. What will you do next?
Doctor: We will make a 15 mm opening in the common chamber horizontally after applying a Cooley's clamp. Another opening of similar dimensions will be made over the left atrial appendage. The vertical vein will then be anastomosed to the left atrial appendage posteriorly with 6-0 prolene in a side-to-side fashion. We will then ligate the vertical vein-innominate confluence at the end of the procedure.
Patient: Will he be okay after the surgery?
Doctor: Yes, he will require mechanical ventilation for about 12 hours after the surgery. But, he should recover uneventfully and be discharged on Day 10.
Patient: That's a relief. Thank you, Doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient's mother reports that her 7-year-old son has been experiencing effort intolerance. There are no signs of cyanosis. The chief complaint is primarily related to the child's difficulty in performing activities that require physical exertion.

Objective.Observations: Clinical examination was unremarkable. Doppler echocardiography showed that the left-sided pulmonary veins are draining into the left innominate vein, with normal drainage of the right pulmonary veins into the left atrium. There is no atrial septal defect (ASD), but there is dilation of the right atrium and right ventricle. Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) confirmed the diagnosis of isolated left-sided Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC), with the left pulmonary veins forming a common channel draining into the superior vena cava via the left brachiocephalic vein.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is isolated left-sided supracardiac PAPVC. The dilation of the right atrium and right ventricle are likely secondary to the increased flow and pressure from the anomalous pulmonary venous return. The prognosis is good with surgical correction.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current management; monitor for progression

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 66-year-old man who presented with a bilateral direct inguinal hernia and benign prostatic hyperplasia. To resolve this problem, we performed a TEP (totally extraperitoneal) procedure using mesh and a TURP (transurethral resection of prostate). How are you feeling now?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, but there's some discomfort in my groin area.
Doctor: Alright, let me explain what we did during the surgery. First, we obtained laparoscopic transperitoneal access to minimize the risk of infection during the transurethral resection of your prostate. Then, we repaired your bilateral hernia with laparoscopy by reducing the hernia sac and placing a prosthetic mesh inlay. The mesh used for closing the defect was made of polypropylene.
Patient: Oh, I see. Thanks for explaining that.
Doctor: You're welcome. We also gave you preoperative and postoperative single doses of levofloxacin to further reduce the risk of infection. The laparoscopic procedures of TEP and TURP were done without any difficulties, and the total operating time was 3 hours with an estimated blood loss of 100 cc. 
Patient: Okay, that's good to know.
Doctor: Before the surgery, we did a pathological examination that showed atypical adenomatous hyperplasia with chronic inflammatory cell infiltration. Your PSA level was also high at 29 ng/ml. In the third week after your surgery, we found a hematoma in your right inguinal area. Did you notice any pain or swelling there?
Patient: Yes, I did feel some pain and noticed swelling in that area.
Doctor: We performed an ultrasound examination and found fluid collection in that area. Unfortunately, at your three-month postoperative follow-up, we discovered that you had developed bilateral inguinal abscess and sepsis. We then performed a CT scan, which showed an irregularly shaped mass and prostate. 
Patient: That sounds serious. What did you do to treat it?
Doctor: We conducted an evacuation and debridement laparotomy to treat the inguinal abscess and address the issues caused by the previous laparoscopic surgery. At your next follow-up, we found no evidence of hernia recurrence after the mesh evacuation.
Patient: I'm glad to hear that. What should I do now to ensure proper healing and prevent complications?
Doctor: It's important to keep the surgical area clean and follow all postoperative care instructions. If you notice any signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, or increased pain, please contact me immediately. Additionally, make sure to attend all follow-up appointments so we can monitor your progress and address any issues that may arise.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I'll follow your advice and keep an eye on my recovery.
Doctor: You're welcome, and feel free to contact me if you have any concerns or questions throughout your recovery. Take care!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: I'm feeling okay, but there's some discomfort in my groin area
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The 66-year-old male patient reports discomfort in the groin area following a TEP procedure for bilateral direct inguinal hernia and a TURP for benign prostatic hyperplasia. He also noted pain and swelling in the right inguinal area postoperatively.

Objective.Observations: The patient underwent TEP and TURP with a total operating time of 3 hours and an estimated blood loss of 100 cc. Preoperative and postoperative levofloxacin was administered. Pathological examination revealed atypical adenomatous hyperplasia and chronic inflammatory cell infiltration, with a high PSA level of 29 ng/ml. Postoperative complications included a hematoma in the right inguinal area, confirmed by ultrasound, and bilateral inguinal abscess with sepsis, confirmed by CT scan. Subsequent treatment involved evacuation and debridement laparotomy, with no evidence of hernia recurrence after mesh evacuation.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis of bilateral direct inguinal hernia and benign prostatic hyperplasia, with postoperative complications including hematoma, bilateral inguinal abscess, and sepsis. Differential diagnosis included potential recurrent hernia, which was ruled out after

Plan.Treatment: Continue postoperative care with emphasis on hygiene and monitoring for signs of infection. Patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments for ongoing assessment and management of recovery. Immediate contact with healthcare provider is recommended if signs of infection or other complications arise. Compliance with postoperative instructions is crucial for recovery and prevention of further complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Not so great, doc. I've got this severe soft tissue infection in my leg.
Doctor: I see. Well, you've been admitted to our emergency hospital for treatment. We'll start you on Ceftriaxone and clindamycin for the infection, and prophylactic enoxaparin will be added to your current medications, enalapril and simvastatin.
Patient: Okay, doc. I hope that helps.
Doctor: We'll keep an eye on your progress. Now, I need to ask you about any symptoms you're experiencing. Have you noticed any unusual bruising or bleeding?
Patient: Hmm, not really, just the pain and swelling in my leg.
Doctor: All right. We've been monitoring your laboratory findings, and there's one issue we need to address. You have thrombocytopenia, which means your platelet counts are low. They've dropped from 320x109/L to 8x109/L in EDTA.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: No, it's a concern. We tried giving you three full-dose platelet transfusions over the last two days, but your platelet counts didn't increase. There were no accompanying flags or blood smears mentioned in your medical chart.
Patient: So, what's the plan now?
Doctor: A consultant anesthesiologist suspected PTCP, so we took a blood sample in EDTA, sodium citrate, and heparin. Your platelet counts were 13x109/L in EDTA, but 355x109/L in sodium citrate and 310x109/L in heparin. Thrombocytopenia and platelet aggregates were flagged only in the EDTA aliquot.
Patient: What does that mean, doc?
Doctor: It means we found abnormal platelet histogram and white blood cell counts, suggesting in vitro platelet clumping. This could be causing the low platelet counts in the EDTA sample.
Patient: I see. So what's the next step?
Doctor: Unfortunately, your leg is deemed beyond salvage. We need to perform an amputation under spinal anesthesia. The procedure will be carried out uneventfully, and we'll continue to monitor your recovery.
Patient: I understand, doc. Thank you for explaining everything to me.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Not so great, doc
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports severe pain and swelling in the leg, diagnosed as a soft tissue infection. No unusual bruising or bleeding noted. The patient is currently on enalapril and simvastatin, with recent additions of Ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and prophylactic enoxaparin.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Abnormal platelet histogram and white blood cell counts
Objective.Observations: Vital signs are within normal limits. Lab findings indicate thrombocytopenia with a significant drop in platelet count from 320x10^9/L to 8x10^9/L in EDTA, despite three full-dose platelet transfusions. Platelet counts in sodium citrate and heparin are normal (355x10^9/L and 310x10^9/L, respectively), suggesting in vitro platelet clumping in EDTA samples. No improvement in platelet count post-transfusion in EDTA.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is severe soft tissue infection with secondary pseudothrombocytopenia due to in vitro clumping of platelets in EDTA. Differential diagnosis includes true thrombocytopenia, which was ruled out by normal platelet counts in non-EDTA samples. The leg infection is severe enough to require amputation.

Plan.Treatment: Continue antibiotic treatment with Ceftriaxone and clindamycin. Enoxaparin will be used for thromboprophylaxis. Amputation of the affected leg is planned under spinal anesthesia. Post-operative care will include monitoring for infection and recovery progress. Patient education on the procedure and recovery expectations will be provided. Referral to a rehabilitation specialist post-amputation for mobility training and adaptation.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been diagnosed with liver masses and I'm here for a transplantation.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: I'm not really sure about the details, but I had a biopsy done that confirmed the diagnosis.
Doctor: Okay, let's take a look at your imaging results. Your preoperative imaging shows an enlarged liver with multifocal disease throughout the hepatic parenchyma. The lesions show peripheral enhancement with central hypoattenuation on arterial phase and appear isodense to the liver parenchyma on delayed phase imaging. Some of the masses also have calcifications. There hasn't been a significant interval change in size in the 10 months since your initial diagnosis. No chest or pelvic masses were identified during the preoperative workup. 
Patient: Hmm, that sounds complicated. What does it all mean?
Doctor: It means that there are multiple areas of disease in your liver with various characteristics. The fact that there hasn't been a significant change in size over the past 10 months is a positive sign. Let's talk about the pathologic examination of your liver. It revealed multiple tan discrete nodules ranging from 0.5 to 3.0 cm in greatest dimension, involving the bilateral lobes. 
Patient: What does that mean for my condition?
Doctor: The examination showed two main histologic patterns. One subset of the nodules contained well-formed vascular channels and scattered cords of tumor cells embedded in a sclerotic hyalinized matrix. Other areas of the tumor were characterized by small, irregular central hyalinized scars containing subtle foci of neoplastic cells and a mild bile ductular reaction.
Patient: What about the other findings?
Doctor: On high magnification, the tumor cells exhibited mild cytologic atypia and were characterized by abundant pale cytoplasm, nuclei bearing open chromatin, and visible though not large nucleoli. Scattered intracytoplasmic vacuoles were noted in the tumor cells arranged in a linear pattern. Mitotic figures were not observed; however, focal vascular invasion by single tumor cells was noted. There was also stromal lymphocytic inflammation and focal calcification in one of the lesions. The surrounding liver parenchyma had a nodular architecture, reminiscent of focal nodular hyperplasia.
Patient: And what about the immunohistochemical results?
Doctor: Immunohistochemically, the tumor cells showed an endothelial phenotype with strong expression of CD31 and ERG. The tumor nuclei were also positive for TFE3 but not for CAMTA1.
Patient: So, what does all this mean for my treatment and prognosis?
Doctor: This information helps us better understand the nature of your liver masses and guides us in determining the most appropriate course of treatment, which in this case is transplantation. Your prognosis will depend on how well your body responds to the transplantation and any necessary follow-up treatments. We will closely monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your explanation and guidance throughout this process.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports being

Objective.Observations: Preoperative imaging reveals an enlarged liver with multifocal disease throughout the hepatic parenchyma, peripheral enhancement with central hypoattenuation on arterial phase, and isodensity on delayed phase imaging. Calcifications are noted in some masses. No significant change in mass size over 10 months. Pathologic examination shows multiple tan nodules (0.5 to 3.0 cm) in bilateral lobes, with two histologic patterns: well-formed vascular channels and scattered cords of tumor cells in a sclerotic matrix, and areas with central hyalinized scars and neoplastic cells. Immunohistochemical results show strong expression of CD31 and ERG, positive TFE3, and negative CAMTA1 in tumor cells.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient has multifocal hepatic masses with features suggestive of a vascular neoplasm, possibly a variant of hepatic hemangioma or angiosarcoma, given the vascular nature and immunohistochemical staining. The stable size of the masses and detailed histologic and immunohistochemical findings support a controlled but cautious approach, with liver transplantation as the indicated treatment.

Plan.Treatment: Proceed with liver transplantation as planned. Post-transplantation, closely monitor the patient for signs of rejection and manage immunosuppression carefully. Regular follow-up appointments will be necessary to assess liver function and detect any recurrence of disease. Educate the patient on signs of complications related to transplantation and ensure understanding of the need for lifelong follow-up and care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you have been diagnosed with refractory AML and were admitted to our hospital for treatment. We have planned an EMA regimen for you, which includes mitoxantrone, etoposide, and cytarabine. We will need to insert a central venous catheter and start chemotherapy. How have you been feeling lately?
Patient: I've been okay, but I'm a bit worried about the treatment.
Doctor: It's normal to feel worried, but we will do our best to help you through this process. After the chemotherapy, you might experience some side effects. For example, you might become feverish due to catheter-related infection. We'll be closely monitoring your oral temperature and absolute neutrophil count. 
Patient: Hmm, alright.
Doctor: We will also be conducting regular evaluations to check for anemia and thrombocytopenia. Your current hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dl, and your platelet count is 20,000 per microliter. 
Patient: What about urinalysis?
Doctor: Your urinalysis results are normal. In case of an infection, we will prescribe meropenem and teicoplanin as antibiotics. Ultrasonography may also be used to check for any thrombosis in your jugular vein. 
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We have detected Staphylococcus epidermidis in the blood cultures of your central line and peripheral vein. Antibiotic lock therapy will be started along with systemic antibiotics.
Patient: And if I have a fever?
Doctor: If you become feverish again, we will investigate further. In a previous case, a patient had episodes of fever and neutropenia, but their vital signs were stable. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the paranasal sinuses revealed sinusitis with hyperdense opacification.
Patient: What was the treatment for that?
Doctor: They were given Liposomal amphotericin B (LAMB) and underwent sinus endoscopy and functional endoscopic sinus surgery.
Patient: I see. What if I develop skin lesions?
Doctor: If you develop painful, erythematous macular and papular lesions resembling ecthyma gangrenosum, we will perform a skin lesion biopsy to determine the cause. In a similar case, the patient also complained of loss of vision in their left eye, and fundoscopic examination revealed endophthalmitis.
Patient: What was done for their eye?
Doctor: Intravitreal AMB was added to their systemic antifungal therapy to treat the endophthalmitis. We will closely monitor your condition and take necessary actions based on your symptoms.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything. I feel more informed now.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any more questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We are here to help you through this process.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: I've been okay, but I'm a bit worried about the treatment
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient,

Objective.Observations: The patient's current hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dl, and platelet count is 20,000 per microliter, indicating anemia and thrombocytopenia. Urinalysis results are normal. Blood cultures from the central line and peripheral vein have grown Staphylococcus epidermidis. The patient is scheduled for chemotherapy via a central venous catheter, with close monitoring of oral temperature and absolute neutrophil count to watch for fever and infection.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is refractory AML. The patient is at risk for catheter-related infections, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and potential complications from chemotherapy, such as fever and neutropenia. Differential diagnoses for any fever include sinusitis, as indicated by previous cases, and potential skin and ocular infections.

Plan.Treatment: The treatment plan includes starting the EMA chemotherapy regimen and inserting a central venous catheter. Prophylactic antibiotic lock therapy and systemic antibiotics (meropenem and teicoplanin) will be administered due to the presence of Staphylococcus epidermidis. Regular evaluations will monitor for anemia, thrombocytopenia, and infection signs. In case of fever, further investigations will be conducted, potentially including CT scans and ultrasonography for thrombosis. If skin lesions or ocular symptoms develop, biopsy and fundoscopic examination will be performed, respectively, with appropriate treatments such as intravitreal antifungal therapy for endophthalmitis. The patient will be educated about the signs of complications and encouraged to report any new symptoms promptly.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I heard you were brought to the emergency department from your nursing home due to respiratory distress and altered mental status. How are you feeling now?
Patient: Yeah, I was having trouble breathing and feeling really out of it.
Doctor: We intubated you promptly on arrival to help with your breathing. I have reviewed your past medical history, and it seems you have had an intracranial aneurysm with bleeding after a VP shunt placement, ischemic stroke with aphasia and paraplegia, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Your vital signs and clinical laboratory results have been presented to me. Based on your condition, we suspect you might be experiencing septic shock. We've ordered a sepsis workup, including two sets of blood cultures and a urine culture. In the meantime, we're treating you with aggressive intravenous fluid hydration and broad-spectrum antibiotics, vancomycin and meropenem.
Patient: Oh, okay. I hope that helps.
Doctor: We also performed a non-contrast computed tomography (CT) of your chest, abdomen, and pelvis. The results showed bibasilar pulmonary atelectasis, which means your lungs are partially collapsed, but there's no focal infiltrate. The CT scan also revealed the presence of a right-sided VP shunt catheter traversing your right neck, chest, and abdominal wall. Interestingly, the tip of the catheter is located within your gastric lumen, and it seems to have entered through the PEG tube insertion site.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also noticed that the PEG tube is outside your gastric lumen, and it terminates in your abdominal wall. A repeat CT scan confirmed that you have abdominal wall cellulitis and localized abscesses around the PEG tube insertion site. Medical records from another facility show that the PEG tube and VP shunt catheter were in normal positions one year prior.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: Given the malposition of the VP shunt inside your gastric lumen, we suspected a possible VP shunt infection or meningitis/encephalitis. We performed a lumbar puncture, but the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis came back unremarkable. Thankfully, your blood cultures and urine culture results were also negative.
Patient: That's a relief, I guess.
Doctor: However, your wound culture tested positive for Proteus mirabilis, which is sensitive to carbapenems and piperacillin/tazobactam. We've debrided your abdominal wall and drained the abscess. We'll continue your intravenous antibiotic coverage according to the sensitivity testing.
Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll continue to monitor your condition closely. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I was having trouble breathing and feeling really out of it
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a resident of a nursing home, was admitted to the emergency department with respiratory distress and altered mental status. The patient reported difficulty breathing and feeling disoriented. The patient has a significant medical history including an intracranial aneurysm with post-surgical bleeding, ischemic stroke resulting in aphasia and paraplegia, and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement.

Objective.Observations: Upon admission, the patient was intubated for respiratory support. Vital signs and clinical laboratory results indicated a potential septic shock, prompting a sepsis workup including blood and urine cultures. Initial treatment included aggressive intravenous fluid hydration and broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin and meropenem). A non-contrast CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed bibasilar pulmonary atelectasis and malposition of the VP shunt catheter inside the gastric lumen, with the PEG tube terminating outside the gastric lumen. Abdominal wall cellulitis and localized abscesses were noted around the PEG tube insertion site. CSF analysis and cultures were negative, but wound culture grew Proteus mirabilis, sensitive to carbapenems and piperacillin/tazobactam.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to abdominal wall cellulitis and localized abscesses, complicated by malpositioned VP shunt and PEG tube. Differential diagnoses included VP shunt infection and meningitis/encephalitis, which were ruled out by CSF analysis and culture results.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes continuation of intravenous antibiotics based on sensitivity testing, close monitoring of the patient's clinical status, and supportive care for respiratory and circulatory stabilization. Surgical consultation for potential correction of the VP shunt and PEG tube malposition is recommended. The patient will be educated about the treatment plan and monitored for any signs of worsening infection or other complications. Regular follow-ups and reassessment of the treatment efficacy will be scheduled.
Plan.Follow-Up: We'll continue your intravenous antibiotic coverage

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello there, I understand you were referred to our Emergency Department after experiencing a high velocity frontal collision with a car while riding a motorcycle. Can you tell me a bit more about yourself?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 49-year-old Caucasian man, married and working as a car body repairer. I've never smoked or drank, and I'm not on any medication.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Our prehospital primary survey assessment according to ATLS protocols showed that you were hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 136/82 mmHg and a heart rate of 65 beats per minute. You had no airway or breathing alterations, and you were oriented and conscious. You reported pain in the symphyseal region and left arm. We provided cervical spine immobilization and intravenous access, and applied a pelvic binder, the SAM® Pelvic Sling™ II.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that. I was feeling quite alert at that time.
Doctor: When you arrived at our ED, we observed that you were alert without any relevant cardiorespiratory dysfunction. Your body temperature was 36.8 °C, heart rate 65 bpm, blood pressure 132/80 mmHg, oxygen saturation 100%, and Glasgow Coma Scale of 15. During our secondary survey, we found a deformation in your left wrist and painful palpation of the pubic symphysis and sacral region. We maintained the pelvic binder and conducted a total body CT scan with two-dimensional MPR and three-dimensional reconstruction.
Patient: What did the CT scan show?
Doctor: The CT scan findings revealed mild normocytic anemia (133 g/l), but your liver and renal functions were normal. We also provided a chronologic timeline of your patient management and investigations in the Additional file. No relevant pelvic anomaly was detected, even after three-dimensional reconstruction.
Patient: So, what's next?
Doctor: Because of the high velocity of the crash and persisting symphyseal pain, we ordered plain anteroposterior pelvic radiography shortly after the CT. The pelvic radiography revealed a non-osseous pelvic disruption, with an opening of the pubic symphysis (more than 2.2 cm) and of the left sacroiliac joint (type 61).
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that we need to closely monitor your condition and provide appropriate treatment to address the pelvic disruption. We will keep you informed of any further findings and discuss the best course of action to ensure your recovery.
Patient: Okay, thank you for the information and taking care of me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help you.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I'm a 49-year-old Caucasian man, married and working as a car body repairer
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: 49-year-old Caucasian male, car body repairer, non-smoker, non-drinker, not on any medication, presented to the Emergency Department following a high velocity frontal collision while on a motorcycle. Reports pain in the symphyseal region and left arm. No previous medical history provided.

Objective.Observations: Initial vital signs at scene: BP 136/82 mmHg, HR 65 bpm, alert and oriented. On arrival to ED: BP 132/80 mmHg, HR 65 bpm, Temp 36.8 °C, SpO2 100%, GCS 15. Physical exam revealed deformation in left wrist, painful palpation of pubic symphysis and sacral region. CT scan showed mild normocytic anemia (133 g/l), normal liver and renal functions, no pelvic anomalies. Pelvic radiography indicated non-osseous pelvic disruption with opening of pubic symphysis (>2.2 cm) and left sacroiliac joint (type 61).

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis of non-osseous pelvic disruption secondary to high velocity trauma. Differential diagnosis includes potential complications from pelvic instability. Prognosis depends on response to treatment and management of complications.

Plan.Treatment: Maintain pelvic binder and monitor vitals closely. Administer analgesics for pain management. Plan for orthopedic consultation to evaluate need for surgical intervention for pelvic disruption. Regular follow-ups to monitor healing and function. Educate patient on the importance of adhering to treatment plan and follow-up schedules. Provide psychological support and information regarding potential recovery trajectory and complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented with a chief complaint of persistent bright red blood per rectum. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing this bleeding quite recently. It was one large episode of bright red blood with blood clots.
Doctor: I understand. I also see from your history that you have hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, coronary artery disease with three prior myocardial infarctions, recurrent cerebrovascular accidents requiring anticoagulation with warfarin, gastroesophageal reflux disease, asthma, and endometrial cancer. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Regarding your endometrial cancer, fifteen months prior to this presentation, you were diagnosed with a grade 1 endometrial adenoma but were not considered a good surgical candidate due to your multiple comorbidities. Vaginal hysterectomy was considered but due to your long and narrow vagina, this option was deferred initially. Your treatment option was radiation therapy and brachytherapy. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see that you eventually underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy due to continued pelvic pain. How has your recovery been from that surgery?
Patient: It's been okay, but I still have some pain from time to time.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Now, regarding your recent bleeding, have you experienced any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or melena?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Your most recent colonoscopy was performed four months ago and revealed three diminutive polyps in the transverse colon, with pathology confirming tubular adenoma. Your physical examination today showed mild left-sided abdominal tenderness, but was otherwise unremarkable. Your rectal examination showed nonbleeding hemorrhoids and no visible blood. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Your blood work revealed white blood cells of 14.3k/uL (normal range 4.3-10.0 k/uL) and hemoglobin of 9.6 g/dL (normal range 11.8-14.8 g/dL), which is similar to your baseline. Your creatinine was slightly elevated to 1.2 and blood urea nitrogen was elevated to 39. Your international normalized ratio was 2.0. Due to the large volume of hematochezia and presence of anemia, we decided to admit you to the hospital for further evaluation. 
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: You underwent a colonoscopy which revealed a large, fungating, friable, and ulcerated lesion. We'll be discussing your case with a team of specialists to determine the best course of action for your treatment. In the meantime, please let me or the nursing staff know if you experience any changes in your symptoms or if you have any questions.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to keep you informed and provide the best care possible.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, I've been experiencing this bleeding quite recently
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a recent episode of significant bright red blood per rectum with blood clots. The patient has a complex medical history including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, coronary artery disease with three prior myocardial infarctions, recurrent cerebrovascular accidents requiring anticoagulation with warfarin, gastroesophageal reflux disease, asthma, and endometrial cancer treated with radiation therapy, brachytherapy, and total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy. The patient denies experiencing abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or melena.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed mild left-sided abdominal tenderness but was otherwise unremarkable. Rectal examination showed nonbleeding hemorrhoids and no visible blood. Recent colonoscopy identified three diminutive polyps in the transverse colon, confirmed as tubular adenomas. Blood work showed elevated white blood cells at 14.3k/uL, low hemoglobin at 9.6 g/dL, slightly elevated creatinine at 1.2, and elevated blood urea nitrogen at 39. International normalized ratio was 2.0. A subsequent colonoscopy revealed a large, fungating, friable, and ulcerated lesion.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a large ulcerated lesion in the colon, likely contributing to the hematochezia. Differential diagnoses include colorectal cancer or a severe form of inflammatory bowel disease, considering the patient's history and current presentation. The patient's anemia and elevated inflammatory markers are concerning and warrant further investigation.

Plan.Treatment: The patient has been admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management. A multidisciplinary team consultation is planned to discuss the treatment options for the identified lesion. The patient will be monitored closely for changes in symptoms and vital signs. Blood transfusions may be considered if hemoglobin levels drop further or if the patient exhibits symptoms of significant anemia. Anticoagulation therapy with warfarin will be managed carefully in the context of the current bleeding and potential surgical interventions. Patient education will be provided regarding the findings and the planned investigations and treatments to ensure understanding and compliance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 43-year-old male of Japanese Brazilian descent. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing hypesthesia from my right lower lip to the mental region, so I decided to consult a hospital for the first visit.
Doctor: I see. Have you undergone any tests or examinations for this issue?
Patient: Yes, I had a computed tomography (CT) scan, which revealed a round radiolucent area in my right mandibular body. After that, a biopsy was carried out, and I was diagnosed with schwannoma.
Doctor: I understand. You've been referred to our Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery here at Gunma University Hospital for a detailed examination and treatment. Let's discuss your current physical and nutritional status. How do you feel overall?
Patient: I think my physical status is moderate, and my nutritional status is favorable. There's no other notable factor, I believe.
Doctor: That's good to hear. We also conducted a visual inspection, and there was no tumor lesion found in your oral cavity. We did, however, note hypesthesia extending from your right lower lip to the mental region, with the perception level being approximately 50% of that on the unaffected side. The CT imaging showed dilation of the mandibular canal, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an irregular high signal intensity on horizontal sections of short inversion time inversion recovery (STIR). On sagittal sections, dilation of the right mandibular canal was observed around the mandibular foramen. Dynamic images showed crescendo enhancement.
Patient: Hmm, okay. So, what do the preoperative biopsy findings suggest?
Doctor: The biopsy findings from the first hospital you visited suggest a schwannoma involving the Antoni A region. Briefly, the lesion is immature, which means there's an active potential for future tumor growth.
Patient: I see. So, what's the plan for treatment?
Doctor: Considering the risk of future tumor growth, we decided to extirpate the tumor under general anesthesia in late April 2015. During the surgery, we found a cystic tumor (3.2 × 1.0 cm) associated with the inferior alveolar nerve and vessels. As a result, the inferior alveolar nerve was ligated, cut, and extirpated as a mass.
Patient: And what about the results of the surgery?
Doctor: Intraoperative rapid diagnosis confirmed the absence of tumor cells at the margins of the resected nerve specimen, which is a positive sign. During your 2-year postoperative follow-up, we observed radiopacity enhanced at the wound site after extirpation of the tumor, confirming favorable bone outgrowth.
Patient: That's a relief. Thank you for explaining everything, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll continue to monitor your progress and make sure your recovery goes smoothly. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to reach out.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 43-year-old male of Japanese Brazilian descent presenting with hypesthesia from the right lower lip to the mental region. He reports moderate physical status and favorable nutritional status, with no other notable factors.

Objective.Observations: The patient's CT scan showed a round radiolucent area in the right mandibular body, and MRI revealed irregular high signal intensity on STIR horizontal sections and dilation of the right mandibular canal on sagittal sections. Biopsy findings indicated a schwannoma involving the Antoni A region, suggesting immature lesion with active potential for growth. Intraoperative findings included a cystic tumor (3.2 × 1.0 cm) associated with the inferior alveolar nerve, which was ligated and extirpated. Postoperative follow-up showed enhanced radiopacity at the wound site, indicating favorable bone outgrowth.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is schwannoma of the right mandibular region. The patient underwent successful surgical extirpation with no tumor cells found at the margins of the resected nerve specimen. The prognosis is favorable with ongoing monitoring.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent tumor extirpation under general anesthesia with subsequent positive outcomes. He will continue to be monitored during his recovery, with regular follow-ups to assess bone outgrowth and ensure no recurrence. The patient is advised to maintain his nutritional status and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see from your history that you're a 51-year-old female with hypertension and stage 4 human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER-2) positive gastric adenocarcinoma with peritoneal, bone, and lymph nodes metastasis. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, recently I had an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. I've never had seizures before.
Doctor: I see. You were diagnosed with stage 4 cancer two years ago, and you've been on trastuzumab, cisplatin, and capecitabine for three cycles, continuing trastuzumab until your presentation, with the last cycle being four weeks prior to presentation, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: We performed a brain MRI with and without contrast which revealed bilateral, symmetric areas of T2-weighted-fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (T2-FLAIR) hyperintensity involving the occipital and posterior parietal lobes. There was no evidence of acute stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, or intracranial metastasis. These findings are suggestive of PRES.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: The multidisciplinary tumor board committee decided that PRES could be attributed to the toxic effect of trastuzumab or your hypertension. We discharged you on levetiracetam with a plan to continue trastuzumab, strictly control your blood pressure, and repeat the MRI in three months.
Patient: Okay, so how was my blood pressure during that time?
Doctor: During that period, your blood pressure was controlled on multiple encounters with all readings being < 140/90.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: A repeated brain MRI with and without contrast revealed persistent T2-FLAIR hyperintensity in the occipital and posterior parietal lobes, still suggestive of PRES. The tumor board decided to hold trastuzumab for one month.
Patient: I see. But recently I was admitted with worsening epigastric pain, and I'm concerned about disease progression.
Doctor: We performed an Esophagogastroduodenoscopy which revealed a large, malignant-appearing, partially obstructing mass in the gastric body with no active bleeding. This indicates that your concern for disease progression is valid.
Patient: Oh no, what's the next step?
Doctor: The tumor board committee will discuss your case and determine the best course of action moving forward. We will keep you informed and involve you in the decision-making process.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the information and your support.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, recently I had an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 51-year-old female with a history of hypertension and

Objective.Observations: The patient has been treated with trastuzumab, cisplatin, and capecitabine, continuing trastuzumab until recently. Brain MRI showed bilateral symmetric T2-FLAIR hyperintensity in the occipital and posterior parietal lobes, suggestive of PRES, with no evidence of acute stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, or metastasis. Blood pressure readings were controlled, all <140/90. A recent Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a large, malignant-appearing, partially obstructing mass in the gastric body, confirming disease progression.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is PRES, likely secondary to trastuzumab toxicity or hypertension, and stage 4 HER-2 positive gastric adenocarcinoma with confirmed progression. Differential diagnosis includes complications from metastasis and side effects of ongoing chemotherapy.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring with levetiracetam for seizure management and strict blood pressure control. Hold trastuzumab for one month and reassess. Repeat brain MRI in three months to monitor PRES. Address gastric mass and disease progression through discussions in the tumor board committee and adjust treatment plan accordingly. Maintain supportive care and involve the patient in decision-making processes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been diagnosed with a sarcoma in 2011 and have had multiple treatments since then.
Doctor: I see, can you tell me about the treatments you've had so far?
Patient: I had my first surgical intervention in 2011 with enucleation of a lesion on my thigh. I also received two cycles of chemotherapy with Ifosfamide and Epirubicin. But the disease locally progressed.
Doctor: It seems that your oncologists decided to perform preoperative radiotherapy and a second, more radical surgical intervention the following year. Were there any recurrences after that?
Patient: Yes, until the end of 2014, I was stable. But in 2015 and 2016, I had to be treated again for local relapses with limb-sparing surgeries, including a left femoro-popliteal bypass.
Doctor: I understand. After these surgeries, did the disease progress any further?
Patient: Unfortunately, yes. The disease distantly progressed with a pulmonary metastatic spread. I was then treated with four high-dose, neoadjuvant chemotherapy cycles of Ifosfamide.
Doctor: Did you have a complete response to the chemotherapy?
Patient: No, the lung lesions decreased but didn't completely disappear. In August 2017, I underwent microwave ablation for the four larger lung lesions to control the disease.
Doctor: It looks like in October 2017, a control magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your left leg and knee showed a new local relapse. Can you tell me about the symptoms you experienced?
Patient: I noticed two pathologic nodules near the scars on my calf and soleus muscle. My doctor confirmed them with an ultrasound examination.
Doctor: Due to your previous therapies, surgical excision was considered not feasible. The first proposed treatment option was leg amputation. What did you decide to do?
Patient: I refused the leg amputation. My oncologist, radiation oncologist, and interventional radiologist decided to attempt treatment with PLA under US-guidance to avoid a major amputation.
Doctor: That's a reasonable decision. How has the treatment been working for you?
Patient: So far, it seems to be helping. I'm just hoping I can avoid the amputation.
Doctor: It's important to follow up with your oncologist and radiation oncologist regularly to monitor your progress. Please keep me updated on your condition, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and advice.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, previously

Objective.Observations: The patient underwent initial enucleation of a thigh lesion, followed by chemotherapy (Ifosfamide and Epirubicin), preoperative radiotherapy, and radical surgery. Despite initial stability, local relapses occurred, treated with limb-sparing surgeries and a femoro-popliteal bypass. Distant progression involved pulmonary metastases, treated with high-dose chemotherapy and microwave ablation. Recent MRI and ultrasound confirmed new local relapses at the calf and soleus muscle.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is recurrent sarcoma with both local and distant metastases. The patient's history of multiple recurrences and treatments complicates the prognosis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of soft tissue sarcoma or metastatic disease from another primary cancer, though clinical history supports recurrent sarcoma.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring the efficacy of PLA treatment and assess for potential complications. Regular follow-ups with the oncology team are crucial to evaluate disease progression and treatment response. Discuss pain management and psychological support as needed. Educate the patient on signs of disease progression or complications related to current treatments. Encourage adherence to scheduled follow-ups and open communication with the healthcare team.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you're here today because your 12-month-old son has been referred to us due to an unsymmetrical bilateral cleft lip and palate, causing a protruding premaxilla. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Alright, let me explain what we did to treat this condition. We removed a minimal amount of bone, about 3 mm, from the vomer which is located posterior to the vomeroperpendicular suture (VPS). This helped to align the premaxilla.
Patient: Okay, I see.
Doctor: We made sure to preserve the septo-premaxillary ligament, which is located anterior to the VPS. This is important for the proper positioning of the premaxilla.
Patient: Hmm, I understand.
Doctor: After that, we repositioned the premaxilla and stabilized it using interosseous suturing with a material called 2-0 polyglactin 910 (Vicryl®, Ethicon Inc., USA).
Patient: So, the suturing will keep it in place?
Doctor: Yes, exactly. After stabilizing the premaxilla, we performed a muscular repair of the orbicularis muscle.
Patient: And what about his nose?
Doctor: We also performed a limited rhinoplasty to improve the appearance of his nose. This was done through a reverse U-shaped incision.
Patient: Oh, that's good to know.
Doctor: Postoperatively, you should notice that his columella, which is the tissue between his nostrils, has been elongated, and the nasolabial structures have been normalized. You can see the improvement in this figure (Fig. ).
Patient: Wow, it looks much better!
Doctor: I'm glad you're pleased with the results. It's important to keep an eye on your son's healing process and to follow up with us if you have any concerns or questions.
Patient: Definitely, I'll make sure to do that. Thank you so much for your help, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. We're here to help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's right
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient's mother reports that her 12-month-old son was referred for treatment of an unsymmetrical bilateral cleft lip and palate with a protruding premaxilla.

Objective.Observations: Surgical intervention involved the removal of approximately 3 mm of bone from the vomer, located posterior to the vomeroperpendicular suture (VPS), to align the premaxilla. The septo-premaxillary ligament, anterior to the VPS, was preserved to maintain proper positioning of the premaxilla. The premaxilla was then repositioned and stabilized using interosseous suturing with 2-0 polyglactin 910 (Vicryl®, Ethicon Inc., USA). A muscular repair of the orbicularis muscle and a limited rhinoplasty through a reverse U-shaped incision were also performed to improve nasal appearance.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is an unsymmetrical bilateral cleft lip and palate with a protruding premaxilla. The surgical procedures performed aimed to correct these deformities and improve facial symmetry and function. The prognosis is generally positive with proper healing and

Plan.Treatment: Postoperative care includes monitoring the healing process and ensuring proper follow-up visits to assess the surgical outcome and address any complications. The patient's mother is advised to keep an eye on her son's recovery and contact the healthcare provider if any concerns or questions arise. Further consultations with pediatric specialists and continued surgical follow-ups are planned to ensure optimal recovery and development.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're here for a follow-up appointment regarding chronic back pain control. How have you been managing your pain with methadone?
Patient: It's been helping a bit, but I've been struggling with some other issues lately.
Doctor: I see. What kind of issues have you been experiencing?
Patient: I've been having trouble breathing and needed more oxygen in the past few months. It's been getting worse.
Doctor: That's concerning. Let's perform an EKG to monitor your QTc and see if there's any issue with your heart. *After performing the EKG* It looks like you have a new-onset atrial bigeminy. We'll need to send you to the emergency department for further evaluation.
Patient: Oh, alright. What's going to happen there?
Doctor: They'll do telemetry and another EKG to see if the arrhythmia has resolved. Based on your complaints of worsening dyspnea, they may also perform a CT-angiogram of your pulmonary arteries to rule out any pulmonary embolism.
*At the emergency department*
Doctor: Your telemetry and EKG showed resolution of the arrhythmia, which is good news. The CT-angiogram, however, revealed a partial anomalous pulmonary venous connection (PAPVC) involving the pulmonary vein in your left upper lobe and lingula, returning blood to your right atrium through the left brachiocephalic vein. We also performed an echocardiogram, which ruled out an atrial septal defect but showed a mildly dilated right ventricle, mild tricuspid valve regurgitation, and normal left ventricular function.
Patient: Oh, that sounds complicated. Is it related to my other health issues?
Doctor: It could be. You have morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, and a history of acute lymphocytic leukemia with a bone marrow transplant and graft-versus-host disease. These conditions have caused severe restrictive lung disease, with reduced lung capacity and function. Your total lung capacity is at 42%, FEV1 at 39%, FVC at 37%, and DLCO at 41% of predicted values. You're also using two liters of oxygen supplementation at home and have a functional capacity of four metabolic equivalents (METS).
Patient: That's not good. What's the next step?
Doctor: We performed a right and left heart catheterization to evaluate the shunt. The results revealed pulmonary hypertension with a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 52 mmHg, diastolic pressure of 43 mmHg, mean pressure of 40 mmHg, pulmonary vascular resistance of 1.7 Wood Units, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 25 mmHg, and cardiac output (Fick) of 7.47 L/min. The shunt-index, or pulmonary to systemic flow ratio (Qp/Qs), is 1.22:1.
Patient: What does all of that mean for me?
Doctor: It means we need to closely monitor your condition and consider further treatment options. We'll discuss this in more detail during your follow-up appointment. In the meantime, continue using your oxygen supplementation and managing your chronic back pain with methadone. Reach out to us if you experience any worsening symptoms or have any concerns.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll keep an eye on my symptoms and reach out if needed.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: It's been helping a bit, but I've been struggling with some other issues lately
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports chronic back pain, managed partially with methadone, and worsening dyspnea requiring increased oxygen supplementation. The patient has a history of morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, acute lymphocytic leukemia with bone marrow transplant and graft-versus-host disease, leading to severe restrictive lung disease.

Objective.Observations: Vital signs were not specified. EKG revealed new-onset atrial bigeminy, which resolved. CT-angiogram showed partial anomalous pulmonary venous connection (PAPVC) involving the pulmonary vein in the left upper lobe and lingula. Echocardiogram indicated mildly dilated right ventricle, mild tricuspid valve regurgitation, and normal left ventricular function. Pulmonary function tests showed total lung capacity at 42%, FEV1 at 39%, FVC at 37%, and DLCO at 41% of predicted values. Right and left heart catheterization revealed pulmonary hypertension with elevated pressures and a pulmonary to systemic flow ratio (Qp/Qs) of 1.22:1.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is partial anomalous pulmonary venous connection (PAPVC) with secondary complications of pulmonary hypertension and chronic respiratory failure due to severe restrictive lung disease. Differential diagnosis initially included pulmonary embolism, which was ruled out by CT-angiogram.

Plan.Treatment: Continue oxygen supplementation and methadone for chronic back pain management. Close monitoring of respiratory and cardiac status is necessary, with follow-up appointments to discuss further treatment options. Patient education on symptom monitoring and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial. Referral to a pulmonologist and a cardiologist for specialized care and management of PAPVC and pulmonary hypertension is recommended.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've been referred by your general practitioner to our Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery. You have presented with a 4-week history of suspicious upper lip swelling, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. It suddenly became large and quite painful.
Doctor: Okay. I understand that you have been defensive when questioned about any possible trauma or precipitating factors for this swelling. Are you aware of any events that may have caused this issue?
Patient: Well, I don't remember any specific trauma or anything like that.
Doctor: Alright. It's good to know you're medically fit and healthy, with no risk factors for oral cancer such as smoking or alcohol consumption. Let me conduct an examination to better understand your condition.
Patient: Sure, go ahead.
Doctor: Upon examination, I can see that your upper lip is disproportionately enlarged and there's an incompetent lip seal. There's also a 2 cm × 1 cm firm, erythematous swelling in the upper right lip. The lesion is not encroaching on the midline, and there's no associated cranial nerve deficit or lymphadenopathy. At the vermillion border, there's a puncture wound on a background of traumatised tissue adjacent to the firm swelling. Is the lesion painful when I touch it?
Patient: Yes, it is painful on palpation.
Doctor: I also noticed that there's no suppuration, induration, or ulceration on the lesion. Your dental health appears to be unremarkable, and there are no signs of systemic infection. I have reviewed your electronic health care record and found that you attended the Accident and Emergency Department at Homerton University Hospital four weeks prior. The main complaint was the swelling of the upper lip following self-injection of a dermal filler. Is this accurate?
Patient: Yes, I did purchase a dermal filler over the internet and injected it myself. I'm uncertain of the website's name, though.
Doctor: Thank you for being forthcoming about the true mode of injury. It's important for us to know the cause in order to provide the best care. Now that we have a better understanding of your situation, we can discuss the appropriate treatment options and follow-up requirements.
Patient: Okay, what should I do next?
Doctor: I will consult with my team and come up with a treatment plan to address your upper lip swelling. In the meantime, please avoid any further self-injections or similar actions. We will schedule a follow-up appointment to monitor your progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's right
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, referred by a general practitioner to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial

Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals a disproportionately enlarged upper lip with an incompetent lip seal. There is a firm, erythematous 2 cm × 1 cm swelling on the upper right lip, not crossing the midline, with a puncture wound at the vermillion border on a background of traumatised tissue adjacent to the firm swelling. The lesion is painful on palpation but shows no signs of suppuration, induration, or ulceration. There are no signs of cranial nerve deficits, lymphadenopathy, or systemic infection. Dental health is unremarkable. Review of electronic health records confirms a visit to the emergency department for upper lip swelling following self-injection of a dermal filler.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is localized swelling and inflammation of the upper lip due to self-administration of a dermal filler, with a differential diagnosis of infection or allergic reaction to the filler material. The absence of systemic signs and specific symptoms such as suppuration and ulceration reduces the likelihood of a severe infectious process.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan will include consultation with the oral and maxillofacial team to develop a specific treatment strategy, likely focusing on conservative management initially, such as observation and possibly pharmacological intervention to reduce inflammation. The patient is advised against further self-injections and similar procedures. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor the lesion's progression and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education regarding the risks of self-administered dermal fillers and the importance of professional administration will be provided.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've brought your two-year-old boy to the emergency department with respiratory distress but no fever. Can you tell me a little more about his medical history?
Parent: Sure, doctor. He doesn't have a pathological perinatal history, nor any personal or family history of atopy.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Has he had any choking episodes or swallowed a foreign body that you're aware of?
Parent: No, we haven't witnessed any choking episodes, and he's never had any dysphagia.
Doctor: I see. How long has he been experiencing these symptoms?
Parent: Well, during the last month before his admission, he had repeated attacks of cough and wheezing, but no dysphagia or drooling.
Doctor: What treatments has he received so far?
Parent: He was given antibiotics and steroids for a month to treat suspected asthma, but his cough got progressively worse. The appearance of dyspnea is what motivated us to come for an emergency consultation.
Doctor: Let me share the results of the examination with you. Your child was conscious and without cyanosis. He had a temperature of 37.5°C, a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, an oxygen saturation of 93%, and no signs of dehydration or malnutrition. His pulmonary examination showed suprasternal recession, scattered snoring, and diffuse wheeze. The cardiovascular examination was normal, and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.
Doctor: We also conducted blood tests, which showed a normal complete blood count and a C-reactive protein of 14 mg/l. However, an anteroposterior chest X-ray revealed a foreign body in the upper region of the mediastinum.
Parent: Oh, no! What did you do about it?
Doctor: We extracted the foreign body through a hypopharyngoscopy under sedation. It turned out to be a clothing button from the upper thoracic esophagus. The mucosa around the button was irregular, but there was no obvious stricture or perforation.
Parent: That's a relief. What's the plan for his recovery?
Doctor: We maintained your son on intravenous fluids and corticosteroids to decrease the periesophageal inflammation. He was discharged at 24 hours, and there were no clinical signs indicative of a perforation. The following day, he was started on a clear liquid diet.
Parent: How has he been doing since then?
Doctor: Over the ensuing year, your child has been well and gaining weight satisfactorily. There have been no reports of subsequent hospital attendances related to this episode.
Parent: That's great to hear! Thank you so much for taking care of our son. We really appreciate it.
Doctor: You're welcome! If you have any concerns or questions in the future, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No chief complaint documented
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a two-year-old boy, presented to the emergency department with respiratory distress but no fever. The parent reported that the child had a month-long history of repeated attacks of cough and wheezing, worsening despite treatment with antibiotics and steroids for suspected asthma. There was no history of choking, dysphagia, drooling, atopy, or pathological perinatal issues.

Objective.Observations: On examination, the child was conscious, afebrile with a temperature of 37.5°C, tachycardic with a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and had an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination revealed suprasternal recession, scattered snoring, and diffuse wheeze, but no signs of dehydration, malnutrition, or cyanosis. Cardiovascular examination was normal. Laboratory tests showed a normal complete blood count and a C-reactive protein of 14 mg/l. An anteroposterior chest X-ray identified a foreign body in the upper mediastinum.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis was respiratory distress due to a foreign body (a clothing button) in the upper thoracic esophagus, which was initially misdiagnosed as asthma. The differential diagnosis included asthma and other causes of pediatric respiratory distress. The prognosis is good following the removal of the foreign body, with no signs of stricture or perforation and satisfactory recovery over the past year.

Plan.Treatment: The foreign body was removed via hypopharyngoscopy under sedation. Post-operatively, the patient was managed with intravenous fluids and corticosteroids to reduce periesophageal inflammation. He was discharged 24 hours post-procedure on a clear liquid diet and has shown no signs of complications or recurrence of symptoms. Follow-up care should include monitoring for any signs of esophageal damage or respiratory issues. Further education on preventing foreign body aspiration is recommended for the caregivers.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I was diagnosed with IPF about 5 years ago, and I've been undergoing oral nintedanib therapy with LTOT. Recently, I've been experiencing respiratory distress and worsening of my cough.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a physical examination to check your lungs. *listens to patient's lungs* I can hear bilateral fine crackles in your lungs, which could be a sign of something serious. We should perform a CT scan and some blood tests to get a better understanding of your condition.
Patient: Okay, doctor. Let's do those tests.
*After the tests*
Doctor: The CT scan showed new ground-glass opacity over a broad range of bilateral lung fields. This, along with your comparatively poor blood oxygen concentration, indicates that you have an acute exacerbation of your IPF, also known as AE-IPF. Your blood test also showed a high PT antibody titer of 104 EU/mL on day 13 of admission.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means we need to adjust your treatment plan. We'll increase your LTOT dosage to help manage your symptoms. Fortunately, you responded well to the clinical treatment, so you'll be able to be discharged to your home.
Patient: That's a relief. Is there anything else I should know or do?
Doctor: Yes, it's important to note that you didn't receive any pertussis vaccination since adolescence. Although you have a typical usual interstitial pneumonia pattern on high-resolution CT, we didn't find any signs of autoimmune disease through blood tests or physical findings. You mentioned having a chronic cough associated with your IPF, but you also reported uncontrolled cough deterioration and continuous cough beginning about 3 weeks before hospitalization.
Patient: That's correct.
Doctor: We weren't able to detect Bordetella pertussis from your sputum, and PCR analysis wasn't performed. However, no other infectious diseases or causative bacteria were found through sputum culture tests, serum markers, or urine antigen tests. Moreover, no heart failure was observed.
Patient: So, what's the plan moving forward?
Doctor: We're going to treat you with macrolides and broad-spectrum β-lactam antibiotics, along with high-dose corticosteroid therapy. This should help manage your condition, which is a recurrent acute exacerbation.
Patient: I see. Thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please follow the treatment plan and let me know if you notice any changes in your symptoms or have any concerns. Take care!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient,

Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed bilateral fine crackles in the lungs. CT scan showed new ground-glass opacity across a broad range of bilateral lung fields. Blood tests indicated a high PT antibody titer of 104 EU/mL on day 13 of admission. Blood oxygen concentration was comparatively poor. No signs of autoimmune disease, infectious diseases, causative bacteria, or heart failure were detected through additional tests.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is an acute exacerbation of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (AE-IPF). Differential diagnoses considered included pertussis and other infectious diseases, but these were ruled out through sputum culture and absence of specific findings. The patient's condition is complicated by uncontrolled cough and respiratory distress.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes increasing the dosage of LTOT and initiating treatment with macrolides, broad-spectrum β-lactam antibiotics, and high-dose corticosteroid therapy to manage the recurrent acute exacerbations. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and report any changes. Education on the importance of vaccination and compliance with the new treatment regimen was provided. The patient will be discharged to home care with these adjustments in his treatment plan.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you are a 23-year-old African American man with a history of bipolar disorder. Could you please tell me your current symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really out of it mentally, and I've been throwing up a lot.
Doctor: I see. You've been presented to the Comprehensive Psychiatric Emergency Program. We've followed emergency protocols and placed two large-bore (16 gauge) intravenous cannulas and started a standard saline infusion to treat your descending blood pressure. Your initial examination showed a Glasgow Coma Scale Score of 15, and a quick neurological exam revealed no deficits in your extremities.
Patient: Okay. So, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means your muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, and cranial nerve function appear normal. However, we couldn't assess your gait due to your fatigue and the emergency condition. We also have your clinical laboratory values at admission.
Patient: Alright. I'm currently taking VA, 1500 mg daily. I take 500 mg in the morning and 1000 mg in the evening.
Doctor: I see that you started taking VA four months prior after trials with other medications failed due to adverse effects, such as diarrhea caused by lithium. After starting VA, you were monitored via follow-up examinations in the clinic on a monthly basis. On your second-month visit, you reported concerns of weakness and fatigue. Laboratory tests revealed elevated ammonia and VA levels. At that time, you were diagnosed with VA-induced hyperammonemia.
Patient: Yeah, that's right. They stopped the VA treatment and started me on lactulose syrup and lamotrigine.
Doctor: We monitored you weekly after that. After your third weekly visit, you reported concerns of worsening manic symptoms and severe bullae and rashes on your chest. We stopped the lamotrigine, and the manic symptoms recurred, leading to reinstating the VA treatment with weekly follow-up monitoring.
Patient: So, what's the plan now?
Doctor: Your ammonia levels have been elevated on all follow-up visits. We've added a daily combination of lactulose syrup and levocarnitine to your treatment regimen during each weekly visit, but your ammonia levels continued to be high.
Patient: Oh, I see. What can we do about that?
Doctor: We will continue to closely monitor your ammonia levels and adjust your treatment as necessary. It's important to keep attending your weekly follow-up visits and report any changes in symptoms or concerns you may have.
Patient: Got it. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care, and I'll see you at your next follow-up visit.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been feeling really out of it mentally, and I've been throwing up a lot
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 23-year-old African American male with a history of bipolar disorder, currently experiencing mental disorientation and frequent vomiting. He reports a history of adverse reactions to various medications, including diarrhea with lithium, leading to a trial of Valproic Acid (VA) which was initiated four months ago. He has experienced VA-induced hyperammonemia, leading to discontinuation and subsequent trials with other medications including lactulose syrup and lamotrigine, which were also discontinued due to side effects and recurrence of manic symptoms.

Objective.Observations: On physical examination, the patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15 and normal findings in muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, and cranial nerve function. Neurological gait assessment was not possible due to patient fatigue and emergency condition. Two 16-gauge intravenous cannulas were placed, and a standard saline infusion was started to manage descending blood pressure. Laboratory tests have consistently shown elevated ammonia levels despite treatment adjustments.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is bipolar disorder with complications including VA-induced hyperammonemia and medication-related side effects. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vomiting and mental disorientation, but these are less likely given the patient's specific medication history and lab findings.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes continued monitoring of ammonia levels and adjustment of the treatment regimen as necessary. The patient is currently on a combination of lactulose syrup and levocarnitine. It is crucial for the patient to maintain weekly follow-up visits to monitor his condition and treatment efficacy. Education on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and prompt reporting of any new symptoms or concerns is essential.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to the Emergency Department of Chitwan Medical College with a history of weakness in both lower limbs for two days, preceded by muscle cramps of three days' duration. Can you tell me more about how this weakness started and progressed?
Patient: Yes, the weakness was insidious in onset and gradually got worse, affecting my upper limbs by the next day. I didn't have any altered sensorium, seizure, or bladder or bowel problems.
Doctor: I understand. Your past medical history shows that you've had positive results for repeated hospital admissions following episodes of weakness and fatigue associated with hypokalemia for the past three years. These episodes were managed as hypokalemic periodic paralysis and responded well to supplemental potassium alone. Have you had any similar problems recently?
Patient: Yes, I've had similar problems episodically for the past three years, which required repeated hospital admissions.
Doctor: In addition to that, you also mentioned a history of drooping of your bilateral eyelids, foreign body sensation in the eyes, dry mouth, and recurrent muscular weakness for the past three years. Have you experienced vomiting or taken any diuretics, alcohol, or laxatives recently?
Patient: No, I haven't had any vomiting or taken diuretics, alcohol, or laxatives.
Doctor: Your previous medical records revealed negative results for the antibody against acetylcholine receptor, ruling out myasthenia gravis. I've conducted a physical examination, and your vital signs are within normal limits. Your oral cavity was dry, but there was no lymphadenopathy. Motor power was 3/5 on the lower limbs and 4/5 on the upper limbs, affecting both proximal and distal group of muscles. Deep tendon reflexes were diminished bilaterally. There was no sensory deficit, and your cranial nerve examination was unremarkable. Cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and thyroid examination findings were also normal.
Patient: Okay, so what's the issue?
Doctor: We found that you have hypokalemia, with a documented serum K+ of 1.6 meq/L, which is below the normal range of 3.5-5.5 meq/L. Your ECG showed a sinus bradycardia with global T wave inversion and the presence of a subtle U wave.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: Hypokalemia means you have low levels of potassium in your blood, which can cause muscle weakness and affect your heart's electrical activity, as seen in your ECG results. We will start you on intravenous potassium supplementation at the rate of 20 meq/hour to address this issue.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me. I hope the treatment helps.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll closely monitor your progress, and I expect the potassium supplementation to improve your symptoms. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, the weakness was insidious in onset and gradually got worse, affecting my upper limbs by the next day
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 34-year-old male, presented with a chief complaint of progressive weakness in both lower limbs over two days, which then affected the upper limbs. The onset was insidious, and the weakness was preceded by muscle cramps lasting three days. The patient denied any altered sensorium, seizure, or bladder or bowel issues. He reported a history of similar episodes of weakness and fatigue associated with hypokalemia over the past three years, requiring hospital admissions. These episodes were previously diagnosed and managed as hypokalemic periodic paralysis. The patient also noted bilateral eyelid drooping, foreign body sensation in the eyes, and dry mouth but denied recent vomiting, diuretic, alcohol, or laxative use.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Vital signs are within normal limits
Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed motor power of 3/5 in the lower limbs and 4/5 in the upper limbs, affecting both proximal and distal muscle groups. Deep tendon reflexes were diminished bilaterally. No sensory deficits or cranial nerve abnormalities were noted. Vital signs were within normal limits, and cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and thyroid examinations were unremarkable. Laboratory results showed severe hypokalemia with a serum potassium level of 1.6 meq/L (normal range: 3.5-5.5 meq/L). ECG indicated sinus bradycardia with global T wave inversion and a subtle U wave.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is hypokalemic periodic paralysis, likely triggered by severe hypokalemia. Differential diagnoses previously considered, such as myasthenia gravis, have been ruled out through negative antibody testing. The patient's recurrent symptoms and severe hypokalemia pose risks for cardiac arrhythmias and further muscular weakness.

Plan.Treatment: Immediate management includes intravenous potassium supplementation at 20 meq/hour to correct the hypokalemia. Continuous cardiac monitoring will be implemented due to the ECG changes and risk of arrhythmias. The patient will be educated on the importance of monitoring for symptoms of weakness or cardiac disturbances. Follow-up will include reassessment of potassium levels and motor function after initial treatment. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of hypokalemic periodic paralysis is planned. The patient will also be advised on dietary potassium intake and potential triggers for hypokalemic episodes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I am here to report the case of a 47-year-old male patient from Mali, West Africa. Can you please tell me more about the symptoms you experienced?
Patient: Yeah, for the past three weeks, I've been having intermittent fever, chills, increased fatigue, decreased appetite, and diffuse back and abdominal pain. I also lost about 35 pounds in the last three months.
Doctor: I see. Do you have a history of any infections or illnesses?
Patient: I had a malarial infection six months ago, but it was treated. I've been traveling around Africa until I got sick recently.
Doctor: Thank you for the information.
