You signed the informed consent and started the administration of CBS eye drops in April 2016, with a posology of 0.4 ml (8 drops) in your right eye, each day for a total of two months. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I followed that treatment.
Doctor: And during the first and second month, you received the CBS dosages as determined for the two lots. Now, in September 2016, how would you describe your current discomfort in your right eye?
Patient: Well, I have noticed a significant relief from the subjective symptoms of discomfort in my right eye.
Doctor: That's great to hear! We'll continue to monitor your progress, and if you have any further issues or concerns, don't hesitate to contact us. Keep using the tear substitute as prescribed and let us know if anything changes.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I really appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I'm here for a follow-up
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient,

Objective.Physical_Exam: Didn't find any epithelial damage or signs of inflammation
Objective.Observations: The patient's symptoms were quantified with an Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI) of 74/100 and a Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain of 85 mm/100 in the right eye, indicating severe discomfort. The left eye presented milder symptoms with an OSDI of 22/100 and a VAS of 21 mm/100. Slit lamp examination showed no epithelial damage or signs of inflammation, but revealed a reduced Tear Film Break-Up Time (TFBUT) of 4 seconds in the right eye and 8 seconds in the left eye. The patient has been undergoing an unconventional therapy with topical cannabinoid-based solution (CBS) eye drops since April 2016, with a dosage of 0.4 ml daily in the right eye.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is POAG with severe ocular surface disease (OSD) predominantly affecting the right eye. The differential diagnosis could include other causes of ocular surface irritation, but the lack of epithelial damage or inflammation makes these less likely. The patient's response to CBS therapy suggests a positive outcome for symptom management in refractory cases of OSD.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the long-term efficacy and safety of the CBS therapy. Maintain the current regimen of the hyaluronic acid-based tear substitute four times daily in both eyes. Encourage the patient to report any changes in symptoms or side effects. Consider further adjustments to therapy based on symptom progression or regression. Ensure patient education on the importance of adherence to treatment and scheduled follow-up visits.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having chronic headaches for years, and they've been getting worse lately.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and when they started?
Patient: My symptoms started about twelve years ago as a mild headache that persisted through the day. Gradually, the headache worsened, and now I have severe headaches with vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. These episodes last for two to three days and then get resolved.
Doctor: That sounds quite distressing. Have you tried any medications to help with your headaches?
Patient: Yeah, I was treated with flunarizine for suspected basilar migraine, but it didn't help.
Doctor: I see. And have you noticed any other symptoms during these episodes, such as unsteadiness of gait or body numbness?
Patient: Yes, when I have these headaches, I also experience distressing vertigo, unsteadiness of gait, and right-sided body numbness.
Doctor: It's important to note that. Have you tried simple analgesia for the diffuse headache in between these episodes?
Patient: I have, but it doesn't seem to help.
Doctor: Do you ever experience fever, night sweats, or any constitutional symptoms during these episodes?
Patient: No fever or night sweats, but I've had constitutional symptoms that last for several months.
Doctor: I understand these symptoms must severely affect your daily activities and functionality. Now, have you ever had any neurological deficits in the past?
Patient: Yes, over the last 17 years, I've had repeated episodes of neurological deficits. I had visual impairment in my right eye and right lateral rectus palsy. I was treated for retrobulbar neuritis with methylprednisolone, and it helped.
Doctor: I see. Were there any other episodes?
Patient: One year later, I developed left-sided visual impairment, which also responded to methylprednisolone. I had an MRI at that time, but the imaging showed normal results.
Doctor: And any other neurological events after that?
Patient: A few months after that, I was admitted with right hemisensory loss and hemiplegia. They suspected a demyelination disease or hemiplegic migraine, but my second MRI during that admission didn't show any abnormalities.
Doctor: Were there any other instances?
Patient: Eight years ago, I developed a left lower motor type facial nerve palsy that was attributed to Bell's palsy.
Doctor: And have you been diagnosed with any other conditions?
Patient: Yes, within the last year, I was diagnosed with depression and anxiety and was treated for a few months.
Doctor: Thank you for providing all this information. It helps me understand your condition better. We may need to perform some further tests and evaluations to determine the best course of treatment for you.
Patient: I understand. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. In the meantime, try to get enough rest and maintain a healthy lifestyle. I will be in touch with you once we have a better understanding of your condition and the best treatment options.
Patient: Okay, I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been having chronic headaches for years, and they've been getting worse lately
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports chronic headaches that began approximately twelve years ago, initially mild but have progressively worsened to severe headaches accompanied by vertigo, nausea, vomiting, unsteadiness of gait, and right-sided body numbness. These episodes last 2-3 days. The patient has a history of neurological deficits including visual impairment, right lateral rectus palsy, and left lower motor type facial nerve palsy. Previous treatments include flunarizine for suspected basilar migraine and methylprednisolone for retrobulbar neuritis, both with limited success. The patient also reports depression and anxiety diagnosed within the last year.

Objective.Observations: The patient has undergone multiple MRIs which showed no abnormalities. Past medical interventions include treatment with methylprednisolone for visual impairments and suspected neurological conditions, which temporarily alleviated some symptoms. No fever, night sweats, or other systemic symptoms were reported.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary assessment is chronic severe headaches with neurological deficits, possibly indicative of a complex migraine disorder or an underlying demyelinating disease, despite previous normal MRI findings. Differential diagnoses could include chronic migraine with aura, basilar-type migraine, or a form of multiple sclerosis, considering the neurological deficits and response to steroids.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests including repeat MRI with contrast to look for any changes or abnormalities that might have developed. Referral to a neurologist for comprehensive evaluation and management is necessary. Continue monitoring the effectiveness of current migraine management strategies and adjust as needed. Psychological support and continued treatment for depression and anxiety are recommended to address mental health aspects. Educate the patient on lifestyle modifications that might help reduce headache frequency and severity.
Plan.Follow-Up: Once we have a better understanding of your condition and the best treatment options

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've been experiencing some unexplained weight loss and abdominal pain recently. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've lost over 10 kg in the past 6 months, and I've been having this nonspecific pain in my abdomen.
Doctor: I see. How about any other GI symptoms? Have you noticed any changes in your bowel habits or appetite?
Patient: No, I haven't noticed any other GI symptoms.
Doctor: Alright. Let's check your vital signs first. *After checking vital signs* Your vital signs are within normal limit, but I do notice that you look quite pale. I'm going to do a physical examination now.
*After examination*
Doctor: During the examination, I found a palpable fist-sized mass at your left upper quadrant. We'll need to do some laboratory tests and a CT scan to get a better understanding of what's going on.
Patient: Okay, that sounds concerning.
*After tests*
Doctor: Your laboratory tests show a hemoglobin level of 9 g/dL, while the rest of your blood tests came back unremarkable. The CT scan demonstrated a heterogeneously enhancing solid-cystic mass measuring 10 cm in maximal diameter at the pancreatic body and tail.
Patient: What does that mean, doc?
Doctor: Based on these findings, our provisional diagnosis is pancreatic mucinous cystadenoma, which is a type of tumor. The recommended treatment is a distal pancreatectomy, lymphadenectomy, and splenectomy.
Patient: Alright, if that's what needs to be done.
*After the operation*
Doctor: We've completed the operation. During the exploration, we made a Chevron incision and discovered that the tumor was actually originating from the proximal jejunum, not the pancreas. It was abutting the body and tail of the pancreas. We carefully dissected and removed the tumor without any spillage or rupture of the capsule.
Patient: What happens next?
Doctor: We completed the operation with an end-to-end jejunojejunostomy. There was an absence of adjacent mesenteric lymphadenopathy, which is a good sign.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: Upon examining the gross specimen, it measured 9x8x6.5 cm and was a soft, round-shaped, tan-grey colored mass with an irregular surface. There was large central necrosis and a cavity. The histologic examination showed interlacing bundles of spindle cells and nuclear atypia was presented. However, nuclear mitosis was scarcely found, which is a positive sign.
Patient: So, what does the immunohistochemical study show, doc?
Doctor: The immunohistochemical study will give us more information about the tumor cells and help us determine the best course of action for your follow-up care. We'll discuss the results once they become available. For now, focus on your recovery and we'll continue to monitor your progress closely.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've lost over 10 kg in the past 6 months, and I've been having this nonspecific pain in my abdomen
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Patient reports a significant unexplained weight loss of over 10 kg in the past 6 months and nonspecific abdominal pain. No changes in bowel habits or appetite were noted.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Interlacing bundles of spindle cells and nuclear atypia was presented
Objective.Observations: Vital signs are within normal limits; however, patient appears pale. Physical examination revealed a palpable fist-sized mass in the left upper quadrant. Laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 9 g/dL (normal range: 13.8-17.2 g/dL for men, 12.1-15.1 g/dL for women), with other blood tests unremarkable. CT scan identified a heterogeneously enhancing solid-cystic mass measuring 10 cm in maximal diameter at the pancreatic body and tail. Post-operative findings indicated the mass originated from the proximal jejunum, not the pancreas, and was successfully resected with an end-to-end jejunojejunostomy performed. Gross specimen measured 9x8x6.5 cm with central necrosis and cavity; histologic examination showed interlacing bundles of spindle cells with nuclear atypia and scarce nuclear mitosis.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Initial provisional diagnosis was pancreatic mucinous cystadenoma; however, surgical findings and histology revised the diagnosis to a likely benign spindle cell tumor of the proximal jejunum, pending further immunohistochemical studies. No evidence of lymphadenopathy suggests absence of metastasis.

Plan.Treatment: Completed distal pancreatectomy, lymphadenectomy, and splenectomy, followed by successful tumor resection and jejunojejunostomy. Patient to focus on recovery with close monitoring of post-operative progress. Await immunohistochemical study results to finalize diagnosis and determine further follow-up care. Educate patient on signs of complications and ensure compliance with follow-up appointments.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, what brings you to the emergency department today?
Mother: Hi, my son had an episode of hemoptysis just before we arrived here. He's been coughing up blood.
Doctor: I see. Has he been experiencing any other symptoms recently?
Mother: Yes, he's had cold-like symptoms for the past few days, and he vomited last night and this morning. He also had diarrhea during that time, but there was no blood in it.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. Has there been any change in his urine output?
Mother: No, his urine output has been normal.
Doctor: Did he have a fever recently?
Mother: Yes, he had a fever last night and this morning, with a maximum temperature of 101º F.
Doctor: Alright. Does he attend daycare or have any recent exposure to other sick children?
Mother: Yes, he goes to daycare, and many kids there have recently caught the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).
Doctor: Okay. Can you tell me a little about his birth and medical history?
Mother: He was born full term with no complications. Since we adopted him a few months after birth, he's had multiple bronchitis infections. He's up to date on all his vaccinations, but we don't know his family history.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let me check his vitals. His temperature is now 98.7º F, pulse rate is 131 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and blood pressure is 89/60. Upon physical exam, I can see the presence of clear rhinorrhea, and I hear diffuse crackles and expiratory wheezing in all lung quadrants.
Mother: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means there might be some respiratory issues. Let's run some tests to get a better understanding of the situation. We'll do a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, as well as chest radiographs in two views.
(After tests)
Doctor: The blood tests and metabolic panel are all within normal limits. The chest radiographs show no acute lung abnormalities or pulmonary infiltrates. We also performed a hemoccult test on the blood-tinged rag you brought, which confirmed the presence of blood.
Mother: So what's causing my son to cough up blood?
Doctor: It's not entirely clear, but it could be related to his recent respiratory symptoms and history of bronchitis infections. We'll continue to monitor him and provide any necessary treatment. In the meantime, make sure he gets plenty of rest and stays hydrated.
Mother: Okay, thank you, Doctor. We'll follow your advice.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No chief complaint documented
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a young child, presented with hemoptysis, cold-like symptoms, vomiting, diarrhea, and a recent fever peaking at 101º F. The mother reports the child attends daycare where there is a current outbreak of RSV. The child has a history of multiple bronchitis infections and is adopted with an unknown family medical history.

Objective.Observations: Current vital signs include a temperature of 98.7º F, pulse rate of 131 bpm, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 89/60 mmHg. Physical examination revealed clear rhinorrhea, diffuse crackles, and expiratory wheezing across all lung quadrants. Laboratory tests including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits. Chest radiographs show no acute lung abnormalities or pulmonary infiltrates. Hemoccult test confirmed the presence of blood.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary assessment is hemoptysis likely related to an acute respiratory infection, considering the patient's symptoms and environmental exposure to RSV. Differential diagnoses include bronchitis and other respiratory infections. The absence of acute findings on chest radiographs and normal lab results suggest no severe underlying pathology at this time.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to monitor the patient closely in the emergency department for any progression of symptoms. Administer supportive care including hydration and rest. Educate the mother on signs of respiratory distress and when to seek further medical attention. Schedule a follow-up appointment with a pediatrician within 48 hours to reassess the patient's condition. Consider referral to a pediatric pulmonologist if symptoms persist or worsen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello MF, I understand you were referred to our tertiary centre after having two endoscopic endonasal sinus operations in the past 18 months. How have you been feeling since those procedures?
Patient: Well, I still have this chronic rhinosinusitis and a left frontal mucocoele. It's been quite bothersome.
Doctor: I see. Your medical history also indicates that you've had significant ptosis and underwent some ophthalmological intervention. How has that been holding up?
Patient: Hmm, not so great actually. The ptosis is still quite noticeable.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. At presentation, you mentioned that you're suffering from recurrent sinonasal disease. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I've been having this constant left-sided headache and a left fronto-orbital fistula discharge over my medial canthus. It's quite uncomfortable.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We performed a computer tomography of your orbit, sinuses, and skull base to get a better understanding of your condition. The results showed a small A-P diameter of your frontal sinus and extensive neo-osteogenesis from chronic frontal sinusitis. 
Patient: Oh, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the inside of your frontal sinus is quite small and there's new bone formation due to the chronic inflammation. Unfortunately, an endonasal endoscopic approach to address this issue would likely be ineffective in your case.
Patient: So, what can be done about this?
Doctor: Our multidisciplinary team had a discussion about your situation and came up with an option to perform Riedel's procedure, along with concurrent excision of the fronto-orbital fistula, under the same anaesthetic. This should help alleviate your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, and what exactly is Riedel's procedure?
Doctor: Riedel's procedure is a surgical intervention that aims to remove the frontal sinus and recreate a healthy environment in your sinuses. By doing this, we hope to address the root cause of your chronic frontal sinusitis and left-sided headaches.
Patient: I see. And the excision of the fronto-orbital fistula, what's that for?
Doctor: The excision of the fronto-orbital fistula will help remove the abnormal connection between your frontal sinus and the orbit, which is causing the discharge over your medial canthus. This should improve your overall comfort and quality of life.
Patient: Alright, sounds like a reasonable plan. How soon can we proceed with this?
Doctor: We will schedule the procedure as soon as possible. Our team will provide you with all the necessary information and instructions for your preparation and post-operative care.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate the help and hope this will finally bring me some relief.
Doctor: You're welcome, MF. We'll do our best to ensure a successful outcome and help you on your path to recovery.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Well, I still have this chronic rhinosinusitis and a left frontal mucocoele
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, MF, reports persistent symptoms of chronic rhinosinusitis and a bothersome left frontal mucocoele despite two previous endoscopic endonasal sinus surgeries within the last 18 months. MF also mentions ongoing significant ptosis post-ophthalmological intervention and recurrent left-sided headaches associated with a left fronto-orbital fistula discharge over the medial canthus.

Objective.Observations: Recent imaging via computer tomography of the orbit, sinuses, and skull base revealed a small anteroposterior diameter of the frontal sinus and extensive neo-osteogenesis secondary to chronic frontal sinusitis. These findings suggest that a standard endonasal endoscopic approach may be ineffective.

Assessment.Diagnosis: MF is diagnosed with chronic frontal sinusitis complicated by neo-osteogenesis and a left fronto-orbital fistula. The ptosis remains a significant concern, likely related to the recurrent sinonasal disease and previous surgeries. The primary diagnosis is chronic frontal sinusitis with associated complications.

Plan.Treatment: The proposed management plan includes surgical intervention via Riedel's procedure to remove the frontal sinus and concurrent excision of the fronto-orbital fistula under the same anaesthetic. This approach aims to address the root causes of MF's symptoms and improve overall quality of life. Pre-operative and post-operative care instructions will be provided, and the surgery will be scheduled as soon as possible. Follow-up appointments will be necessary to monitor recovery and manage any complications.
Plan.Follow-Up: We will schedule the procedure as soon as possible

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having migraines lately, and I'm not sure what's causing them.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent accidents or injuries?
Patient: Yeah, I was in a road traffic accident and suffered a craniocerebral injury. I even had a tracheostomy.
Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: I've had rheumatoid arthritis for 3 years now, and I'm taking methotrexate at 2.5 mg three times per day. I also take topiramate for my migraines, 200 mg twice a day.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Now, let's do a clinical examination of your thyroid gland. *Examines patient* Your thyroid gland is not palpable and seems painless. I would recommend some laboratory tests to investigate further.
Patient: Sure, doc. What do these tests involve?
Doctor: We'll be checking for rheumatoid factor, antithyroglobulin, and thyroid peroxidase antibodies, among other things. *After tests* The results are in, and they confirm a positive rheumatoid factor with normal antithyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase antibodies at 16 U/ml and 16.7 U/ml, respectively.
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: It suggests that there might be an issue with your thyroid, so I would recommend an ultrasound-guided needle aspiration biopsy to get a clearer picture.
Patient: Okay, I had that done at a private clinic, and they found distinct nodules in the lower pole of my left thyroid lobe. The report said it's suggestive but not conclusive of malignancy.
Doctor: In that case, we'll start you on thyroxine (T4) treatment to manage your hypothyroidism. Once you become euthyroid with a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 0.89 μIU/ml, triiodothyronine (T3) level of 1.30 ng/mL, and T4 level of 7.2 μg/dl, we'll proceed with a total thyroidectomy at our hospital.
Patient: Alright. What can you tell me about the thyroidectomy?
Doctor: After the thyroidectomy, we'll examine the resected thyroid specimen. In your case, it was received in three pieces with multiple adhesions, and its total weight was 36 g. Two of the specimens showed small irregular follicles separated by reticular connective tissue, while the third specimen had five small areas of amorphous necrotic tissue.
Patient: And what does the microscopic examination reveal?
Doctor: The necrotizing lesions, 0.2 to 0.4 cm in diameter, corresponded to rheumatoid nodules. These are composed of a central area of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading. This gives us more information about the condition of your thyroid and helps us determine the best course of action moving forward.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been having migraines lately, and I'm not sure what's causing them
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports experiencing migraines, which began following a road traffic accident resulting in a craniocerebral injury and a tracheostomy. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis for 3 years, managed with methotrexate (2.5 mg three times per day) and topiramate (200 mg twice a day) for migraines.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Small irregular follicles separated by reticular connective tissue
Objective.Observations: Clinical examination revealed an impalpable and painless thyroid gland. Laboratory tests showed a positive rheumatoid factor, with normal antithyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase antibodies (16 U/ml and 16.7 U/ml, respectively). Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid detected nodules in the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, suggestive of malignancy. Thyroid function tests indicated euthyroid status with TSH at 0.89 μIU/ml, T3 at 1.30 ng/mL, and T4 at 7.2 μg/dl. Post-thyroidectomy examination showed necrotizing lesions corresponding to rheumatoid nodules.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis of hypothyroidism secondary to rheumatoid involvement of the thyroid gland, with a differential diagnosis of thyroid malignancy suggested but not confirmed. The presence of rheumatoid nodules in the thyroid gland complicates the clinical picture.

Plan.Treatment: Initiate thyroxine treatment to manage hypothyroidism and maintain euthyroid status. Monitor thyroid function regularly. Proceed with total thyroidectomy to further evaluate and manage potential malignancy. Post-surgery, continue close monitoring and management of rheumatoid arthritis, adjusting medications as necessary to control systemic inflammation and prevent further autoimmune complications. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and regular follow-up for thyroid function tests and rheumatologic assessment.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello. You mentioned that you recently presented to our hospital with dyspnea. Can you tell me if you have experienced any other symptoms recently?
Patient: Yes, I developed general fatigue about 5 years ago and numbness on the right side of my body 3 years ago.
Doctor: I see. Have you received any diagnosis or treatment for these symptoms?
Patient: I went to an orthopedic surgeon and was diagnosed with OPLL of the cervical spine. But the neuropathy has been getting worse, and I even have trouble walking now.
Doctor: That sounds quite concerning. Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath?
Patient: Yes, I developed dyspnea on exertion about a year ago.
Doctor: And have you noticed any changes in your body weight?
Patient: My body weight has fallen from 46 to 41 kg over the past 5 years.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. I understand that you've had a spirometry test performed by a local physician, which revealed restrictive ventilation impairment. We'd like to conduct a more comprehensive evaluation to understand your condition better.
Patient: Okay, that sounds good.
Doctor: Do you have any notable medical, family, or social history?
Patient: No, nothing of note. I've never smoked either.
Doctor: Great, thank you. Let's review your vital signs. Your body temperature is 36.2°C, pulse rate is 71 beats/min with a regular rhythm, and blood pressure is 103/56 mm Hg. Our physical examination revealed decreased thoracic motion, muscle weakness of the right upper limb, numbness of the extremities, and claudication. No rales were audible, although breath sounds were decreased in both lungs.
Patient: Hmm, what does all of that mean?
Doctor: It means we need to investigate further to identify the cause. We've assessed your Japanese Orthopaedic Association Score (JOA score), which grades the status of patients suffering from cervical myelopathy. Your score is 14 points, indicating mild cervical myelopathy with no need for surgery at this time.
Patient: Alright, so what's next?
Doctor: We've conducted a Chest X-ray and chest computed tomography (CT) to examine your lungs. Thankfully, there were no abnormal shadows in either lung field. However, the movement of your diaphragm was decreased when comparing the inspiratory X-ray with the expiratory image.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means there could be some respiratory issues contributing to your symptoms. Additionally, we found that the ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL) of your cervical spine runs longitudinally across the vertebral body. Sagittal T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a thickened posterior longitudinal ligament that is severely compressing your cervical cord at C3/4. Your spinal cord MRI also showed atrophic change and an intramedullary lesion.
Patient: So, what can be done for my condition?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we'll need to discuss the best course of action for managing your symptoms and preventing further complications. We'll work together to create a personalized treatment plan that addresses your specific needs.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, I developed general fatigue about 5 years ago and numbness on the right side of my body 3 years ago
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a history of general fatigue for 5 years, numbness on the right side of the body for 3 years, and dyspnea on exertion for 1 year. The patient has experienced a weight loss from 46 to 41 kg over the past 5 years. Previously

Objective.Observations: Vital signs include a body temperature of 36.2°C, pulse rate of 71 beats/min, and blood pressure of 103/56 mm Hg. Physical examination revealed decreased thoracic motion, muscle weakness of the right upper limb, numbness of the extremities, and claudication. No rales, but decreased breath sounds in both lungs. Spirometry indicated restrictive ventilation impairment. Japanese Orthopaedic Association Score (JOA score) is 14, suggesting mild cervical myelopathy. Chest X-ray and CT showed no abnormal shadows but decreased diaphragmatic movement. MRI of the cervical spine revealed severe compression of the cervical cord at C3/4 due to thickened posterior longitudinal ligament, with atrophic changes and an intramedullary lesion in the spinal cord.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is cervical myelopathy secondary to OPLL with associated respiratory impairment and possible early neuromuscular disorder due to spinal cord compression. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neuropathy and myelopathy. The prognosis depends on the progression of the spinal cord compression and respiratory involvement.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to manage the patient includes referral to a neurologist for further evaluation of neuropathy and myelopathy. Consultation with a pulmonologist for the management of restrictive lung disease is also recommended. Physical therapy to address muscle weakness and maintain mobility. Regular follow-up to monitor the progression of spinal cord compression and respiratory status. Discuss potential surgical options if neurological or respiratory symptoms worsen. Educate the patient on symptom management and the importance of regular medical reviews. Ensure patient understands the treatment plan and encourage compliance with follow-up appointments and therapy sessions.
Plan.Follow-Up: We need to investigate further to identify the cause

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have a family history of colon cancer, with your paternal grandfather and uncle being affected. What brought you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing generalized abdominal pain for about a week now, along with nausea, unintentional weight loss of four pounds, and shortness of breath.
Doctor: I see. We've done some initial blood work and it showed elevated liver enzymes and elevated total and direct bilirubin. We also performed a fecal occult blood test, which came back positive. To further investigate, we did a computed tomography (CT) scan of your abdomen and pelvis with contrast. It demonstrated ascites, retroperitoneal and periportal lymphadenopathy, and hepatomegaly with extensive confluent masses in the liver parenchyma, indicating extensive metastatic disease.
Patient: Oh wow, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: The scan also showed dilated loops of small bowel, a distended transverse colon, and a collapsed distal colon. We found that your tumor marker, CA 19-9, was elevated as well. We performed a core needle biopsy of your liver, and it exhibited poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The immunohistochemical staining was positive for CDX2 and CK20, while being negative for PAX-8, CK7, p40, and TTF-1. This indicates that the lower gastrointestinal tract is the primary site of origin for this metastasis.
Patient: So, what does that mean for me?
Doctor: We performed a colonoscopy, which showed a large 5 x 6 cm fungating and friable obstructing mass in your cecum, 90 cm from the anal verge. Biopsies were taken, and the results showed intramuscular adenocarcinoma in a background of tubulovillous adenocarcinoma. We performed a right hemicolectomy with ileostomy, and the resected specimen showed a 4.7 cm high-grade (poorly differentiated) adenocarcinoma involving the cecum and appendiceal orifice, perforating the parietal peritoneum.
Patient: What does that mean for my staging?
Doctor: The pathological staging of your tumor is pT4a, N1b, M1a according to the AJCC 7th edition. Immunohistochemistry showed a low probability of microsatellite instability (MSI).
Patient: Is there anything else I should know?
Doctor: Surprisingly, the surgical pathology report from the resected specimen also showed a distinct 1 cm well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor (NET) in the distal half of your appendix, invading the visceral peritoneum. It stained positively for pancytokeratin and synaptophysin.
Patient: Oh, that's unexpected. What does that mean for my treatment?
Doctor: We will discuss your case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of action for your treatment. This may involve chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or other targeted therapies. We will keep you informed and discuss your options thoroughly, so you can make the best decision for your care.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate all the information and your help in figuring out what's going on with me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will work together to ensure you receive the best care possible. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, with a family history of colon cancer, presents with generalized abdominal pain, nausea, unintentional weight loss of four pounds, and shortness of breath for approximately one week.

Objective.Observations: Vital signs were not specified. Blood work revealed elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. Fecal occult blood test was positive. CT scan showed ascites, retroperitoneal and periportal lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly with extensive liver masses suggestive of metastatic disease, dilated small bowel loops, distended transverse colon, and collapsed distal colon. CA 19-9 was elevated. Core needle biopsy indicated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with immunohistochemical staining positive for CDX2 and CK20, negative for PAX-8, CK7, p40, and TTF-1. Colonoscopy revealed a large cecal mass, confirmed as adenocarcinoma on biopsy. Right hemicolectomy with ileostomy was performed; pathology confirmed pT4a, N1b, M1a adenocarcinoma and a separate well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor in the appendix.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma of the colon, stage pT4a, N1b, M1a, with a secondary diagnosis of neuroendocrine tumor of the appendix. Differential diagnoses could include other sources of intra-abdominal malignancy, but immunohistochemistry supports a colorectal origin.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to discuss the case in a multidisciplinary team meeting to determine an appropriate treatment strategy, likely involving chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or targeted therapies. Patient education regarding the diagnosis, staging, and treatment options will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor treatment response and manage any complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 29-year-old, non-lactating, and non-gravid woman, and I've come here with a complaint of a lump in my right breast. I also have a low-grade fever and some unilateral pain in my breast tissue.
Doctor: I see. Let's perform a general physical examination to assess the situation. Hmm, I can see a one-centimeter erythematous and tender mass in your right breast tissue. There is no nipple discharge, axillary lymphadenopathy, or external draining sinuses. I will have you evaluated by a primary care physician and call for a USG for the assessment of the affected breast.
(USG is performed)
Doctor: The USG demonstrated an ill-defined lesion with thin fluid streaks in the lower outer quadrant, suggesting an inflammatory lesion. We have also aspirated some cystic fluid from your breast for a bacterial culture test.
Patient: What did the culture test show?
Doctor: The culture showed no growth of any microorganisms after 48 hours. The cytology revealed predominantly neutrophils and degenerating cells in a hemorrhagic background, which suggested an acute suppurative inflammatory process of the affected breast.
Doctor: Based on the clinical features, imaging findings, and cytology reports, we have a presumptive diagnosis of acute mastitis with an underlying bacterial abscess. I will prescribe you a course of antibiotics and antipyretics for one week.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
(After one week)
Patient: Doctor, instead of improving, my condition has worsened over time.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. In this case, we will need to repeat the ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration and cytology (FNAC) to get more information.
(FNAC is performed)
Doctor: The sonomammogram of your right breast revealed an ill-demarcated hypoechoic irregular lesion involving the parenchyma in the outer lower and adjoining upper quadrants. The lesion measured 34.4 millimeters on a long axis with no fluid components.
Doctor: The repeated cytological examination also showed cellular clusters comprising histiocytes and epithelioid-like cells. Based on these findings, it seems that the ongoing clinical picture is more suggestive of tuberculosis of the breast.
Patient: Oh no, what do we do now?
Doctor: We will start a therapeutic trial of anti-tuberculosis therapy (ATT) for you. It's important to follow the prescribed treatment plan closely to ensure the best possible outcome.
Patient: Alright, thank you for your help, Doctor. I will follow the therapy as prescribed.
Doctor: You're welcome. Make sure to keep in touch and update me on your progress. If you have any concerns, don't hesitate to reach out.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I'm a 29-year-old, non-lactating, and non-gravid woman, and I've come here with a complaint of a lump in my right breast
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 29-year-old, non-lactating, non-gravid woman presenting with a chief complaint of a lump in her right breast, accompanied by low-grade fever and unilateral pain in the breast tissue.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Cellular clusters comprising histiocytes and epithelioid-like cells
Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed a 1 cm erythematous, tender mass in the right breast, with no nipple discharge, axillary lymphadenopathy, or external draining sinuses. Initial ultrasound (USG) showed an ill-defined lesion with thin fluid streaks in the lower outer quadrant of the right breast. Aspiration cytology indicated an acute suppurative inflammatory process, with no microbial growth from the culture. Follow-up USG and fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) demonstrated an ill-demarcated hypoechoic irregular lesion measuring 34.4 mm, with cytology showing histiocytes and epithelioid-like cells, suggesting tuberculosis of the breast.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Initial diagnosis of acute mastitis with underlying bacterial abscess was reconsidered following worsening symptoms and further diagnostic evaluation, leading to a revised diagnosis of tuberculosis of the breast.

Plan.Treatment: Initiated a therapeutic trial of anti-tuberculosis therapy (ATT). The patient was advised to adhere strictly to the treatment regimen and to keep regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and address any concerns.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were admitted to the emergency department in December 2017 with a sudden-onset tonic-clonic seizure and status epilepticus. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, it was really frightening. I suddenly had a seizure and I couldn't control my body.
Doctor: I understand that must have been scary. Looking at your history, you were diagnosed with left maxillary sinus DLBL in July 2009, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: When you were admitted in 2017, you were intubated and admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for the management of status epilepticus. We also conducted a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain with contrast. It revealed a dominant left frontal mass approximately 3.8 cm in diameter with an adjacent rim of vasogenic edema. The signal characteristics, restricted diffusion, and the pattern of enhancement raised questions about lymphoma, metastasis, or less likely intermediate-grade primary brain tumor, given the multifocal disease.
Patient: Oh, I didn't know all that.
Doctor: Let's go back to when you were first diagnosed in 2009. You had left facial swelling, erythema, and pressure sensation for about seven weeks, right?
Patient: Yes, my face was swollen and red, and it felt like there was a lot of pressure.
Doctor: To diagnose your condition, we performed an 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) scan. It demonstrated a 2.3 x 1.4 cm focus anterior to the left maxilla. An oral surgery biopsy was done, and the definitive pathology diagnosis was DLBL with positive immunohistochemical stain for CD20, BCL2, LCA, and CD45RB. Your bone marrow biopsy was negative. You were staged as stage IIA with a CNS international prognostic index (CNS-IPI) score of four, which placed you in the high-risk group.
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: You underwent three cycles of chemotherapy with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CHOP) regimen and 36 Gy involved-field radiation therapy. The post-chemo/radiotherapy PET/CT scan showed decreased size and activity of the subcutaneous soft tissue mass anterior to the left maxilla with a residual mass of 2.4 x 0.6 cm. This mass resolved on further follow-up.
Patient: Yes, I was relieved when that mass went away.
Doctor: When the recent 2017 frontal lobe mass was discovered, we performed a biopsy with frameless CT-guided navigation. It confirmed DLBL with positive immunohistochemical stain for CD10, CD20, BCL2, and MUM1. Over 80% of the cells stained for Ki-.
Patient: So what does that mean for me now?
Doctor: It means that we need to continue monitoring your condition and follow up with appropriate treatment as needed. It's important to stay in close communication with your healthcare team and report any changes in your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, it was really frightening
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reported a sudden-onset tonic-clonic seizure in December 2017, which was described as frightening and uncontrollable. The patient has a history of left maxillary sinus diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBL) diagnosed in July 2009, presenting initially with left facial swelling, erythema, and pressure sensation. The patient underwent treatment including chemotherapy and radiation, with a noted resolution of the mass.

Objective.Observations: In 2017, the patient was intubated and admitted to the MICU for status epilepticus management. MRI of the brain with contrast revealed a left frontal mass approximately 3.8 cm in diameter with adjacent vasogenic edema, suggestive of lymphoma, metastasis, or a primary brain tumor. A frameless CT-guided biopsy of the mass confirmed recurrence of DLBL. Initial staging in 2009 was IIA with a CNS-IPI score of four, indicating high risk. Treatment included R-CHOP chemotherapy and 36 Gy radiation, with post-treatment scans showing decreased mass size.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is recurrent DLBL, manifesting as a left frontal brain mass associated with seizure activity. Differential diagnoses considered were metastasis or a primary brain tumor. The prognosis is guarded given the recurrence and the high-risk nature of the initial presentation.

Plan.Treatment: The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments and imaging studies to assess the status of the disease. The patient will be managed with a multidisciplinary approach involving oncology, neurology, and potentially radiation oncology for further treatment options. Education regarding symptom management and when to seek immediate care will be provided. The importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up schedule will be emphasized to the patient.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're an 81-year-old female who presented to our tertiary referral centre with non-specific epigastric pain of increasing severity and frequency. Your comorbidities are limited to hypertension. Can you tell me more about your pain?
Patient: Yes, doctor. The pain has been getting worse and more frequent, and it's really bothering me.
Doctor: I understand. We performed a CT angiography and confirmed the presence of a 67-mm infrarenal AAA extending distally to the aortic bifurcation. The aneurysm sac doesn't contain any intraluminal thrombus. However, the neck of the aneurysm is extremely angulated, with the proximal landing zone measuring 16 mm in diameter. Your right common iliac artery is ectatic and measures 16 mm, while the left one appears normal. Both external iliac arteries are tortuous but within normal limits in diameter, measuring 7.8 and 7.6 mm on the right and left side, respectively.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also performed a stress echocardiogram, which showed good left ventricular function. Your pulmonary function is satisfactory with a forced vital capacity of 125% of predicted and a forced expiratory volume in 1 s/forced vital capacity ratio of 84%.
Patient: That's a relief, at least.
Doctor: Given your age and general condition, our assessment is that open surgery would carry a significant risk of morbidity and mortality. Therefore, we believe that EVAR is the preferred treatment modality. It's a minimally invasive surgery, and it aligns with your preference over open repair.
Patient: I see, so what's the plan?
Doctor: Unfortunately, the significantly narrowed aneurysm neck precludes the use of standard endografts, which have a minimum diameter of 23 mm. For you, this would entail 43% oversizing of the native aorta. To overcome the challenging anatomical morphology, we're considering a novel endovascular option of deploying a small diameter and short thoracic endograft into the proximal neck of the aneurysm, combined with telescopic deployment of a branched iliac device.
Patient: And is this option approved?
Doctor: Yes, we've gained consensus to proceed with this approach following discussion at our local multidisciplinary team meeting.
Patient: What will happen during the procedure?
Doctor: Intraoperatively, you'll be positioned supine, and we'll adequately prep you for surgery. Surgical access will be obtained via bilateral groin cut-downs. After the procedure, we'll closely monitor your recovery and provide any necessary follow-up care.
Patient: Thank you, doctor, for explaining everything. I'm ready to proceed with the treatment.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll schedule the surgery and keep you informed about the details. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or concerns.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: 81-year-old female presents with non-specific, worsening, and frequent epigastric pain. She has a history of hypertension. No other significant medical history reported.

Objective.Observations: CT angiography revealed a 67-mm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) extending to the aortic bifurcation without intraluminal thrombus. The aneurysm neck is angulated with a proximal landing zone diameter of 16 mm. Right common iliac artery is ectatic at 16 mm; left common iliac artery is normal. Both external iliac arteries are tortuous but within normal limits, measuring 7.8 mm on the right and 7.6 mm on the left. Stress echocardiogram shows good left ventricular function. Pulmonary function tests indicate a forced vital capacity of 125% of predicted and a forced expiratory volume in 1 s/forced vital capacity ratio of 84%.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is infrarenal AAA with a challenging anatomical morphology due to the angulated neck and narrow proximal landing zone. Differential diagnosis includes other causes of epigastric pain, but imaging and symptoms primarily support the AAA diagnosis. The patient's age and comorbidities increase the risk associated with open surgical repair.

Plan.Treatment: Proceed with endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) using a novel approach due to the narrow aneurysm neck. This involves deploying a small diameter and short thoracic endograft into the proximal neck, combined with telescopic deployment of a branched iliac device. The procedure will be performed under general anesthesia with bilateral groin cut-downs. Postoperative care will include close monitoring and follow-up. The patient has been informed about the procedure details and has consented to proceed with the recommended treatment plan. Surgery scheduling and further preoperative preparations will be coordinated.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you've been referred to our department for treatment of a right kidney tumor and IVC thrombus. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Sure, I've been experiencing some discomfort and pain in the right side of my abdomen recently.
Doctor: I see. We have performed a CTAG on you, and based on the results, your tumor is classified as level II. Before the procedure, we also conducted a laboratory evaluation. Your results were as follows: Hb 83 g/L, CRP 52.2 mg/L, urea 5 mmol/L, creatinine 105.4 μmol/L, and WBC 12.2 × 109/L.
Patient: Oh, okay. What does all that mean?
Doctor: These results indicate that there's an issue with your kidney function, and that's likely related to your tumor and the IVC thrombus. So, we decided to perform a right nephrectomy to address the issue.
Patient: How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The surgery went well. We dissected the right kidney and IVC in a standard manner. The IVC was dilated up to 5 cm just under the right ventricle. We removed your right kidney and the tumor dimensions were 120 × 75 × 70 mm. During the procedure, we also had to remove the tumorous thrombus in your IVC through cavotomy because it had infiltrated the IVC wall. We removed the thrombus in two pieces (65 × 40 × 40 mm and 42 × 30 × 32 mm).
Patient: Wow, that sounds intense. Is everything okay now?
Doctor: Yes, we resected the IVC wall where the tumor had infiltrated and closed the cavectomy with a primary suture. There was some residual stenosis after the closure, but it was around 40%. You were discharged on the 6th postoperative day with urea at 9.2 mmol/L and creatinine at 111.2 μmol/L.
Patient: I'm glad that's over. What did the tests show about the tumor?
Doctor: The tumor histology revealed that it was a clear cell renal carcinoma, classified as pT3a pNO, pMO, grade 3 according to the Fuhrman classification.
Patient: What does that mean for me going forward?
Doctor: You will need regular follow-ups to monitor your condition. Currently, you are alive and without recurrence of RCC or IVC tumor thrombus after 48 months of follow-up. We will continue to keep a close eye on your health to ensure there are no complications.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I really appreciate your help and expertise.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Sure, I've been experiencing some discomfort and pain in the right side of my abdomen recently
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, referred for treatment of a right kidney tumor and IVC thrombus, reports discomfort and pain on the right side of the abdomen. The patient has undergone a right nephrectomy to address these issues.

Objective.Observations: CTAG results classified the kidney tumor as level II. Pre-operative lab results showed Hb 83 g/L, CRP 52.2 mg/L, urea 5 mmol/L, creatinine 105.4 μmol/L, and WBC 12.2 × 10^9/L. Postoperative findings included a right kidney tumor measuring 120 × 75 × 70 mm and IVC thrombus in two pieces (65 × 40 × 40 mm and 42 × 30 × 32 mm). Postoperative urea was 9.2 mmol/L and creatinine 111.2 μmol/L. Tumor histology confirmed clear cell renal carcinoma, pT3a pNO, pMO, grade 3 (Fuhrman classification).

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is clear cell renal carcinoma with IVC thrombus. The patient underwent successful right nephrectomy and thrombectomy with residual IVC stenosis of 40%. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the current absence of recurrence after 48 months of

Plan.Treatment: The patient will continue with regular follow-ups to monitor for recurrence of renal cell carcinoma or IVC thrombus. Emphasis on monitoring renal function and potential complications related to residual IVC stenosis. Education on signs of recurrence and importance of adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I have a report here regarding your medical history. You were diagnosed with clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) of the right kidney and underwent a radical nephrectomy, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I had that surgery about 6 years ago.
Doctor: I see. You were in remission for 6 years post-nephrectomy when you presented with a solitary lesion in the head of the pancreas. This was discovered upon surveillance, and it was resected via a Whipple procedure. Do you recall that?
Patient: Yeah, I remember that surgery. They initially thought it was a single lesion.
Doctor: Yes, but interestingly, histopathology reported it as a multi-focal lesion of renal cell carcinoma rather than a solitary lesion. Ten years after the resection of the primary tumor, you presented with a thyroid nodule without any history of thyroid dysfunction. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I had never had any thyroid issues before that.
Doctor: Accordingly, imaging was performed, and a 5.16 cm lesion was found. A fine needle aspiration was done, which revealed RCC metastasis. As a result, you underwent a total thyroidectomy. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I had that surgery to remove my thyroid.
Doctor: Six months later, you presented with a mass on the anteromedial aspect of the forearm. It was biopsied and confirmed to be another metastatic lesion of RCC, and thus it was excised with negative margins. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I had that mass removed from my forearm.
Doctor: Within the following year, you presented with another mass on the forearm, distal to the site of the previous one. After discovering the subcutaneous lesion on your forearm, a metastatic workup was promptly performed, and a CT scan showed multiple enhanced pancreatic lesions. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I had another mass on my forearm and the CT scan revealed those pancreatic lesions.
Doctor: Subsequently, you underwent a completion pancreatectomy and resection of the second forearm mass. One year later, another metastatic lesion was found in the left kidney, for which you underwent a left partial nephrectomy with negative margins. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I had those surgeries as well.
Doctor: I'm happy to report that, as per a recent follow-up, you are currently alive and in good condition. Please continue to follow up with us regularly to monitor your health.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and will continue to follow up as needed.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's right
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a long-term survivor of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC), initially presented with a right kidney tumor treated with radical nephrectomy 16 years ago. Six years post-nephrectomy, the patient developed a multi-focal lesion in the head of the pancreas, initially thought to be a solitary lesion, treated with a Whipple procedure. Ten years after the primary tumor resection, the patient presented with a thyroid nodule, later identified as RCC metastasis, leading to a total thyroidectomy. Six months following, a forearm mass was noted and excised; it was confirmed as metastatic RCC. Another forearm mass and multiple pancreatic lesions were identified within a year, treated with completion pancreatectomy and mass resection. Most recently, a metastatic lesion was found in the left kidney, treated with partial nephrectomy.

Objective.Observations: The patient underwent multiple surgeries for metastatic RCC including radical nephrectomy, Whipple procedure, total thyroidectomy, excision of forearm masses, completion pancreatectomy, and partial nephrectomy of the left kidney. Histopathology confirmed RCC in all instances. Recent follow-up shows the patient in good condition.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). The patient has shown multiple metastases over the years including to the pancreas, thyroid, forearm, and contralateral kidney. Despite multiple metastatic events, the patient remains in good condition post multiple resections with negative margins.

Plan.Treatment: Continue regular follow-ups to monitor for any new metastatic lesions or recurrence of ccRCC. Emphasize the importance of adherence to scheduled surveillance imaging and consultations. Educate the patient on symptoms of potential new metastases for early detection. Manage any post-surgical complications or symptoms with appropriate referrals to oncology, endocrinology, and surgical specialties as needed.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, sir. I see that you presented to our outpatient clinic in August 2011 with left vision deterioration. Can you tell me more about your vision problem?
Patient: Yes, my left eye's vision has been getting worse over time.
Doctor: I have your test results here. Your best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/20 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. We also performed an anterior segment examination, which was unremarkable. However, during the dilated fundus examination, we noticed red-orange lesions in the macula associated with RPE damage.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we diagnosed you with polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PCV). We initiated a pro re nata (PRN) regimen with intravitreal ranibizumab (IVR) injections to treat your condition. After 42 anti-VEGF injections, including 7 initial IVRs and subsequent 35 intravitreal aflibercept (IVA) injections, over a period of 5 years and 7 months, your left vision remained at 20/40.
Patient: So, did the treatment help at all?
Doctor: Yes, but the OCT scans showed persistent subretinal fluid and RPE detachment. We also performed indocyanine green angiography (IA), which demonstrated a branching vascular network (BVN) and polyps in your left eye. That's when we decided to switch your treatment strategy to combination IVR and photodynamic therapy (PDT) according to the EVEREST II study.
Patient: How did that work out?
Doctor: After three months, IA confirmed complete regression of the polyp, with the BVN persisting without apparent regression. In your case, we acquired the first OCT-A image using PLEX Elite 9000 nine months prior to the combination therapy, which also disclosed the BVN and polyp in the corresponding locations as indicated by IA.
Patient: Were there any changes before the PDT?
Doctor: Before incorporating PDT into your treatment, your eye received 9 additional IVRs. However, OCT-A after each injection showed no apparent changes in the BVN or polyp.
Patient: So, what's next for my treatment?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we decided to switch to the combined therapy of IVR and PDT. We performed standard full-fluence PDT three days after your 43rd IVR. We will continue to monitor your condition closely and adjust your treatment as necessary.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any more questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, my left eye's vision has been getting worse over time
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a male, reported progressive deterioration of vision in his left eye. He has been under treatment for polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PCV) since his diagnosis in August 2011. He expressed concerns about the effectiveness of the ongoing treatment.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Persistent subretinal fluid and RPE detachment
Objective.Observations: The patient's best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was recorded at 20/20 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. Anterior segment examination showed no remarkable findings. Dilated fundus examination revealed red-orange lesions in the macula with retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) damage. After 42 anti-VEGF injections over approximately 5 years and 7 months, his left vision remained at 20/40. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) scans indicated persistent subretinal fluid and RPE detachment. Indocyanine green angiography (IA) and OCT angiography (OCT-A) confirmed the presence of a branching vascular network (BVN) and polyps. Despite multiple intravitreal ranibizumab (IVR) injections, there was no significant change in the BVN or polyps until the introduction of photodynamic therapy (PDT).

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PCV) with persistent subretinal fluid and RPE detachment despite extensive anti-VEGF treatment. The patient has shown partial response to intravitreal injections and recent introduction of PDT, with complete regression of the polyp but persistence of BVN.

Plan.Treatment: The treatment plan includes continuation of combined therapy with IVR and PDT, following the protocol of the EVEREST II study. The patient received standard full-fluence PDT three days after his 43rd IVR injection. Close monitoring of his condition will be necessary to adjust treatment as needed. Further consultations with a retinal specialist are recommended to evaluate the progression and modify the treatment strategy accordingly. Patient education on the chronic nature of PCV and the importance of regular follow-up is crucial for managing expectations and ensuring compliance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello Mr. G, I see here that you're a 39-year-old Asian British man, married and currently unemployed, living with your family. You have a long forensic history. Can you tell me about your experience with Bipolar Disorder?
Patient: Yeah, I've had Bipolar Disorder since I was 28. I've been admitted to hospitals a bunch of times, and I've had trouble taking my medications and engaging with my community team.
Doctor: I understand. It looks like you also have a history of poly-substance misuse, including alcohol, cocaine, MDMA, cannabis, and "legal highs." Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's true.
Doctor: In the past, you've been treated with a mood stabilizer called Sodium Valproate, as well as Zuclopenthixol and Risperidone Depot, both of which were stopped due to sexual dysfunction. You've also been on Olanzapine and Quetiapine, but those were stopped because of a poor response. Is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, that's right.
Doctor: At the time of your admission to Highgate Mental Health Centre, you were administered Abilify Depot 400 mg, monthly, but it seemed to have little efficacy. You were transferred from another ward due to a manic relapse, with no leave and a diagnosis of Bipolar Affective Disorder, current episode manic. Can you tell me about your behavior during that time?
Patient: I was really agitated, aggressive, and intimidating. I banged my fist on the table and threatened the staff with a glass bottle. I was also acting really bizarre, like wearing sunglasses indoors and holding pieces of paper with weird notes on Hitler, quantum physics, and aliens.
Doctor: It seems that you were thought disordered and had grandiose delusional beliefs, like thinking you were the King of Egypt and able to cause a nuclear war. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's what was happening.
Doctor: I also see that you have a long history of violence towards staff and patients, like breaking a nurse's nose and stabbing another patient with a pen. Is that correct?
Patient: Unfortunately, yes. I wasn't in a good state of mind.
Doctor: I understand. It must have been very difficult for you and the staff to verbally de-escalate the situation. You didn't agree to change your medication regime at the time, as you believed you should be treated "only with love." Is that right?
Patient: Yeah, I was really resistant to changing my meds.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing your experiences with me, Mr. G. Based on your history and symptoms, we'll work together to find a treatment plan that better suits your needs and helps you manage your Bipolar Disorder.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've had Bipolar Disorder since I was 28
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Mr. G, a 39-year-old Asian British male, reports a history of Bipolar Disorder diagnosed at age 28, with multiple hospital admissions and difficulties adhering to treatment and engaging with community teams. He has a history of poly-substance misuse including alcohol, cocaine, MDMA, cannabis, and "legal highs." He describes significant medication non-compliance and resistance to changing medications, believing that he should be treated "only with love." He reports aggressive and bizarre behavior during manic episodes, including threats and delusional beliefs.

Objective.Observations: Mr. G was previously treated with mood stabilizers and antipsychotics including Sodium Valproate, Zuclopenthixol, Risperidone Depot, Olanzapine, and Quetiapine, all discontinued due to side effects or poor response. Currently, he is on Abilify Depot 400 mg monthly, which has shown little efficacy. He was recently admitted to Highgate Mental Health Centre due to a manic relapse, exhibiting agitation, aggression, and thought disorder.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is Bipolar Affective Disorder, current episode manic, with a history of medication non-compliance and poly-substance misuse. Differential diagnoses could include substance-induced mood disorder or personality disorder, considering his complex clinical and forensic history. The prognosis is guarded due to the chronic nature of his illness and poor medication adherence.

Plan.Treatment: The treatment plan will involve a review and possible adjustment of his current pharmacotherapy, considering his history of poor response and side effects. A multidisciplinary approach will be necessary, involving psychiatry, nursing, and possibly a substance misuse team. Psychoeducation will be provided to enhance medication compliance and understanding of his condition. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor his mental state and response to the adjusted treatment plan. Referral to a psychotherapist for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) may be beneficial to address substance misuse issues and improve coping strategies.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm here to discuss your daughter's medical history and recent genetic testing. She was born via Caesarean section at 32 weeks gestational age to you, a 31-year-old gravida 4 para 3 mother. Was the pregnancy course uncomplicated?
Mother: Yes, it was pretty smooth, and no prenatal genetic testing was indicated at that time.
Doctor: I see. Delivery was emergent due to fetal heart rate decelerations, and after delivery, a nuchal cord was noted. Her birth weight was 1304 g, which is between the 10-25th percentile for her gestational age. She stayed in the neonatal intensive care unit for 2 months, during which her course was complicated by intraventricular hemorrhage of unknown grade. Were you aware of this?
Mother: Yes, we were informed about that.
Doctor: Paternity testing was obtained a few months after birth due to court regulations involving you and the alleged father. 21 polymorphic loci were genotyped, and initial results appeared to exclude the alleged father from paternity due to genetic inconsistencies at loci F13A01 and D5S818. However, you insisted on the alleged father’s paternity, and additional testing was performed. Is that correct?
Mother: Yes, I was sure he was the father, so we went for more testing.
Doctor: During the resolution process, the lab tested PowerPlex© ESX, PowerPlex© Fusion, and PowerPlex© LC5 test batteries. HLA testing was also performed. A notable finding was that your daughter was homozygous for maternal alleles for all loci located on chromosome 6. These findings prompted the laboratory to recommend that she receive a medical genetics evaluation for possible maternal uniparental disomy. Are you familiar with this condition?
Mother: Not really, can you explain it to me?
Doctor: Maternal uniparental disomy is an underlying genetic condition where a child inherits both copies of chromosome 6 from the mother instead of one from each parent. This can lead to various health issues, depending on the specific genes involved.
Mother: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Your daughter presented for a medical genetics consultation at 10 months of age following the updated test results. During the visit, you reported that she appeared to be developing well and reaching milestones appropriately. Have you noticed any concerning symptoms since then?
Mother: No, she seems to be doing fine so far.
Doctor: That's good to hear. We will continue to monitor her development and health as she grows. It's important to have regular check-ups and follow-up appointments to ensure she remains healthy and to address any concerns that may arise.
Mother: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. We'll make sure to keep up with her appointments.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No chief complaint documented
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 10-month-old female born prematurely at 32 weeks via Caesarean section, presented for a medical genetics consultation. The mother reports a smooth pregnancy with no prenatal genetic testing indicated. Post-delivery, the patient experienced intraventricular hemorrhage and stayed in the NICU for 2 months. Recently, genetic testing suggested maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 6. The mother reports that the patient is developing well and reaching milestones appropriately, with no concerning symptoms noted since the last consultation.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Homozygous for maternal alleles for all loci located on chromosome 6
Objective.Observations: Birth weight was 1304 g, between the 10-25th percentile for gestational age. Genetic testing included 21 polymorphic loci, PowerPlex© ESX, PowerPlex© Fusion, and PowerPlex© LC5 test batteries, and HLA testing, revealing homozygosity for maternal alleles on chromosome 6. No physical examination findings or recent laboratory results were provided in the dialogue.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 6, a genetic condition where both copies of chromosome 6 are inherited from the mother. This condition can lead to various health issues, although the patient currently shows normal development and no symptoms.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to continue regular pediatric and genetic follow-up to monitor the patient’s development and address any emerging health issues. Educate the mother on potential health complications associated with maternal uniparental disomy and ensure understanding of the importance of adherence to scheduled appointments. No specific medication or dietary changes indicated at this time.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 51-year-old male patient with a history of asthma managed with β2 adrenergic receptor agonists like salbutamol. What brings you to the asthma clinic at the University hospital of Verona today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. Over the last 24 hours, I've been experiencing wheezing, coughing, whistling sounds during breathing, and worsening dyspnea.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a physical examination to check for any abnormalities. Please take a deep breath for me.
Patient: *takes a deep breath*
Doctor: I can hear wheezing during your normal breathing and prolonged phases of forced exhalation. It also seems like you're using accessory muscles for breathing. I'd like to prescribe a blood gas analysis to investigate the effectiveness of gas exchange and the state of your voluntary respiratory control. This will give us more information about your current condition.
Patient: Okay, Doctor. What does the blood gas analysis involve?
Doctor: A nurse will collect a venous blood sample from you using a 3.0 mL heparinized syringe, which is a product of Smiths Medical. The sample will then be hand-delivered to our central laboratory for analysis of blood gases.
Patient: Alright, sounds good.
*Nurse collects the blood sample and delivers it to the laboratory*
Doctor: We've received the results of your blood gas analysis. Based on these findings, we'll be able to make a more informed decision about your treatment plan. I'll go through the results with you and explain their implications.
Patient: Okay, I appreciate that.
Doctor: *explains the results and treatment plan*
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'll follow the treatment plan and keep you updated on my progress.
Doctor: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. We'll also schedule a follow-up appointment to monitor your condition. Take care, and I hope you feel better soon.
Patient: Thanks, Doctor. See you at the follow-up appointment!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 51-year-old male with a history of asthma, currently managed with β2 adrenergic receptor agonists such as salbutamol. He reports experiencing increased wheezing, coughing, whistling sounds during breathing, and worsening dyspnea over the last 24 hours.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed wheezing during normal breathing and prolonged phases of forced exhalation, with the use of accessory muscles for breathing. A blood gas analysis was conducted using a 3.0 mL heparinized syringe, and the sample was analyzed at the central laboratory. Specific results of the blood gas analysis were not detailed in the transcript.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with an exacerbation of asthma. The blood gas analysis was likely used to assess the severity of the exacerbation and the effectiveness of the patient's current asthma management strategy.

Plan.Treatment: The treatment plan will be adjusted based on the results of the blood gas analysis, although specific modifications were not detailed in the transcript. The patient was advised to follow the new treatment plan and keep the healthcare provider updated on his progress. A follow-up appointment was scheduled to monitor his condition. The patient was encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I have your test results from your fundus examination and optical coherence tomography (OCT) back in November 2012. It seems that you were diagnosed with wet AMD in your left eye due to the onset of metamorphopsia. At that time, you were being treated with a combination of angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor and thiazide diuretic for a 20-year history of well controlled hypertension. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Your best-corrected visual acuity was 10/10 in your right eye and 8/10 in the left eye. We also performed a slit-lamp examination, which showed that both anterior chambers had clear aqueous humor and no inflammatory reaction. Dilated fundus examination revealed a subretinal whitish mass and adjacent subretinal hemorrhage.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: The OCT confirmed the presence of a subretinal lesion and intraretinal edema. After obtaining your consent, we treated you with monthly intravitreal administration of 0.5 mg ranibizumab for three months. This resulted in complete retinal hemorrhage and edema resolution, and an increased visual acuity in your left eye to 10/10.
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: Following that, you underwent routine follow-up visits every two months, including fundus examination and OCT, which did not show any abnormal findings. However, in May 2014, there was a reduction of visual acuity from 10/10 to 7/10. We monitored your condition but did not treat you with anti-VEGF drugs as there was no sign of neovascularization.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: In May 2015, your visual acuity further reduced to 3/10, and both fundus examination and OCT revealed a reactivation of the neovascular membrane, edema, and pigment epithelial detachment. For this reason, we treated you again with intravitreal injections of ranibizumab (0.5 mg), first on a monthly basis and then using a treat and extend approach.
Patient: How many injections did I receive?
Doctor: You received overall six injections until the end of February 2016, when your visual acuity increased to 6/10. At the follow-up visit in May 2016, the neovascular membrane appeared inactive and the visual acuity was stable at 6/10, so our ophthalmologist decided for a pro re nata approach.
Patient: So, what's the plan going forward?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition closely and determine if any further treatment is needed. If there are any changes in your vision, please contact us immediately.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's right
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a history of wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in the left eye, initially diagnosed in November 2012, with symptoms of metamorphopsia. The patient has a 20-year history of well-controlled hypertension treated with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and a thiazide diuretic. The patient recalls previous treatments and changes in visual acuity over time.
