Doctor: I see. It's important to mention that you come from Barbar El Fugara village, which is the most endemic area for visceral leishmaniasis in Sudan. But you have no history of this disease, right?
Patient: Yeah, that's correct.
Doctor: We'll enroll you in our clinical study called "Neglected Infectious Diseases Diagnosis" (NIDIAG) to find out the cause of your symptoms. We'll perform standard history taking, a physical examination, and a set of diagnostic tests targeting severe and treatable infectious causes of persistent fever. These include visceral leishmaniasis, malaria, tuberculosis, enteric fever, brucellosis, amebic liver abscess, relapsing fever, rickettsial diseases, leptospirosis, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. Don't worry, the NIDIAG project won't interfere with your treatment, and we'll make sure essential medicines for these conditions are available.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: Let's start with the physical examination. Your weight is 21 kg, height 118 cm, axillary temperature 40.7°C, respiratory rate 30/minute, heart rate 108/minute, and blood pressure 90/70 mm Hg. You have a normal level of consciousness, moderate cachexia, pallor, cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy (size 1 cm), and bilateral tonsil inflammation. Your chest examination shows crackles and decreased air entry in the right lung. No abnormalities were found in your abdominal examination. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Patient: Hmm, what does all that mean?
Doctor: It means that you have some signs of infection, like fever, lymphadenopathy, and tonsil inflammation. The crackles and decreased air entry in your right lung could suggest a respiratory infection. We'll need to run some laboratory tests to get a clearer picture.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: Your laboratory testing results show a hemoglobin level of 11.2 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 12.6 × 10^9. These values indicate that your body is fighting an infection. We'll use these results and the results of the other diagnostic tests to determine the cause of your symptoms and the best course of treatment.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Once we have all the test results, we'll discuss the appropriate treatment options with you. In the meantime, make sure to rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take over-the-counter medications to manage your fever and discomfort.
Patient: Got it. Thanks for your help, doctor.
Doctor: It's my pleasure. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to ask. We're here to help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: A 12-year-old boy from Barbar El Fugara village, an endemic area for visceral leishmaniasis in Sudan, presents with a one-week history of fever, chills, headache, dry cough, and vomiting. He reports loss of appetite over the last two days and denies any past history of visceral leishmaniasis.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals a weight of 21 kg, height 118 cm, axillary temperature of 40.7°C, respiratory rate of 30/minute, heart rate of 108/minute, and blood pressure of 90/70 mm Hg. The patient exhibits moderate cachexia, pallor, cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy (1 cm), bilateral tonsil inflammation, and crackles with decreased air entry in the right lung. Abdominal examination is normal. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin at 11.2 g/dL and white blood cell count at 12.6 × 10^9/L.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms and findings suggest an infectious process, likely a severe respiratory infection given the lung findings, in the context of potential exposure to endemic diseases such as visceral leishmaniasis, malaria, and others. Differential diagnoses include respiratory infections, visceral leishmaniasis, and other infectious diseases prevalent in the region.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current management; monitor for progression

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you have a past medical history of hypertension, obesity, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been having abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for the past eight days. Along with that, I've been experiencing nausea, vomiting, fevers, and diarrhea.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let's check your vital signs first. On admission, your blood pressure is 130/90, heart rate is 133, respiratory rate is 18, and your temperature is 102.7 F. During the physical exam, I noticed some jaundice, but I didn't appreciate any abdominal tenderness or guarding. We'll need to run some laboratory tests to get more information.
Patient: Okay, doc.
Doctor: Your lab results show leukocytosis of 20.2 x 109 cells per liter, total bilirubin of 2.4 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 114 units per liter, AST of 62 U/L, ALT of 59 U/L, and albumin of 2.6 g/dL. We conducted an abdominal computed tomographic (CT) scan, which revealed a 6.9 cm heterogeneously enhancing abscess collection within the left hepatic lobe.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We had interventional radiology perform CT-guided percutaneous drainage and place a biliary drain to help with the abscess. The cultures from the abscess showed alpha hemolytic streptococcus. Due to persistent leukocytosis, we performed a repeat abdominal CT scan, which showed a 2.1 cm fish bone as a radiopaque foreign body at the level of the falciform fissure with inflammation tracking to the abscess cavity.
Patient: How did that get there?
Doctor: It's unclear at the moment. We performed an upper endoscopy, but it failed to visualize a fistulous opening by the foreign body in the gastric antrum. We discussed your case in a multidisciplinary hepatobiliary conference.
Patient: What's the plan, then?
Doctor: Since you've shown rapid clinical improvement with minimal biliary drain output, we removed the drains and treated you with extended intravenous antibiotics. We saw you in the clinic six weeks later, and you had no complaints.
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling a lot better.
Doctor: That's great to hear. We performed repeat CT imaging, which indicated a resolution of the hepatic abscess to a size of 1.7x1.3 cm without any further migration of the foreign body.
Patient: So, am I all good now?
Doctor: Yes, it seems that the treatment has been successful, and there is no further migration of the foreign body. Just make sure to continue monitoring your health and reach out if you experience any new symptoms or concerns.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome! Take care, and don't hesitate to contact us if you need anything.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Patient reports a history of hypertension, obesity, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He presents with an eight-day history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fevers, and diarrhea.

Objective.Observations: Vital signs on admission include blood pressure 130/90 mmHg, heart rate 133 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and temperature 102.7 F. Physical exam shows jaundice but no abdominal tenderness or guarding. Laboratory findings reveal leukocytosis (20.2 x 10^9 cells/L), elevated total bilirubin (2.4 mg/dL), alkaline phosphatase (114 U/L), AST (62 U/L), ALT (59 U/L), and low albumin (2.6 g/dL). Abdominal CT scan shows a 6.9 cm hepatic abscess in the left lobe and a 2.1 cm fish bone at the level of the falciform fissure. Interventional radiology performed CT-guided percutaneous drainage and biliary drain placement. Cultures identified alpha hemolytic streptococcus. Repeat CT imaging post-treatment shows resolution of the hepatic abscess to 1.7x1.3 cm with no further migration of the foreign body.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Diagnosis of hepatic abscess secondary to foreign body ingestion (fish bone) with associated complications including leukocytosis and jaundice. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of right upper quadrant pain such as cholecystitis or hepatic tumors.

Plan.Treatment: Treatment included CT-guided percutaneous drainage, placement of a biliary drain, and extended intravenous antibiotics. The biliary drain was removed after rapid clinical improvement and minimal output. Follow-up in clinic six weeks post-treatment showed no complaints and repeat imaging indicated significant resolution of the abscess. Patient advised to continue monitoring health and report any new symptoms or concerns.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith, and I'll be taking care of you today. I just received your medical report. Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Yeah, I'm 70 years old, and I have a history of dyslipidaemia. I also have a habit of smoking.
Doctor: I see. Unfortunately, you recently suffered an ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Did you receive any interventions for this?
Patient: Yes, they couldn't do a percutaneous coronary artery intervention right away, so they performed thrombolysis within 4 hours of my symptoms starting.
Doctor: Okay. It seems that you developed an advanced atrioventricular block after that, requiring a transcutaneous pacemaker. You also experienced cardiorespiratory arrest in ventricular fibrillation, but it was reversed after one cycle of advanced life support. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I understand you were then transported by airplane to a PCI-capable center. They performed a coronary angiography, which showed a 50-60% stenosis in the proximal segment of your right coronary artery. They treated it with a metal stent. Can you confirm that?
Patient: Yes, that's what they did.
Doctor: An echocardiography was also performed, revealing moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of 35%, inferior, inferolateral, and inferoseptal akinesia, and moderate mitral regurgitation. Do you remember this test?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: After your 10-hour flight, you were admitted to our intensive care unit in cardiogenic shock, requiring inotropes and non-invasive ventilation. A bedside transthoracic echocardiography revealed severe mitral valve regurgitation of uncertain mechanism, along with moderate left and right ventricle systolic dysfunction. Is this correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: We performed a transoesophageal echocardiography, which revealed a 9 mm disruption of the posteromedial papillary muscle, consistent with a contained rupture. This instability in the sub-valvular apparatus caused a broad posterior leaflet prolapse, leading to severe mitral regurgitation with an eccentric jet with Coanda effect, reaching the left atria roof. Are you following me so far?
Patient: Yes, I understand.
Doctor: Due to these findings, you underwent an urgent mitral valve replacement with a biological prosthetic valve, preserving both anterior and posterior leaflets. Your post-operative recovery went well, and you were discharged 12 days after surgery. You'll need to continue anticoagulant therapy for three months. Does that sound right to you?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: Great. It's important to follow up with your healthcare team to monitor your progress and ensure the effectiveness of your treatment. Do you have any questions or concerns?
Patient: No, I think you've explained everything clearly. Thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions in the future, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care, and I wish you a smooth recovery.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I'm 70 years old, and I have a history of dyslipidaemia
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of dyslipidemia and smoking. He reports having suffered an ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), followed by thrombolysis due to the unavailability of immediate percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Post-thrombolysis, he developed advanced atrioventricular block requiring a transcutaneous pacemaker and experienced a cardiorespiratory arrest in ventricular fibrillation, which was successfully reversed. He underwent coronary angiography showing 50-60% stenosis in the proximal segment of the right coronary artery, treated with a metal stent. An echocardiography revealed moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 35%, and moderate mitral regurgitation. He was admitted to ICU in cardiogenic shock, requiring inotropes and non-invasive ventilation. A transesophageal echocardiography indicated a 9 mm disruption of the posteromedial papillary muscle, leading to severe mitral regurgitation, which was treated with urgent mitral valve replacement using a biological prosthetic valve.

Objective.Observations: Vital signs and lab results were not provided. Imaging studies confirmed severe cardiac complications including moderate to severe mitral regurgitation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction. The patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement and was discharged on post-operative day 12.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is severe mitral regurgitation secondary to posteromedial papillary muscle disruption following STEMI. Differential diagnoses include complications related to dyslipidemia and smoking, such as further coronary artery disease. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following surgical intervention, though dependent on post-operative management and lifestyle adjustments.

Plan.Treatment: The patient will continue anticoagulant therapy for three months post-operatively. Regular follow-up is essential to monitor valve function and cardiac status. Lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation are strongly advised to mitigate further cardiovascular risks. Referral to a cardiologist for ongoing management and a rehabilitation specialist for physical recovery and conditioning is recommended. Compliance with medication and lifestyle changes will be crucial for recovery and prevention of further complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you have a history of cutaneous melanoma. Can you tell me what brings you here today?
Patient: Hi, yes. I was recently admitted to the Thoracic Surgery Unit of Policlinico Umberto I because of the appearance of some pulmonary nodules on a follow-up exam.
Doctor: I see. Was it a positron emission tomography or computed tomography exam?
Patient: Both, actually.
Doctor: How was your physical examination and serum chemistry?
Patient: They were normal. I was afebrile and in good condition.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Due to your history of melanoma, there was a high suspicion of lung metastasis. I see you underwent a wedge resection in the right lower lobe. Can you tell me what they found in the nodular lesion?
Patient: There were areas of necrosis, and histology confirmed extensive necrosis surrounded by chronic inflammatory reaction.
Doctor: I see. The main finding was the presence of worms embedded in the necrotic material, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: For identification purposes, they performed a polymerase chain reaction–DNA test. The DNA was extracted from the paraffin block, and sequence analysis showed a 100% match with Dirofilaria repens. Are you familiar with this?
Patient: Not really, no.
Doctor: Dirofilaria repens is a type of filarioid parasite. It's not very common, but can be transmitted through mosquito bites. You mentioned living in an urban area of Central Italy, but have you had any recent travels or particular habits that may have exposed you?
Patient: Well, I've traveled to Northeast Italy and every August, I go to a rural area in Bosnia Herzegovina. I remember being frequently bitten by mosquitoes during those trips.
Doctor: It's possible that the exposure occurred during one of those trips. How about your dog? Has it been tested for any parasites?
Patient: Yes, our veterinarian checked the dog and didn't find any parasites, including Dirofilaria, in its blood.
Doctor: That's good to know. Since the infection was localized, you were not given any anti-infective therapy, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: At your 3-month follow-up, were your physical examination and blood analyses normal?
Patient: Yes, everything was normal.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Please continue to monitor your health and report any changes or concerns. If you travel to those rural areas again, I recommend taking precautions to avoid mosquito bites.
Patient: Will do, thank you for the information, doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, yes
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, with a history of cutaneous melanoma, presented due to pulmonary nodules identified in a follow-up exam, which included both PET and CT scans. The patient was asymptomatic, afebrile, and in good condition during the physical examination. The patient reported a recent wedge resection in the right lower lobe where histology confirmed extensive necrosis with chronic inflammatory reaction and presence of Dirofilaria repens worms. The patient has traveled to Northeast Italy and rural Bosnia Herzegovina, where mosquito exposure was significant. The patient's dog tested negative for parasites.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination and serum chemistry were normal. Imaging showed pulmonary nodules. Histology of the nodular lesion from the right lower lobe indicated necrosis with chronic inflammation and embedded worms. PCR-DNA test from the paraffin block confirmed Dirofilaria repens. No anti-infective therapy was administered as the infection was localized. Follow-up at 3 months showed normal physical examination and blood analyses.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is pulmonary dirofilariasis due to Dirofilaria repens, secondary to mosquito bites during travel. Differential diagnosis initially included lung metastasis from previous melanoma, which was ruled out by histological findings and lab tests.

Plan.Treatment: Continue regular follow-up visits to monitor health status. No anti-infective therapy needed as the infection was localized and managed surgically. Advise patient to take precautions against mosquito bites during travels, especially in areas known for mosquito-borne diseases. Educate the patient about signs of potential complications and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see from your chart that you are a 66-year-old woman with a significant past medical history of well-controlled hypertension. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've had complaints of microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria for the past 3 years.
Doctor: I see. How has your creatinine level been during this time?
Patient: It was within normal range when it was last checked.
Doctor: Alright. I noticed that we performed a renal biopsy on you. The results showed mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis with fibro-cellular crescents in one out of 18 glomeruli, excluding one global sclerotic glomerulus. The immunofluorescence microscopy revealed the deposition of IgA and C3 in mesangial areas. There was also weak but significant IgG deposition in the glomeruli, somewhat different from the distribution of IgA or C3. Electron microscopy confirmed the presence of electron-dense deposits in mesangial areas. Based on these findings, you were diagnosed with IgA nephropathy.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: To manage your condition, you were started on antihypertensive therapy, mainly with an RAS inhibitor. However, eight months later, your serum creatinine suddenly rose to 4.53 mg/dL from 1.04 mg/dL a month before. Urinalysis showed 100 red blood cells per high power field and urinary protein excretion of 12.3 g/gCr. We then conducted serological tests to differentiate the cause of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The tests revealed the presence of anti-GBM antibody at a titer of 116 IU/mL and the absence of anti-nuclear antibody and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: After your admission, we initiated treatments with hemodialysis, plasma exchange, and intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy followed by oral prednisolone at a dose of 50 mg/day. We performed a second renal biopsy at four weeks after admission to assess the probability of renal recovery and make a final diagnosis. The biopsy revealed cellular to fibrocellular crescents in 18 of 25 glomeruli, excluding six global sclerotic glomeruli. The immunofluorescence study showed linear IgG deposition along the glomerular capillary walls and mesangial staining for IgA.
Patient: What does that mean for my condition?
Doctor: The results of the second biopsy, along with your clinical history and lab findings, confirm the diagnosis of IgA nephropathy with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. We will continue to monitor your condition closely and adjust your treatments as needed to ensure the best possible outcome.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help in managing my condition.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important to stay on top of your treatment and follow-up appointments. If you have any concerns or symptoms, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you.
Patient: Thank you, I will.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: 66-year-old female with a history of well-controlled hypertension presents with complaints of microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria for the past 3 years. She reports that her creatinine levels were within normal range until eight months ago when it suddenly increased.

Objective.Observations: Last creatinine level was 4.53 mg/dL, up from 1.04 mg/dL a month prior. Urinalysis revealed 100 red blood cells per high power field and urinary protein excretion of 12.3 g/gCr. Initial renal biopsy indicated mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis with fibro-cellular crescents and deposition of IgA, C3, and IgG. Electron microscopy confirmed electron-dense deposits in mesangial areas. Serological tests showed anti-GBM antibody at a titer of 116 IU/mL. A second renal biopsy showed cellular to fibrocellular crescents in 18 of 25 glomeruli with linear IgG deposition along the glomerular capillary walls.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Diagnosis of IgA nephropathy with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The patient's condition has evolved from initial IgA nephropathy to include features of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, evidenced by worsening renal function and biopsy findings.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current regimen of hemodialysis, plasma exchange, and corticosteroid therapy (intravenous methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisolone 50 mg/day). Monitor renal function and adjust treatments as necessary. Emphasize the importance of adherence to treatment and regular follow-up appointments to assess response to therapy and modify management plan accordingly.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have a history of anxiety, depression, and anorexia nervosa. Can you tell me about your symptoms and how long you've been experiencing them?
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really sad, lonely, and hopeless. I also can't enjoy things I used to like. I've been restricting my eating to lose weight for a few years now.
Doctor: I see. You were admitted to our hospital twice, the first one in September 2019 when you lost 16 kg over 3-4 months and were weighing 40 kg with a BMI of 16.0 kg/m2. You also had sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 30-40 BPM. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: According to your lab values during your two admissions, there were significant changes. Now, regarding your eating habits, have you ever engaged in purging, bingeing, or using laxatives?
Patient: No, I haven't done any of those things.
Doctor: I understand you have been emaciated and minimized the severity of your nutritional status and preoccupation with your weight and body image. Have you ever had any suicidal thoughts or desired death?
Patient: I don't really think about suicide, but sometimes I wish I could die rather than deal with my eating disorder.
Doctor: It's important to address these feelings and work towards recovery. I see that you have experienced several moves during your childhood, and you reported increased anxiety after a recent move due to your parents' divorce and starting a new school. Is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, that's true. It's been really tough.
Doctor: You have received eating disorder treatment at various levels of care, including inpatient, residential, partial hospitalization, and intensive outpatient programs in four states. Is that right?
Patient: Yes, I've been through a lot of treatment programs.
Doctor: It seems that at times, you've become physically aggressive towards staff and family, and in one instance, you bit a chunk off the nape of your sister's neck during a family visit at a residential stay. This led to your discharge. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, I got really jealous of my sister because she was going home after the visit, and I had to stay. I just lost control.
Doctor: It's important to address these behaviors as well. For now, we will place you on 1:1 for safety concerns. We will work together to create a treatment plan tailored to your needs and support you on your journey to recovery.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been feeling really sad, lonely, and hopeless
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports long-standing feelings of sadness, loneliness, and hopelessness, with a loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities. The patient has a history of restricting food intake to lose weight, ongoing for several years, without engaging in purging, bingeing, or using laxatives. The patient denies active suicidal ideation but expresses a wish to die to escape the burden of the eating disorder. The patient has experienced increased anxiety following parental divorce and a recent move. There is a history of physical aggression, including a severe incident involving a family member during a treatment program.

Objective.Observations: The patient has a history of two hospital admissions, with significant weight loss (16 kg over 3-4 months) leading to a BMI of 16.0 kg/m2 and sinus bradycardia (heart rate 30-40 BPM). The patient has been treated in various settings for an eating disorder, including inpatient, residential, partial hospitalization, and intensive outpatient programs across four states.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is anorexia nervosa, with comorbid major depressive disorder and anxiety. The patient's history of physical aggression and severe restriction of food intake complicates the treatment. The prognosis is guarded due to the chronic nature of the eating disorder and psychiatric comorbidities.

Plan.Treatment: The immediate plan includes placing the patient on 1:1 monitoring due to safety concerns. A comprehensive treatment plan will be developed, focusing on nutritional rehabilitation, psychotherapy for depression and anxiety, and strategies to manage aggressive behaviors. Continued psychiatric evaluation and close monitoring of vital signs and nutritional status are necessary. Referral to a specialist in eating disorders for ongoing management and possible reevaluation of the current treatment strategy is recommended. Education about the illness and its management will be provided to the patient and family to improve compliance and understanding.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I have a problem with my left eye. I suddenly got a large scotoma about a week ago.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent medical treatments or vaccinations?
Patient: Yes, I had the third intramuscular administration of a rabies vaccine seven days ago. It was from Novartis and called Rabipur. I got it because a stray cat scratched me.
Doctor: I understand. This rabies vaccine you received is an embryonated-egg vaccine. Have you received any other vaccines recently?
Patient: No, this was the only one. And it was the first time I had any symptoms after vaccination.
Doctor: Okay. Was the stray cat available for observation of rabies symptoms?
Patient: No, the cat wasn't available for observation.
Doctor: Alright. Do you have any remarkable medical history or underlying pathology?
Patient: No, I am otherwise healthy.
Doctor: So your best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes with − 9.0 D in the right eye and − 8.5 D in the left eye. We've also done an ophthalmoscopic examination of your left eye, and it revealed nothing that could explain your complaints. However, during the follow-up, you developed photopsia in the left eye. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: We also conducted visual field testing, which showed an enlarged blind spot and decreased sensitivity superiorly and nasally. Fundus fluorescence angiography (FFA) and autofluorescence (AF) revealed hyperfluorescence corresponding to the area of the retina in the region of ellipsoid zone abnormalities. FFA showed normal appearances in the arteriovenous and late phases in your right eye. However, early choroidal background hyperfluorescence and mild diffuse leakage of fluorescein were noted in the late phase of your left eye. Are you following so far?
Patient: Yes, I'm trying to understand.
Doctor: In addition, optical coherence tomography (OCT) demonstrated disruptions in the ellipsoid zone of the posterior retina. Fundus AF also showed multiple ill-defined spots of markedly increased AF in the posterior pole.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We have also done a complete blood cell count, immunological test, syphilis, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) tests, which all came back normal. We will continue to monitor your condition and determine the best course of action for your eye issue. In the meantime, if you experience any changes or worsening of your symptoms, please contact us immediately.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a previously healthy individual, reports a sudden onset of a large scotoma in the left eye occurring one week ago. The patient recently received the third dose of the Rabipur rabies vaccine following a scratch from a stray cat. No other recent vaccinations or significant medical history were reported. The patient also developed photopsia in the left eye.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Nothing that could explain your complaints
Objective.Observations: The patient's best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes with prescriptions of −9.0 D in the right eye and −8.5 D in the left eye. Ophthalmoscopic examination of the left eye showed no abnormalities. Visual field testing indicated an enlarged blind spot with decreased sensitivity superiorly and nasally in the left eye. Fundus fluorescence angiography and autofluorescence revealed hyperfluorescence and ellipsoid zone abnormalities in the left eye, with normal findings in the right eye. Optical coherence tomography showed disruptions in the ellipsoid zone of the posterior retina in the left eye. Complete blood cell count, immunological tests, and screenings for syphilis and HIV were normal.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a post-vaccination ocular complication, specifically involving the left eye with ellipsoid zone disruptions and photopsia. Differential diagnoses could include autoimmune retinopathy or other inflammatory conditions, though the lack of systemic symptoms and normal immunological tests make these less likely.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's ocular condition with follow-up appointments scheduled to reassess the visual and structural changes in the left eye. The patient is advised to immediately report any new symptoms or worsening of the current condition. Education regarding the potential ocular side effects of vaccinations will be provided to ensure the patient is informed about their condition and the importance of follow-up. Referral to a specialist in retinal disorders may be considered if there is no improvement or further deterioration in the patient's condition.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I am aware that you have a history of schizoaffective disorder, chronic renal failure, type 2 diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, previous stroke with a right arm contracture, and aortic stenosis. You are currently on risperidone and escitalopram, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: You were admitted in December 2015 due to a urinary tract infection, acute renal failure, and deranged international normalized ratio (INR). The Psychiatry service was consulted shortly after your admission. Can you tell me more about your mood during that time?
Patient: Well, my mood was quite low since my brother fell ill about 2 months before that. My antidepressant dose was increased a month before my admission.
Doctor: I see. So at that time, you were at your baseline mental state, engaging well in conversation and denying any low mood, which was confirmed by the community mental health nurse. No changes were made to your management, right?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: A week later, the neurology service was asked to review you due to an altered level of consciousness. During the examination, you presented with waxy flexibility, negativism, new onset increased tone of your left arm, posturing, and catalepsy. Your mobility had deteriorated, with selective speech, mute episodes, and poor oral intake noted by medical staff. Does that sound accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's exactly what happened.
Doctor: The impression was that you were suffering from acute catatonia. An MRI of your brain was performed, and it showed no acute changes. Nasogastric (NG) feeding was established to ensure adequate oral intake. The psychiatry service was again consulted, and they confirmed the diagnosis of acute catatonia. You were diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder with catatonia, as per DSM-5. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: A trial of lorazepam was advised for the treatment of catatonia. The dose was titrated to 3 mg per day. How did you respond to the treatment?
Patient: The treatment worked well for me.
Doctor: That's great to hear. It's important to continue monitoring your symptoms and maintain communication with your healthcare team. If you notice any changes in your mood or experience any new symptoms, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and advice.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's correct
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, with a history of schizoaffective disorder, chronic renal failure, type 2 diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, previous stroke with right arm contracture, and aortic stenosis, reported a low mood related to his brother's illness two months prior to his last hospital admission in December 2015. During that admission, his mood was stable, and no changes were made to his psychiatric management. However, he later developed symptoms of acute catatonia including waxy flexibility, negativism, increased tone in the left arm, posturing, and catalepsy, along with deteriorated mobility, selective speech, mute episodes, and poor oral intake.

Objective.Observations: On physical examination, the patient showed signs of acute catatonia. An MRI of the brain showed no acute changes. The patient was on risperidone and escitalopram, and a trial of lorazepam up to 3 mg per day was initiated, which he responded well to. His vital signs and other specific lab results like INR were not provided in the dialogue.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is schizoaffective disorder with acute catatonia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of altered mental status such as metabolic encephalopathy or neuroleptic malignant syndrome, considering the patient's complex medical history and medication regimen.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring the patient's response to lorazepam for catatonia. Maintain risperidone and escitalopram for underlying schizoaffective disorder. Regular follow-up with psychiatry to monitor mental status and adjust medications as needed. Encourage the patient to maintain communication with the healthcare team, especially if new symptoms arise or mood changes. Nutritional support through established NG feeding should be assessed and continued as necessary. Further consultations with neurology and nephrology should be considered to manage his chronic conditions and prevent complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you have a complex medical history, including a total hip arthroplasty, bladder carcinoma in situ, and chronic kidney disease. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing worsening pain in my left thigh lately.
Doctor: I see. You had a THA placed thirty-one years ago, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And you also had a papillary bladder tumor that was treated with fulguration five years prior to admission, followed by a recurrence of bladder carcinoma in situ diagnosed a year later, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I underwent six initial and six maintenance instillations of Bacillus Calmette-Guérin treatment, which is a strain of Mycobacterium bovis, and my bladder cancer went into remission.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. Now, tell me more about this new pain in your left thigh.
Patient: Well, about four years after the BCG therapy, I developed new-onset drainage from my left lateral thigh. It started swelling and I've been having increasing purulent discharge, pain with movement, chills, rigors, and a fever of 101 °F.
Doctor: How are you feeling today? Are you still experiencing fever?
Patient: I'm afebrile now and my vital signs are normal.
Doctor: Good to know. Let me examine your thigh. Hmm, there's an open wound on the lateral left thigh with purulent drainage and surrounding erythema. Does it hurt when I adduct your left hip?
Patient: Yes, it's painful.
Doctor: I'd like to order some laboratory tests. Your white blood cell count is 10,200 cells/mm3, C-reactive protein is 9.7 mg/dL, and sedimentation rate is 71 mm/hr. We also took a radiograph of your left hip, which showed extensive lucencies around the left THA.
Patient: What does that mean, Doctor?
Doctor: It means we need to take further action. You underwent incision and drainage with an antibiotic spacer placed following admission. Wound, hip fluid, and abscess cultures obtained during irrigation and debridement were negative for bacterial pathogens. However, given your history of prior BCG therapy, we asked the microbiology laboratory to perform mycobacterial cultures, which grew acid-fast bacilli concerning for Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex.
Patient: Oh, no. What's the next step?
Doctor: We initially treated you with clindamycin, ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and metronidazole. Now, you'll be started on isoniazid 300 mg PO daily and rifampin for your tuberculosis complex. We'll closely monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I hope this will help me get better soon.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, with a history of total hip arthroplasty (THA), bladder carcinoma in situ treated with Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG), and chronic kidney disease, presents with worsening pain in the left thigh, new-onset drainage, swelling, purulent discharge, pain with movement, chills, rigors, and a previous fever of 101 °F. The patient reports the pain started approximately four years after BCG therapy. Currently, the patient is afebrile with normal vital signs.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Extensive lucencies around the left THA
Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals an open wound on the lateral left thigh with purulent drainage and surrounding erythema, painful on adduction of the left hip. Laboratory tests show a white blood cell count of 10,200 cells/mm3, C-reactive protein at 9.7 mg/dL, and sedimentation rate at 71 mm/hr. Radiograph of the left hip shows extensive lucencies around the THA. Mycobacterial cultures from the wound, hip fluid, and abscess grew acid-fast bacilli concerning for Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex infection secondary to prior BCG therapy, complicated by a probable prosthetic joint infection given the symptoms and radiographic findings. Differential diagnoses include other bacterial joint infections, though cultures were negative.

Plan.Treatment: The patient was initially treated with clindamycin, ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and metronidazole. Following the identification of Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, the treatment plan was adjusted to include isoniazid 300 mg PO daily and rifampin. The patient will be closely monitored for response to therapy and potential side effects, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with infectious disease specialists and orthopedic surgeons are planned to manage the joint infection and assess the need for surgical intervention.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I have reviewed your medical history and I see that you were admitted to Shafa Hospital on August 15th, 2017. You have a history of ulcerative colitis, steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, deep vein thrombosis in your left thigh, ecchymotic skin lesions, swelling in your left nose, ptosis, and facial nerve palsy. Can you tell me more about the intestinal bleeding you experienced after the fasting periods?
Patient: Sure, Doc. I had bleeding after the Islamic fasting month, Ramadan. It was pretty intense.
Doctor: I see. Your ulcerative colitis was confirmed by clinical manifestations and a colon biopsy. You were on azathioprine 50 mg/day and high-dose prednisolone 60 mg/day for 2 months prior to your hospital admission. How did you feel during that treatment?
Patient: Well, the prednisolone caused my blood sugar to go up, so I had to start taking insulin for my diabetes about a month before being admitted to the hospital.
Doctor: That's correct. You were also on anticoagulant drugs for the treatment of your deep vein thrombosis. After you were admitted to the hospital, you developed progressive periorbital ecchymosis, extensive edema of the nasal area, and a nasal ulcer. Your eye examination revealed proptosis with a 4+ light reaction, evidence of an afferent pupillary defect, also known as Marcus Gunn pupil, no light perception, absolute blindness, ophthalmoplegia, and neurological defects of cranial nerves 2, 3, 4, and 6. 
Patient: Yeah, my eyes were in really bad shape. I couldn't see anything and my eyelids wouldn't move properly.
Doctor: I understand. Your laboratory tests and vital signs at that time showed a fast blood sugar of 302 mg/dL, a white blood cell count of 9460/µl, a red blood cell count of 3.53×106/µl, platelets of 60×103/µl, hemoglobin of 8.9 g/dl, blood urea nitrogen of 35 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 2.3 mg/dl, potassium of 2.1 mg/dL, a body temperature of 38°C, blood pressure of 120/70 mm/Hg, a pulse rate of 80/min, and a respiratory rate of 14/min. 
Patient: That sounds about right. I remember feeling really sick during that time.
Doctor: Given your medical history and the results of your examination, it's important to continue managing your ulcerative colitis and diabetes. You should continue taking your medications as prescribed and monitor your blood sugar levels closely. It's also crucial to follow up with your healthcare team for regular check-ups to ensure your conditions are well-managed.
Patient: Okay, Doc. I'll make sure to keep up with my medications and follow-ups. Thank you for going over everything with me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns or notice any changes in your health, don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare team. We're here to help. Take care.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Sure, Doc
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reported intense intestinal bleeding following the Islamic fasting month, Ramadan. He has a history of ulcerative colitis, steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, deep vein thrombosis in the left thigh, ecchymotic skin lesions, swelling in the left nose, ptosis, and facial nerve palsy. The patient experienced side effects from prednisolone, including elevated blood sugar levels requiring insulin therapy.

Objective.Observations: The patient was previously on azathioprine 50 mg/day and high-dose prednisolone 60 mg/day. Objective findings included progressive periorbital ecchymosis, extensive edema of the nasal area, nasal ulcer, proptosis, Marcus Gunn pupil, no light perception, absolute blindness, ophthalmoplegia, and neurological defects of cranial nerves 2, 3, 4, and 6. Laboratory tests showed a fast blood sugar of 302 mg/dL, WBC 9460/µl, RBC 3.53×10^6/µl, platelets 60×10^3/µl, hemoglobin 8.9 g/dl, BUN 35 mg/dL, serum creatinine 2.3 mg/dl, potassium 2.1 mg/dL, body temperature 38°C, blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, pulse rate 80/min, and respiratory rate 14/min.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis includes exacerbated ulcerative colitis post-fasting, poorly controlled steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, and complications including deep vein thrombosis and severe ocular and cranial nerve involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of immunosuppression-related complications.

Plan.Treatment: Continue management of ulcerative colitis and diabetes mellitus with current medications. Monitor blood sugar levels closely due to steroid therapy. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are crucial for managing complex multi-system involvement. Patient education on recognizing symptoms of worsening conditions and the importance of adherence to prescribed therapy is essential. Referral to an endocrinologist for diabetes management and a neurologist for cranial nerve assessment may be beneficial.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I heard you're referred here due to constant pain in your right proximal thigh that has been progressing for 8 years. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, it's been really painful, and it's affecting my daily life.
Doctor: Do you have any other known medical conditions or family history of sclerosing bone diseases?
Patient: No, I don't have any other conditions, and there's no family history of bone diseases.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about when the limb pain is aggravated and what helps to alleviate it?
Patient: The pain usually gets worse at night, but it's moderately relieved during physical activities and cold baths.
Doctor: Have you been taking any medication for the pain?
Patient: Yes, I'm on daily analgesic medication with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, paracetamol, and weak opioid agonists.
Doctor: I understand you're on sick leave from your university studies due to these symptoms. Are you also experiencing a leg length discrepancy?
Patient: Yes, I have been using shoe inserts because of the difference in leg length.
Doctor: I also read that you consulted a rheumatologist at age 11 due to hip joint pain. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: They did a hip joint puncture guided by ultrasound because of fluid gathering. But the serology was negative, and the joint pain stopped after the puncture.
Doctor: Were there any incidents prior to your referral to our clinic that may have impacted your condition?
Patient: About six months ago, I was hit by a car at knee level in a traffic accident. I was discharged from the ER without a suspected fracture, and they didn't do a radiological examination. My femoral pain worsened after the accident.
Doctor: During the clinical examination, we didn't find any skin lesions, café au lait spots, or redness. We also didn't notice any increased temperature or swelling in your right thigh. Your leg length was unequal but within normality. 
Patient: That's good to know.
Doctor: We would like you to keep a daily diary to track your pain on an analog scale from zero to 10, with increasing values representing more intense pain. If your pain exceeds a score of 6, you should take orally administered analgesics. Please reserve a score of 10 for pain that prevents you from falling asleep and doesn't respond well to the medication.
Patient: Okay, I can do that.
Doctor: We've also performed magnetic resonance (MR) and positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) scans. The results show a significant increase in cortical thickness in your right femoral diaphysis, which partially obliterates the medullary cavity.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: We'll discuss your treatment options based on the findings from the scans. In the meantime, continue with your medication and pain diary, and we'll keep monitoring your condition and symptoms.
Patient: Alright, thank you, Doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, it's been really painful, and it's affecting my daily life
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports constant pain in the right proximal thigh, worsening over 8 years, aggravated at night and relieved by physical activity and cold baths. The patient uses daily analgesics including NSAIDs, paracetamol, and weak opioids. There is a history of leg length discrepancy managed with shoe inserts. The patient had a hip joint puncture at age 11 due to seronegative joint effusion. Symptoms worsened following a car accident 6 months ago impacting the knee. No family history of sclerosing bone diseases.

Objective.Physical_Exam: A significant increase in cortical thickness in your right femoral diaphysis
Objective.Observations: Clinical examination showed no skin lesions, café au lait spots, redness, increased temperature, or swelling in the right thigh. Leg length discrepancy noted but within normal limits. MR and PET-CT scans revealed significant cortical thickening in the right femoral diaphysis, partially obliterating the medullary cavity. No radiological examination was performed post-accident when seen in the ER.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis of progressive sclerosing bone disorder, likely affecting the right femur, with differential diagnoses including post-traumatic changes or a chronic osteomyelitis. The worsening of symptoms post-accident and the significant findings on imaging suggest an advanced or aggressive disease process.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current analgesic regimen and maintain a pain diary to monitor severity. Follow up with repeat MR and PET-CT scans in 3 months to assess progression. Referral to an orthopedic specialist for further evaluation and management, including possible biopsy to rule out malignancy or infection. Educate patient on signs of acute exacerbation requiring immediate care. Encourage compliance with pain management and monitoring protocols.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've been admitted with a history of febrile illness, arthralgia, and myalgia. Can you tell me how long you've been experiencing these symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've had these symptoms for about 4 days now.
Doctor: I understand. Your NS1 antigen test came back positive on admission, which indicates that you have dengue. Have you been feeling ill and experiencing any postural dizziness and abdominal pain?
Patient: Yeah, I've felt really ill, and I've been having dizziness and pain in my abdomen.
Doctor: During the examination, we noticed that you were dehydrated and had central cyanosis, which is a bluish coloration in your skin. Your superficial veins were also collapsed. We recorded your supine blood pressure as 90/80 mmHg, but we were unable to measure your standing blood pressure due to your severe postural symptoms.
Patient: Oh, that's not good.
Doctor: Additionally, your capillary refilling time was prolonged, and your respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute. We didn't find any evidence of free fluid in your abdomen and pleura during the clinical examination. Have you had any trouble passing urine recently?
Patient: Yes, I haven't been able to pass urine for the last 12 hours.
Doctor: Based on your symptoms, we have diagnosed you with dengue haemorrhagic fever with decompensated shock. We have started critical phase management and admitted you to the HDU. An ultrasound scan of your abdomen did not show any free fluid in your peritoneal cavity, but you might be in the peak of plasma leaking.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a critical condition. However, we performed a repeat ultrasound scan 12 hours after admission, and it showed a thin rim of free fluid in your hepatorenal pouch. We have resuscitated you with boluses of crystalloids and colloids to help stabilize your condition.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: After the resuscitation, you became hemodynamically stable, and it took about 8 hours for your peripheries to warm up. We have continued fluid management and monitoring, and your symptoms have improved within the last 2 days.
Patient: I'm glad to hear that.
Doctor: Although you went into decompensated shock due to dengue haemorrhagic fever, you had a minimum detectable amount of free fluid in your abdomen during the later phase of leaking. We will continue to monitor your condition and provide the necessary treatment.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all the help.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will do everything we can to help you recover. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, I've had these symptoms for about 4 days now
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a 4-day history of febrile illness, arthralgia, and myalgia. Recently, the patient has experienced severe illness, postural dizziness, and abdominal pain. The patient also mentioned an inability to pass urine for the last 12 hours.

Objective.Observations: On admission, the patient tested positive for the NS1 antigen, indicating dengue. Examination revealed dehydration, central cyanosis, collapsed superficial veins, and a supine blood pressure of 90/80 mmHg. The patient's capillary refilling time was prolonged, and respiratory rate was elevated at 24 breaths per minute. No free fluid was initially detected in the abdomen and pleura. However, a repeat ultrasound showed a thin rim of free fluid in the hepatorenal pouch. The patient was hemodynamically stabilized after resuscitation with boluses of crystalloids and colloids.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is dengue hemorrhagic fever with decompensated shock. The patient's symptoms and clinical findings, including positive NS1 antigen, hypotension, cyanosis, and oliguria, support this diagnosis. The presence of minimal free fluid on repeat ultrasound suggests the peak phase of plasma leaking.

Plan.Treatment: The patient was admitted to the High Dependency Unit (HDU) for critical phase management, including fluid resuscitation with crystalloids and colloids. Continuous monitoring of hemodynamic status and urine output is ongoing. Further management will focus on supportive care, monitoring for signs of recovery or complications, and adjusting fluid therapy as needed. Education on the nature of the illness and expected recovery process will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 32-year-old patient, gravida 3 para 3, with no history of abortion. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I haven't had my period for about 7 months now, so I came here to the radiodiagnosis department for a routine antenatal ultrasound.
Doctor: Alright, let's start with an obstetric evaluation. Have you had any specific complaints or concerns during this pregnancy?
Patient: No, I've been feeling pretty good overall.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Your general condition is good, with a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg, pulse at 76 beats/min, normal temperature, and a body weight of 49 kg. Your menstrual history indicates a 3-4/28-30-day cycle, which is regular. Our abdominal examination shows that your fundal height of the uterus is 26 weeks. 
Patient: Okay, that's good to know.
Doctor: We also did a blood examination. Your haemoglobin is 11.8 g dl-1, total leukocyte count is 9900 mm-3, and the differential leukocyte count shows neutrophils at 77%, lymphocytes at 18%, monocytes at 2%, eosinophils at 3%, and basophils at 0%. Your total red blood cells count is 5.31 million mm-3, packed cell volume is 36.4%, and platelet count is 2.25 million mm-3. Your blood urea is 14 mg% and serum creatinine is 0.64 mg dl-1.
Patient: Alright, but what does all of that mean?
Doctor: These results indicate that your blood levels are within normal ranges. We also tested for human immunodeficiency virus, venereal disease, and hepatitis B surface antigen, and all were non-reactive. Your blood group is "A" Rh positive, and your bleeding and clotting times were normal. The urinalysis was also normal.
Patient: Oh, that's a relief!
Doctor: Now, let's discuss your ultrasound examination. We found a single live intrauterine foetus in the cephalic position, with a gestational age of 24 weeks. However, based on your last menstrual period, the gestational age should be 31.2 weeks.
Patient: Hmm, that's a bit confusing.
Doctor: Yes, it can be. The foetal movements and cardiac pulsations were present, which is a good sign. The amniotic fluid was normal, and the placental position was fundal and posterior with maturation grade 0. The estimated foetal body weight is 649 g, which is at the 50th percentile.
Patient: So, everything seems fine with the baby?
Doctor: For the most part, yes. However, we did notice one thing. The umbilical cord is a three-vessel cord, but there is an absence of coiling. Colour imaging revealed an uncoiled umbilical cord.
Patient: What does that mean for the baby?
Doctor: An uncoiled umbilical cord can sometimes be associated with certain complications, but it doesn't always lead to problems. We'll continue to monitor the situation closely and keep you informed. For now, there's no immediate cause for concern.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask. We'll see you again for your follow-up appointments. Take care!
Patient: Thank you, doctor. Have a great day!

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 32-year-old female, gravida 3 para 3, presenting with amenorrhea for 7 months. She reports feeling generally good with no specific complaints or concerns during this pregnancy. Her menstrual history is regular with a 3-4/28-30 day cycle.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination shows blood pressure at 120/80 mmHg, pulse 76 beats/min, normal temperature, and body weight of 49 kg. Fundal height corresponds to 26 weeks of gestation. Laboratory results are within normal limits: Hemoglobin 11.8 g/dl, total leukocyte count 9900 mm-3, RBC count 5.31 million mm-3, blood urea 14 mg%, and serum creatinine 0.64 mg/dl. HIV, VDRL, and HBsAg tests are non-reactive. Ultrasound reveals a single live intrauterine fetus in cephalic position at 24 weeks gestation, discrepancy noted with menstrual dating suggesting 31.2 weeks. The umbilical cord is noted to be uncoiled.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with a single intrauterine pregnancy at 24 weeks gestation by ultrasound, with a discrepancy in gestational dating. The uncoiled umbilical cord is noted, which may be associated with potential complications, but currently presents no immediate concern.

Plan.Treatment: Plan includes routine antenatal care with close monitoring of fetal development due to the uncoiled umbilical cord and gestational age discrepancy. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to reassess the fetal condition and maternal health. Patient education regarding signs of potential complications will be provided to ensure timely intervention if needed. Further consultations with a specialist in fetal medicine may be considered if any abnormalities are detected in subsequent follow-ups.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me how you've been feeling lately?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've had obstructive jaundice for 3 years, melena for 5 months, and hematemesis for the past 10 days.
Doctor: I see. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 4 years ago and have been treated with metformin.
Doctor: It's also important for me to know about your lifestyle. Have you been a smoker or alcohol consumer?
Patient: I used to smoke 10 cigarettes a day and drink alcohol for 20 years, but I quit both 3 years ago.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Now, let's talk about your prior medical history. Three years ago, you had an abdominal computed tomography which showed multiple hypodense lesions in your liver and a pancreatic head mass. You underwent cholecystectomy, choledochojejunostomy, and biopsies, revealing chronic cholecystitis with lymphocytic, plasmacytic, and eosinophilic infiltration of the gallbladder, liver, and pancreatic parenchyma. Your physical examination was unremarkable with a height of 165 cm and weight of 50 kg.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your laboratory tests showed hemoglobin levels of 75 g/L, a platelet count of 80 × 10^9/L, albumin levels of 30.0 g/L, and serum potassium levels of 3.20 mmol/L. Your fecal occult blood test was also positive.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: On the day of admission, you developed painless hematemesis of about 2100 mL, which led to hypotension and tachycardia. We resuscitated you with intravenous, blood, and norepinephrine infusions. Your laboratory tests showed hemoglobin levels of 47.5 g/L, platelet count of 38 × 10^9/L, and serum albumin of 25.8 g/L.
Patient: Yeah, that was a rough day.
Doctor: The day after admission, you had hematemesis of about 500 mL. We treated you with somatostatin, terlipressin, and pantoprazole infusion. A Sengstaken-Blakemore tube was placed for hemostasis by compression, and we began tube feeding you hemostatic medicine.
Patient: Oh, I remember that.
Doctor: After 4 days of medical intervention, your gastrointestinal bleeding gradually stopped. We performed an esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which revealed a duodenal ulcer at the A1 stage.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We'll continue to closely monitor your condition and manage your symptoms. It's important to follow up with regular appointments so we can ensure your health is improving. We'll also work on managing your type 2 diabetes and make sure you maintain a healthy lifestyle.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I'll do my best to follow your recommendations and take care of myself.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a history of obstructive jaundice for 3 years, melena for 5 months, and recent hematemesis over the past 10 days. The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 4 years ago, currently managed with metformin. The patient has a history of smoking and alcohol consumption, both ceased 3 years ago. Previous medical interventions include cholecystectomy and choledochojejunostomy, with biopsies indicating chronic cholecystitis and infiltration in the gallbladder, liver, and pancreatic parenchyma.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination was unremarkable. Initial laboratory tests showed hemoglobin 75 g/L, platelet count 80 × 10^9/L, albumin 30.0 g/L, serum potassium 3.20 mmol/L, and a positive fecal occult blood test. On admission, the patient experienced severe hematemesis (2100 mL) leading to hypotension and tachycardia, managed with IV fluids, blood, and norepinephrine. Follow-up tests showed hemoglobin 47.5 g/L, platelet count 38 × 10^9/L, and serum albumin 25.8 g/L. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a duodenal ulcer at the A1 stage.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to a duodenal ulcer, with a history of chronic liver and pancreatic disease. Differential diagnoses include complications from previous surgeries and chronic conditions like type 2 diabetes mellitus affecting overall health. The prognosis depends on the management of the gastrointestinal bleeding and the underlying chronic conditions.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely. Management includes ongoing administration of somatostatin, terlipressin, and pantoprazole to control bleeding. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the ulcer healing and manage diabetes. Dietary adjustments and lifestyle management for diabetes and liver health are recommended. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the duodenal ulcer and a diabetologist for optimized diabetes care are planned. Compliance with medication and lifestyle changes will be crucial for the patient's recovery and long-term health management.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me a bit about your medical history?
Patient: Hi, I had an orthotropic heart transplant in 2001 for non-ischemic cardiomyopathy.
Doctor: Thank you. What brings you here today?
Patient: I've been experiencing intermittent palpitations with lightheadedness for about one hour.
Doctor: I see. Did you have any chest pain, orthopnea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea?
Patient: No, I didn't have any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Alright. Can you describe your baseline activities?
Patient: Sure, I'd say they're consistent with New York Heart Association Class 2.
Doctor: Are you currently on any medications?
Patient: Yes, I've been taking Atorvastatin, Cyclosporine, Finasteride, Levothyroxine, Mirtazapine, Mycophenolate, Omeprazole, Prednisone, Quetiapine, Ranitidine, Tamsulosin, and Zolpidem.
Doctor: Did you recently take any Prednisone?
Patient: Yeah, I completed a 4-day course of Prednisone for a gout flare-up.
Doctor: Do you have any known allergies?
Patient: Yes, I'm allergic to Azithromycin.
Doctor: Do you smoke, use illicit drugs, or drink alcohol?
Patient: No, I don't use any of those substances.
Doctor: Upon arrival, your vitals were as follows: afebrile, heart rate 54 bpm, blood pressure 184/89 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on ambient air. Your physical examination was unremarkable. Your cardiac biomarkers showed a CK of 59 U/L and a troponin of 0.11NG/ML, which is slightly elevated. Your B type natriuretic peptide was also elevated at 371 PG/ML. 
Patient: Hmm, what do those numbers mean?
Doctor: It means there might be some issues with your heart. Your lab results showed normal sodium, magnesium, serum creatinine, and hemoglobin levels, but your potassium was a bit low at 3.3 mmol/L. We also performed an electrocardiogram, which revealed a normal sinus rhythm with T wave inversions in the anterior and lateral leads, but this was unchanged compared to your prior ECG.
Patient: What about the cardiac monitoring and echocardiogram?
Doctor: Your cardiac monitoring showed no evidence of arrhythmias. The transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55–65%, a left posterior wall of 1.3 cm and an interventricular septal wall of 1.2 cm, with a thickened trabeculated apex.
Patient: So, what does all of this mean for me, doc?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, we need to keep an eye on your heart health and potassium levels. I will adjust your medications accordingly and recommend regular follow-up appointments to monitor your condition. It's important to report any new symptoms or changes in your health promptly.
Patient: Alright, thank you for your help, doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I had an orthotropic heart transplant in 2001 for non-ischemic cardiomyopathy
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Patient, a 2001 orthotropic heart transplant recipient for non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, reports experiencing intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness for about one hour. Denies chest pain, orthopnea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Describes baseline activities consistent with NYHA Class 2. Medications include Atorvastatin, Cyclosporine, Finasteride, Levothyroxine, Mirtazapine, Mycophenolate, Omeprazole, Prednisone, Quetiapine, Ranitidine, Tamsulosin, and Zolpidem. Recently completed a 4-day course of Prednisone for a gout flare-up. Allergic to Azithromycin. Denies use of tobacco, illicit drugs, or alcohol.

Objective.Observations: Vitals: afebrile, HR 54 bpm, BP 184/89 mmHg, SpO2 98% on ambient air. Physical exam unremarkable. Lab results: CK 59 U/L, troponin 0.11 ng/mL (slightly elevated), BNP 371 pg/mL (elevated), sodium, magnesium, serum creatinine, and hemoglobin normal, potassium low at 3.3 mmol/L. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with T wave inversions in anterior and lateral leads, unchanged from prior. Cardiac monitoring shows no arrhythmias. Echocardiogram: LVEF 55-65%, left posterior wall 1.3 cm, interventricular septal wall 1.2 cm, thickened trabeculated apex.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Differential diagnosis includes post-transplant cardiac complications potentially related to medication side effects or electrolyte imbalances. The elevated troponin and BNP suggest myocardial stress, though no arrhythmias were detected. The patient's history of heart transplant and current symptoms necessitate close monitoring.

Plan.Treatment: Adjust medications to address the low potassium and monitor potential side effects. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to closely monitor cardiac function and electrolyte levels. Educate patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in health. Ensure compliance with medication regimen and follow-up schedules. Consider consultation with a cardiologist if symptoms persist or worsen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you are a 35-year-old man with a history of gastric cancer for one year. You have been referred to Golestan Hospital in Ahvaz, southwest of Iran in 2015. Can you tell me about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been experiencing vomiting, loss of consciousness, food intolerances, impotence, icterus, and paleness for about a year now.
Doctor: I see. It looks like you underwent chemotherapy with taxotel (50mg), cisplatin (35mg), and flucytosine (500mg) as recommended by your practitioner for four days. And this schedule was repeated 4 times, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Let's review your vital sign and biochemical parameters. Your BP was 100/60 mm/Hg, PR: 110/min, RR= 28 /min, and OT: 38.5C. Your other biochemical parameters were ALT = 166, AST= 250, WBC: 23.80x 10 3, HB: 7.4, PLT: 56x10 3, FBS: 93, Na: 130, K: 5.9, Ca: 8.1, P: 3.9, bilirubin (T): 33.6, bilirubin (D): 30.1, BUN= 149, Cr= 5.3. In your urinalysis, we found PRO 2+, Hb: 3+.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: You were transferred to the ICU due to respiratory distress. After a few days, we found several larvae and pupa stages in your nasal and oral cavity. We removed them using forceps and sent them to the parasitology department for a precise diagnosis. Nasal myiasis was recognized by our infectious department consulting.
Patient: That sounds really serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. We treated you with turpentine, meropenem, vancomycin, and fluconazole for myiasis, pneumonia, and candidiasis infection. However, despite our efforts, the patient died after 5 days.
Patient's family member: Thank you for everything you did for him. What were the final findings?
Doctor: We identified the third stages of larvae based on internal and external morphological characteristics. We examined the anterior and posterior air spiracles removed from the maggots' body microscopically. We also cultured the pupa at room temperature to recognize the adult fly.
Patient's family member: Thank you for the information and your efforts in treating him. We appreciate it.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been experiencing vomiting, loss of consciousness, food intolerances, impotence, icterus, and paleness for about a year now
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 35-year-old male with a history of gastric cancer, reported symptoms including vomiting, loss of consciousness, food intolerances, impotence, icterus, and paleness for about a year. He had undergone chemotherapy with taxotel, cisplatin, and flucytosine.

Objective.Observations: Vital signs showed BP 100/60 mmHg, PR 110/min, RR 28/min, OT 38.5°C. Lab results indicated ALT 166 U/L, AST 250 U/L, WBC 23.80 x 10^3/µL, HB 7.4 g/dL, PLT 56 x 10^3/µL, FBS 93 mg/dL, Na 130 mmol/L, K 5.9 mmol/L, Ca 8.1 mg/dL, P 3.9 mg/dL, total bilirubin 33.6 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 30.1 mg/dL, BUN 149 mg/dL, Cr 5.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed PRO 2+, Hb 3+. Nasal myiasis was diagnosed after finding larvae and pupae in the nasal and oral cavities.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis was nasal myiasis, with secondary complications including pneumonia and candidiasis, in the context of underlying severe gastric cancer and chemotherapy-induced immunosuppression. The prognosis was poor, as indicated by the patient's death despite aggressive treatment.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current management; monitor for progression

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I was requested for an intraoperative consultation during your left colectomy for adenocarcinoma. While performing the surgery, your left upper-mid ureter was resected, leaving a 12cm gap. To spare you from having another enteroenterostomy, we performed an antiperistaltic ureteroappendicoureterostomy. Do you have any symptoms currently?
Patient: No, I don't have any symptoms right now.
Doctor: That's good to hear. We placed a double-J stent during the surgery to ensure proper healing. You were discharged from the hospital on the 17th postoperative day, and we removed the stent on the 53rd postoperative day. Have you noticed any changes in your urinary habits since then?
Patient: No, everything has been normal.
Doctor: Great. We did an intravenous pyelogram on the 82nd postoperative day, which showed obstruction at the proximal anastomosis, but a 99TcDTPA nephrogram showed adequate emptying. After 2 years, you remain asymptomatic, which is excellent news. We've also checked your symmetric renal function, and the glomerular filtration rate for both your left and right kidneys is well within the normal range.
Patient: That's good to know. What were the numbers for my glomerular filtration rate?
Doctor: Your glomerular filtration rate for your left kidney is 36.52 and for your right kidney is 37.16 mL/min/1.73m2.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We also performed a computed tomography scan, which showed mild to moderate left pyeloureterectasis, but with good cortical uptake. The scan also revealed both your left and right urinary tracts, as well as the proximal and distal ureteroappendiceal anastomoses.
Patient: So, what does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that your urinary tracts are functioning well and the surgery was successful. Since you're asymptomatic and your renal function is normal, there's no cause for concern at the moment. Just make sure to come in for regular check-ups so we can monitor your progress.
Patient: Alright, thanks, Doctor. I'll make sure to do that.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No, I don't have any symptoms right now
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient underwent a left colectomy for adenocarcinoma, during which the left upper-mid ureter was resected, resulting in a 12cm gap. An antiperistaltic ureteroappendicoureterostomy was performed to bridge this gap. The patient reports no current symptoms and has had normal urinary habits since the

Objective.Observations: The patient was discharged on the 17th postoperative day and had a double-J stent removed on the 53rd postoperative day. An intravenous pyelogram on the 82nd postoperative day showed obstruction at the proximal anastomosis, but a 99TcDTPA nephrogram indicated adequate emptying. Computed tomography scan revealed mild to moderate left pyeloureterectasis with good cortical uptake and normal appearance of the urinary tracts and anastomoses. Glomerular filtration rates are 36.52 mL/min/1.73m2 for the left kidney and 37.16 mL/min/1.73m2 for the right kidney, both within normal limits.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is successful antiperistaltic ureteroappendicoureterostomy post-left colectomy for adenocarcinoma with incidental left upper-mid ureter resection. The patient remains asymptomatic with adequate renal function and no significant complications from the surgery. Differential diagnosis includes potential long-term complications such as stricture or obstruction at the anastomosis site.

Plan.Treatment: Continue regular follow-up visits to monitor renal function and ensure the integrity of the ureteroappendicoureterostomy. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any changes in urinary habits or symptoms. No immediate changes in medication or diet are necessary at this time. Consider referral to urology for further evaluation if any new symptoms or abnormalities arise in future assessments.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you have a 32-month-old boy born full term at a community hospital in Michigan. His birth weight was 3135 g, which is at the 15.0 percentile. Can you tell me about his prenatal ultrasounds?
Mother: Yes, doctor. His prenatal ultrasounds were normal, and he passed meconium at birth.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Did he have any complications like prolonged neonatal jaundice or dehydration?
Mother: No, he didn't have any complications.
Doctor: I also see that his CF NBS showed serum IRT 139 ng/ml and was negative for the 40 gene mutations panel. But at 1 month of age, he developed a wet cough without any other symptoms. Was he followed by his primary care provider (PCP)?
Mother: Yes, he was followed by his PCP, but no treatment was given at the time.
Doctor: Did his symptoms continue?
Mother: Yes, his symptoms continued on and off until he was 1 year old. That's when I noticed an increased frequency of his productive cough, lack of appetite, and poor weight gain. His weight-for-age percentile ranged from 0.3 to 5.0.
Doctor: How were his stools and sweating?
Mother: His stools were reportedly normal, and he had no excessive sweating.
Doctor: I understand he was referred to an outside asthma/allergy specialist for evaluation of asthma. What treatment was prescribed for him?
Mother: He was prescribed budesonide, but there was no improvement in his symptoms.
Doctor: Did he have any other conditions like pharyngitis or otitis media?
Mother: Yes, he had frequent pharyngitis and otitis media that were treated with oral antibiotics. The antibiotics helped treat the acute infection, but the cough persisted.
Doctor: Was he prescribed any medication for possible gastroesophageal reflux disease?
Mother: Yes, he was prescribed an H2 blocker, but there was no improvement in his symptoms.
Doctor: What happened when he was 30 months old?
Mother: He had a cough and fever for one week, so he was seen by his PCP and treated with amoxicillin.
Doctor: Did his symptoms worsen?
Mother: Yes, they continued to worsen despite oral antibiotics. He even had two episodes of small-volume hemoptysis.
Doctor: I see that he was admitted for community-acquired pneumonia and influenza B. What did the chest X-ray show?
Mother: The chest X-ray showed diffuse ill-defined opacities in the perihilar area and diffuse bronchiectasis.
