Doctor: During his hospitalization, a pediatric pulmonary consult was obtained. They stated that CF was unlikely due to the negative NBS, and no sweat chloride test was recommended. Was a videofluoroscopic swallow study performed?
Mother: Yes, he had a normal videofluoroscopic swallow study.
Doctor: What were the results of his immunodeficiency workup?
Mother: His immunoglobulin levels were elevated, and he had protective vaccine titers.
Doctor: Thank you for providing this information. Based on his history and test results, we will continue to monitor his condition and provide appropriate treatment as needed. Please keep me updated on any changes in his symptoms or health.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: No chief complaint documented
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 32-month-old boy with a history of persistent wet cough starting at 1 month of age, productive cough, lack of appetite, and poor weight gain noted from 1 year of age. His weight-for-age percentile has ranged from 0.3 to 5.0. He has experienced frequent pharyngitis and otitis media, treated with oral antibiotics. Despite treatment for asthma and gastroesophageal reflux disease, his symptoms have persisted. Recently, he presented with cough, fever, and small-volume hemoptysis, and was

Objective.Observations: Birth weight was 3135 g (15th percentile). CF NBS showed serum IRT 139 ng/ml, negative for 40 gene mutations panel. Recent chest X-ray revealed diffuse ill-defined opacities in the perihilar area and diffuse bronchiectasis. Immunoglobulin levels were elevated, and vaccine titers were protective. Normal videofluoroscopic swallow study.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is chronic respiratory symptoms with recent community-acquired pneumonia and diffuse bronchiectasis. Differential diagnoses include cystic fibrosis (despite negative NBS), primary immunodeficiency, and chronic aspiration. The prognosis is cautious given the chronicity and severity of symptoms.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status closely. Maintain current antibiotic regimen for pneumonia and consider further evaluation for chronic respiratory conditions. Referral to a pediatric pulmonologist for further assessment of bronchiectasis and management. Educate the mother on signs of respiratory distress and when to seek immediate care. Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've come to our institution with a history of progressive dysphagia for the past 2 months, but without hoarseness. Can you tell me more about your lifestyle habits?
Patient: Yeah, I've smoked 60 cigarettes a day for 40 years and been a heavy alcohol drinker for the same amount of time. I also have hypertension for the last 9 years and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes a year ago.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Have you had any prior malignant diseases or distant metastases?
Patient: No, I haven't had any such issues.
Doctor: Good to know. Now, during the physical examination, we didn't find any palpable neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes, and your blood count and biochemical analysis showed no significant abnormal values. We conducted an Iohexol swallowing test which revealed a malignant-appearing structure in your inferior-thoracic region. 
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Yes, it is a cause for concern. We also performed an endoscopic assessment and found a lesion of mucosal hyperplasia forming a luminal stenosis, 36 cm from your incisor teeth. It's difficult for the gastroscope to pass through it. The biopsy of the lesion demonstrated an esophageal MEC.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: It means that you have a tumor in your esophagus. We did a computed tomography (CT) scan to assess the tumor further, and it appears to be resectable, as shown in Fig.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: Since you're medically fit for an esophageal resection, we recommend surgery. The surgery will involve an esophagectomy, 2-field lymphadenectomy (upper abdominal and mediastinum), and esophagogastrostomy through the esophageal bed. This will be performed on the tenth day of your hospital admission.
Patient: What did you find after the surgery?
Doctor: The resected esophagectomy specimen contained a fungating tumor measuring 45 and 40 mm in the longitudinal and cross-sectional dimensions. Histopathology showed that most tumor tissue was composed of epidermoid cells arranged in nests. We also identified keratin pearl formation.
Patient: What else did you find?
Doctor: Columnar mucus-secreting cells and intermediate cells in small areas were forming tube-like structures with invasive growth. We confirmed this through hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining. Immunohistochemically, the tumor was found to be positive for p-63 and CK5/6, which identified it as epidermoid.
Patient: I see. What should I do now, doctor?
Doctor: We'll continue to monitor your recovery and provide any necessary follow-up care. It's crucial to keep your hypertension and diabetes under control, and I strongly advise quitting smoking and reducing your alcohol consumption to improve your overall health.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've smoked 60 cigarettes a day for 40 years and been a heavy alcohol drinker for the same amount of time
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 60-cigarette-per-day smoker for 40 years and heavy alcohol consumer, presents with progressive dysphagia over the past 2 months, without hoarseness. He has a history of hypertension for 9 years and type 2 diabetes diagnosed a year ago. He denies any history of malignant diseases or distant metastases.

Objective.Physical_Exam: We didn't find any palpable neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes
Objective.Observations: Physical examination showed no palpable neck or supraclavicular lymph nodes. Blood count and biochemical analysis were within normal limits. An Iohexol swallowing test revealed a malignant-appearing structure in the inferior-thoracic region. Endoscopic assessment identified a lesion of mucosal hyperplasia causing luminal stenosis, 36 cm from the incisor teeth, difficult for the gastroscope to pass. Biopsy confirmed esophageal mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC). CT scan indicated the tumor was resectable. Post-surgical histopathology showed a fungating tumor with epidermoid cells, keratin pearl formation, and areas of columnar mucus-secreting cells forming tube-like structures with invasive growth. Immunohistochemistry was positive for p-63 and CK5/6.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is esophageal mucoepidermoid carcinoma, confirmed by biopsy and supported by imaging and histopathological findings. The tumor was resectable, and surgery was performed successfully. Differential diagnoses, such as other types of esophageal cancer, were considered but ruled out based on biopsy and immunohistochemical findings.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent esophagectomy, 2-field lymphadenectomy, and esophagogastrostomy. Post-operative management will include monitoring recovery and managing hypertension and diabetes. Lifestyle modifications are strongly recommended, including cessation of smoking and reduction of alcohol intake to improve overall health and reduce the risk of recurrence or other health issues. Regular follow-up care is essential to monitor for any signs of recurrence or complications from surgery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you were referred here due to intermittent fever and joint pain. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having fever on and off for a while now, and my joints have been really achy.
Doctor: I see. We've conducted some tests, and the findings show that you have an inflammatory condition. Your C-reactive protein (CRP) is at 12.91 mg/dL, and your ferritin is at 246 ng/mL. Additionally, your soluble IL-2 receptor (sIL2R) level is 1389 U/mL, which is also elevated.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: These results suggest that your body is experiencing inflammation. We also found that your white blood cell (WBC) count is normal at 6,880/μL, but there are 2% lymphoblasts in your blood. You also have moderate thrombocytopenia, with a platelet (PLT) count of 6.4 x 104/μL.
Patient: Hmm, and what about my other tests?
Doctor: Your transaminase levels are normal, but your lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is high at 1315 U/L. The blood coagulation test is also slightly abnormal. We did a bone marrow aspiration, which showed that 56.2% of nucleated cells are lymphoblasts with immature nuclei, high N/C ratio, and positive staining for PAS.
Patient: Okay, so what does all of this mean for me?
Doctor: We performed flow cytometry, which revealed positivities for CD19, CD20, CD22, c-CD79, CD38, CD99, and HLA-DR, and a weak positivity for CD10. Although gene rearrangement, frequently seen in ALL, was not detected, we did find low-hypodiploid with 36 or 37 chromosomes. Based on these findings, you've been diagnosed with B-lymphoblastic lymphoma (BLL) with hypodiploid.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What's the treatment plan?
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. You've been judged to have high-risk ALL, so you'll be scheduled to receive multidrug chemotherapy followed by high-dose chemotherapy with allo-HSCT. The chemotherapy will consist of steroid, Vincristine, anthracyclines, and L-asparagenase.
Patient: Alright, and what happens after the chemotherapy?
Doctor: After the induction chemotherapy, we'll monitor your progress. You attained a complete clinical remission on day 33 after initiation. During intensification courses, minimal residual disease-polymeric chain reaction (MRD-PCR) targeting immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) in bone marrow was not detected, which is a good sign.
Patient: That's good to hear. So, what's next?
Doctor: The next step is for you to undergo allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT). You'll be transferred to our hospital for this procedure.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help you through this process.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been having fever on and off for a while now, and my joints have been really achy
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports intermittent fever and joint pain. He has been experiencing these symptoms for an unspecified duration.

Objective.Observations: The patient's laboratory tests indicate an inflammatory condition with elevated C-reactive protein at 12.91 mg/dL (normal <0.5 mg/dL), ferritin at 246 ng/mL (normal 24-336 ng/mL for males), and soluble IL-2 receptor at 1389 U/mL (normal 223-710 U/mL). White blood cell count is normal at 6,880/μL, but with 2% lymphoblasts present. The patient has moderate thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 6.4 x 10^4/μL (normal 150-450 x 10^3/μL). Lactate dehydrogenase is elevated at 1315 U/L (normal 140-280 U/L), and blood coagulation tests are slightly abnormal. Bone marrow aspiration shows 56.2% lymphoblasts with immature nuclei. Flow cytometry results are positive for several markers indicative of B-lymphoblastic lymphoma, and cytogenetics reveal a low-hypodiploid with 36 or 37 chromosomes.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is high-risk B-lymphoblastic lymphoma (BLL) with hypodiploid. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma or leukemia, but these are less likely given the specific findings.

Plan.Treatment: The treatment plan includes multidrug chemotherapy (steroid, Vincristine, anthracyclines, L-asparagenase) followed by high-dose chemotherapy and allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). The patient achieved complete clinical remission on day 33 post-initiation of therapy. Minimal residual disease-polymeric chain reaction (MRD-PCR) targeting immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) in bone marrow was not detected during intensification courses. The next step is allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT), for which the patient will be transferred to a specialized hospital. Continuous monitoring and supportive care will be essential throughout the treatment process.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I remember you were admitted to our hospital in May 2013 with fever, dyspnea, and impending respiratory failure. How have you been feeling since then?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been doing okay, but I still have some concerns.
Doctor: I see. Let's review your case. At the time of your admission, our physical examination found an enlarged nodular lesion over your right shoulder and several smaller nodular lesions on your abdomen. Have you noticed any changes in these lesions?
Patient: Yes, the lesions seem to have improved a lot since then.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Your complete blood count showed leukocytosis at 19.4 × 109 cells/L with 78% segmented neutrophils, 2% band form, 11% lymphocytes, and 9% monocytes. Your C-reactive protein level was 132.26 mg/L, and serum lactate dehydrogenase level was 392 U/L. High-resolution computed tomography revealed multiple lung opacities and mediastinal, cervical, and bilateral axillary lymphadenopathies.
Patient: Oh, I remember that. It was quite concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it was. We performed a bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, which showed no lymphoma cells. However, we did find lymphoma cells in your lymph node biopsies, which confirmed your ALK+ ALCL diagnosis. The lymphoma cells were positive for CD2, CD3, CD4, CD30, ALK1, Bcl-6, MUM1, and TIA-1, but negative for CD20, CD5, cyclin D1, CD10, TdT, CD8, and PD1.
Patient: That's a lot of medical terms, but I'm glad you found the cause of my symptoms.
Doctor: Indeed. Conventional cytogenetic analysis showed a normal karyotype. Your lymph nodes also displayed a relatively small number of small-to-large hallmark cells with reniform nuclei. Due to the rate small cell ALCL variant morphology resembling classic ALCL, it was initially misdiagnosed as ALK+ ALCL.
Patient: I see. But I remember you mentioned that I achieved complete remission 4 months after the diagnosis?
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. Your treatment involved an initial course of intravenous dexamethasone and cyclophosphamide, along with intrathecal administration of methotrexate, cytarabine, and hydrocortisone. Then, you received 3 alternating cycles of A and B regimens every 3 weeks. Regimen A included dexamethasone, high-dose methotrexate, cytarabine, etoposide, and ifosfamide, while regimen B consisted of dexamethasone, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and high-dose methotrexate.
Patient: Yeah, the treatments were quite intense.
Doctor: Unfortunately, new skin lesions were later noted in your lower back, and ALCL relapse was confirmed by skin biopsy 28 months after the initial treatment. Based on these findings, we may need to discuss further treatment options. How have you been feeling lately? Have you noticed any new symptoms?
Patient: I have been feeling a bit tired, but I haven't noticed any other new symptoms.
Doctor: Thank you for letting me know. We'll keep monitoring your condition and discuss potential treatment options to address the relapse. Please keep me updated on any changes in your symptoms or overall health.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help with this.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, previously

Objective.Observations: In 2013, the patient presented with fever, dyspnea, and respiratory distress. Physical examination revealed an enlarged nodular lesion on the right shoulder and smaller nodular lesions on the abdomen, which have since improved. Initial labs showed leukocytosis (19.4 × 10^9 cells/L), with elevated C-reactive protein (132.26 mg/L) and serum lactate dehydrogenase (392 U/L). High-resolution computed tomography indicated multiple lung opacities and lymphadenopathies. Lymph node biopsies were positive for CD2, CD3, CD4, CD30, ALK1, Bcl-6, MUM1, and TIA-1, confirming ALK+ ALCL. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy were negative for lymphoma cells. Recent findings include new skin lesions on the lower back, indicating a relapse.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a relapse of ALK+ ALCL, evidenced by new skin lesions and biopsy results. The patient's history of achieving remission and subsequent relapse suggests a potentially recurrent pattern of the disease. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma or secondary malignancies, though current evidence strongly supports a relapse of ALCL.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan will focus on addressing the ALCL relapse. This will likely involve a reassessment of chemotherapy options, potentially revisiting or modifying previous successful regimens or considering new targeted therapies. Supportive care to manage symptoms such as fatigue will be important. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and any progression of symptoms. Further imaging and lab tests will be ordered as necessary to monitor the disease's status and treatment effects. The patient will be educated on the signs of disease progression and encouraged to maintain communication about any new symptoms or concerns.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you're experiencing some scrotal swelling on the left side. Can you tell me more about the symptoms and when they started?
Patient: Yeah, it started about 5 days ago during a trip to Japan. I had a few severe sneezes while walking outside and then noticed the swelling.
Doctor: I see. Let me examine the area. Alright, I can see a large swelling of the left hemiscrotum. I recall that you were diagnosed with a left-sided varicocele 6 months ago here in our hospital (Fig.). Do you have any other medical history?
Patient: No, that's the only thing I've had.
Doctor: We've taken some blood samples and the results are negative. We'll also perform a Colour Doppler-Ultrasonography (CDU) to get a better understanding of the swelling.
Patient: Okay, thanks.
Doctor: The CDU results show the known varicocele, a normal vascularized left testis, and a swelling of low echogenicity of 39x29mm without blood flow, which indicates a scrotal bleeding (Fig.). The hematoma is considered self-limiting, and we expect spontaneous resorption.
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what's next?
Doctor: We'll schedule a follow-up ultrasonography in 2 months to monitor the hematoma. 
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: After 2 months, the ultrasonography showed that the swelling had increased in size to 40x40mm (Fig.). We referred you to an academic hospital for further evaluation.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that.
Doctor: They performed a CT-scan of your abdomen which showed a prominent vena spermatica on the left, without suspicion of an arteriovenous malformation. A 3D replica of the CT-scan was made to better illustrate the size of the hematoma (Fig.).
Patient: That's when they decided to do the surgery, right?
Doctor: Yes, three months post-event, as the hematoma further increased in size to 50x37x30mm, you underwent a microscopic inguinal varicocelectomy.
Patient: How has it been healing since the surgery?
Doctor: After the surgery, the hematoma showed signs of reabsorption, decreasing in size to 38x24x21mm 4 months post-event; 20x16x11mm 6 months post-event; and eventually, no residual hematoma 15 months post-event. Your left testis did not differ in size at all follow-up points.
Patient: That's great to hear. Thanks for taking care of me.
Doctor: You're welcome! If you experience any further issues, don't hesitate to reach out.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, it started about 5 days ago during a trip to Japan
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a male with a history of left-sided varicocele, reported experiencing scrotal swelling on the left side that began 5 days ago during a trip to Japan. The onset was associated with severe sneezing. No other medical history was noted.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed a large swelling of the left hemiscrotum. Initial blood tests were negative. Colour Doppler-Ultrasonography (CDU) indicated a known varicocele, a normal vascularized left testis, and a 39x29mm swelling of low echogenicity without blood flow, suggestive of a scrotal hematoma. Follow-up ultrasonography showed an increase in hematoma size to 40x40mm. CT-scan of the abdomen displayed a prominent vena spermatica on the left without arteriovenous malformation. Post-surgical follow-ups showed gradual reabsorption of the hematoma, with no residual hematoma 15 months post-event and no change in testis size.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis was a scrotal hematoma secondary to a known varicocele. The hematoma was initially managed conservatively but required surgical intervention due to increasing size, confirmed by imaging studies. No complications such as arteriovenous malformation were identified.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent microscopic inguinal varicocelectomy three months after the initial event due to increasing hematoma size. Post-operative management included regular follow-up ultrasonography to monitor hematoma reabsorption, which showed progressive decrease in size. The patient was advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further follow-up in a specialized academic hospital was arranged to ensure comprehensive care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you're here for the birth of your baby. You're a 17-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks of gestation. Can you tell me about the care you've received during your pregnancy?
Patient: Hi, doctor. Actually, I haven't attended any check-ups during my pregnancy.
Doctor: I see. Well, let's proceed with a physical examination. 
[After examination]
Doctor: Your examination shows that your cervix is 60% to 70% effaced and 3 cm dilated. The baby is in cephalic presentation, and your amniotic membranes are intact. We also performed a fetal ultrasound, which showed an isolated anechoic hepatic cyst measuring 1.32/1.47 cm.
Patient: Oh! Where exactly is the cyst located?
Doctor: The cyst is situated in the right anterior abdominal compartment between the gallbladder and the umbilical vein. At this time, we're not certain if it's located in the parenchyma or choledocal, but due to its position, we suspect it's a parenchymal cyst (Fig. ).
Patient: Hmm, I see. What about the results from the Color Doppler imaging?
Doctor: The Color Doppler flow imaging did not show any flow in the cystic mass, and it confirmed that the cyst is situated to the right of the umbilical vein (Fig. ).
[After the delivery]
Doctor: Congratulations! You've delivered a healthy female fetus in cephalic presentation. Your baby weighed 2440 g at birth, and she's been diagnosed with low weight for gestational age. Don't worry, we'll keep a close eye on her.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. How were the Apgar scores?
Doctor: The Apgar score was 8 at 1 minute and 10 at 5 minutes. Additionally, the acid/base, co-oximetry, oxygen status, and electrolytes values from the umbilical arterial blood were unremarkable and documented immediately after birth.
Patient: That's a relief. What about the hepatic function panel results?
Doctor: At 36 hours after birth, the hepatic function panel showed a slightly elevated aspartate aminotransferase level of 43 U/L, which is just above the normal limit of 37 U/L. The total bilirubin level was 5.2 mg/dL, corresponding to the low-risk zone at 36 hours after birth, according to the Bhutani nomogram.
Patient: So, what's the next step for my baby?
Doctor: We're referring your newborn to the pediatric surgery unit for further multidisciplinary evaluation. A recent abdominal sonography confirmed the presence of a 1.6/0.93 cm intrahepatic cyst situated to the left of the gallbladder. The specialists will be able to provide more information and guidance on the next steps.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and will follow up with the pediatric surgery unit.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 17-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation, presenting for childbirth. She reports no prenatal care throughout her pregnancy. The patient inquires about the fetal ultrasound findings and expresses concern about the hepatic cyst identified in the fetus.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals the patient's cervix is 60-70% effaced and dilated to 3 cm. Fetal ultrasound shows an isolated anechoic hepatic cyst measuring 1.32/1.47 cm in the right anterior abdominal compartment. Color Doppler flow imaging indicates no flow within the cyst. The patient delivered a healthy female fetus weighing 2440 g, diagnosed with low weight for gestational age. Apgar scores were 8 at 1 minute and 10 at 5 minutes. Umbilical arterial blood analysis was unremarkable. Postnatal hepatic function panel shows slightly elevated aspartate aminotransferase at 43 U/L and total bilirubin at 5.2 mg/dL.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is childbirth at 36 weeks with a healthy female infant showing low weight for gestational age. The differential diagnosis includes considerations for the hepatic cyst in the newborn, which is currently suspected to be a parenchymal cyst. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic, pending further evaluation of the hepatic cyst.

Plan.Treatment: The newborn is referred to the pediatric surgery unit for further evaluation of the hepatic cyst. The mother is advised to follow up with pediatric surgery for her baby's care. Recommendations for the mother's postpartum care include routine monitoring and support, particularly given her lack of prenatal care. Education regarding newborn care and signs of complications will be provided to ensure mother and child wellness.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I assist you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having some issues in my mouth, and I'm looking for some help with that.
Doctor: Of course, can you describe the problem or show me the affected areas?
Patient: Sure, there are multiple lesions on the right side of my mouth, like on my tongue, inserted gingiva, and retro commissural region. They don't really hurt, but they look pretty bad.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. It looks like you have desquamative gingivitis in the inserted gingiva as well. Did you have any dental work done recently?
Patient: Yeah, about two years ago, I had extensive amalgam restorations on teeth 17, 15, 14, and 48.
Doctor: Okay, have you had any issues with your gums or breath recently?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing halitosis and spontaneous gingival bleeding. That's actually my main complaint.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a periodontal examination to better understand the situation. I'll use a periodontal probe to measure the depth of your gingival pockets and check for any bleeding or plaque.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: Your probing depths range from 1 to 7 mm, and in the regions affected by gingival desquamation, the depths are between 2 and 6 mm. Your bleeding index during probing is 91.3%, and your plaque index is 74%.
Patient: That doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Based on these results, I'm diagnosing you with generalized periodontitis. Have you had any issues with hypertension, diabetes, or autoimmune diseases in your medical history?
Patient: No, I haven't had any problems with those.
Doctor: Great. And have you been taking any medications recently?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Okay, we'll also need to do a blood analysis and a perilesional biopsy to better understand the condition of your oral mucosa.
Patient: Sure, go ahead.
Doctor: The biopsy results show that the connective tissue has chronic subepithelial and deep inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of lymphocytes and plasmocytes.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It indicates that there is an ongoing inflammatory process in your oral mucosa. We will need to determine the cause and develop a treatment plan to address it. In the meantime, maintain good oral hygiene and schedule regular dental check-ups.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports multiple lesions on the right side of the mouth, including the tongue, inserted gingiva, and retro commissural region, with no associated pain but noticeable appearance. The patient's main complaints are halitosis and spontaneous gingival bleeding. The patient had extensive amalgam restorations two years ago on teeth 17, 15, 14, and 48. No recent medications or history of hypertension, diabetes, or autoimmune diseases.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals desquamative gingivitis in the inserted gingiva. Periodontal examination shows probing depths ranging from 1 to 7 mm, with affected regions having depths between 2 and 6 mm. The bleeding index during probing is 91.3%, and the plaque index is 74%. Biopsy of the oral lesions shows chronic subepithelial and deep inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of lymphocytes and plasmocytes.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with generalized periodontitis, characterized by extensive gingival inflammation and deep probing depths. The biopsy indicates a chronic inflammatory process in the oral mucosa. Differential diagnoses could include autoimmune conditions affecting the oral mucosa, but further tests are needed to confirm.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes maintaining good oral hygiene and scheduling regular dental check-ups. A blood analysis and further diagnostic tests are planned to explore potential underlying causes of the oral inflammation. Referral to a periodontist for specialized care in managing periodontitis is recommended. Education on the importance of oral hygiene and regular dental visits will be provided to improve compliance and outcomes.
Plan.Follow-Up: Maintain good oral hygiene and schedule regular dental check-ups

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented here for an evaluation before your upcoming ophthalmological surgery. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been experiencing shortness of breath and fatigue lately.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any prior health issues related to your heart?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of coronary stents and heart failure.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Let's proceed with a physical examination first. 
[After the physical examination]
Doctor: Your physical examination appears to be unremarkable. I'd like to perform an echocardiogram to check your heart further.
Patient: Okay, doctor.
[After the echocardiogram]
Doctor: The echocardiogram has reported moderate dilation of your left ventricle, and hypokinesis of the apical lateral wall and apical septal wall. Your ejection fraction is around 35-40%.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: These findings suggest some issues with your heart function. I'd like to evaluate you further with a nuclear stress test.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
[After the nuclear stress test]
Doctor: The stress test results came back abnormal. We need to proceed with an invasive coronary angiography to get a clearer picture of your heart's blood vessels.
Patient: Okay, doctor. I hope that helps.
[After the coronary angiography]
Doctor: The angiography showed a 70% eccentric obstruction of the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, and a 70% obstruction of the left circumflex artery with diffuse calcification. Additionally, your right coronary artery (RCA) appears to be anomalous.
Patient: What's the next step, doctor?
Doctor: I'm going to have our cardiothoracic surgery team evaluate you for a coronary artery bypass graft to address these issues.
[After the coronary artery bypass graft surgery]
Doctor: The surgery went well. We identified an anomalous origin of your RCA from the pulmonary artery, which we successfully reimplanted into the ascending aorta. This should help alleviate your symptoms.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, scheduled for ophthalmological

Objective.Observations: Physical examination was unremarkable. Echocardiogram showed moderate dilation of the left ventricle, hypokinesis of the apical lateral wall and apical septal wall, with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. Nuclear stress test results were abnormal. Coronary angiography revealed a 70% eccentric obstruction of the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, a 70% obstruction of the left circumflex artery with diffuse calcification, and an anomalous right coronary artery (RCA). Post-coronary artery bypass graft surgery, the anomalous RCA was reimplanted into the ascending aorta.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient has significant coronary artery disease with compromised heart function, evidenced by abnormal stress test results and echocardiogram findings. The successful coronary artery bypass graft addressed the critical obstructions and anomalous RCA origin.

Plan.Treatment: Post-operative management includes monitoring for any signs of graft failure or cardiac complications. The patient will be scheduled for follow-up echocardiograms and stress tests to assess cardiac function and graft patency. Cardiac rehabilitation will be initiated to improve cardiovascular health and patient education on lifestyle modifications and medication adherence will be provided to prevent further cardiac issues.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented to our emergency department with complaints of progressive right chest pain for 1 week, preceded by back pain. Can you tell me more about this pain?
Patient: Yes, the pain has been getting worse over the past week. It started in my back and then moved to my right chest.
Doctor: I understand. Do you have any history of hypertension or regular control of your blood pressure?
Patient: I have a history of hypertension, but I haven't been controlling it regularly.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Have you experienced any recent trauma that might be related to this pain?
Patient: No, I haven't had any trauma recently.
Doctor: Alright. Upon examining you, I can see that you're alert, conscious, and your vital signs are stable. Your body temperature is 37.6°C, pulse is 62 beats/min, respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min, and blood pressure is 196/111 mmHg. I also noticed that you mentioned carpentry as your profession. Do you think this could be related to your symptoms?
Patient: Hmm, I'm not sure. I haven't had any accidents at work lately.
Doctor: Okay. During your physical and neurological examination, I didn't find any obvious wounds or vesicle formation, and you seem to be neurologically intact. We ran some laboratory tests and found abnormally elevated D-dimer levels (2.01 mg/dL). Your electrocardiography showed normal sinus rhythm, and chest radiography showed no mediastinal widening or obvious lesion. We also performed a chest computed tomography (CT) to rule out acute cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases, such as aortic dissection and pulmonary embolism.
Patient: So, what did the CT scan show?
Doctor: The CT scan indicated a foreign body in the T4-5 spinal cord and upper back. We consulted a neurosurgeon who suggested an operation. We performed a T4-5 laminectomy and foreign body removal.
Patient: What was the foreign body?
Doctor: It turned out to be a 5 cm-long broken nail stuck to your spinal cord with dural rupture. We removed it and irrigated the site with an antibiotic solution.
Patient: Wow, that's incredible! How did it get there?
Doctor: It's difficult to say for sure, but it could have been related to your profession as a carpenter. Regardless, we've administered prophylactic antibiotics for double protection against the possibility of developing meningitis.
Patient: That's a relief. How is my recovery looking?
Doctor: Your pain resolved immediately after the operation, and no unusual events or neurological sequelae were observed during your follow-up. You should continue to monitor your condition, but it appears that the surgery was successful.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, the pain has been getting worse over the past week
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a carpenter, presented with progressive right chest pain for 1 week, initially preceded by back pain. He reports that the pain has been worsening over the past week. The patient has a history of hypertension, which he admits to not controlling regularly. He denies any recent trauma.

Objective.Physical_Exam: I didn't find any obvious wounds or vesicle formation
Objective.Observations: On examination, the patient was alert and conscious with stable vital signs: body temperature 37.6°C, pulse 62 beats/min, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and elevated blood pressure at 196/111 mmHg. Physical and neurological examinations showed no obvious wounds, vesicle formation, or neurological deficits. Laboratory tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels at 2.01 mg/dL. Electrocardiography indicated normal sinus rhythm, and chest radiography showed no mediastinal widening or lesions. A chest CT scan revealed a foreign body in the T4-5 spinal cord. A T4-5 laminectomy and foreign body removal were performed, identifying and removing a 5 cm-long broken nail with dural rupture.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis was a foreign body (broken nail) in the spinal cord at T4-5, leading to severe pain, likely exacerbated by uncontrolled hypertension. Differential diagnoses such as aortic dissection and pulmonary embolism were considered but ruled out through imaging.

Plan.Treatment: Post-operatively, the patient was administered prophylactic antibiotics to prevent meningitis and monitored for any complications. The surgery was successful with immediate resolution of pain and no postoperative complications. The patient is advised to continue monitoring his blood pressure and manage his hypertension. Follow-up appointments with neurosurgery and cardiology are recommended to assess recovery and manage hypertension. Education on the importance of blood pressure control and potential occupational hazards was provided.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, my son has been having some issues and I wanted to discuss his medical history with you.
Doctor: Sure, please tell me more about his issues and his medical history.
Patient: He is 14-years old and the only child from my first marriage. His younger half-brother through me has learning difficulties, but there's no family history of autism.
Doctor: I see. Tell me more about his pregnancy and delivery.
Patient: The pregnancy was normal, but he was delivered by caesarean section at 39 weeks due to a breech presentation. He weighed 3.54 kg at birth, which is the 65th centile.
Doctor: Did he face any complications after birth?
Patient: Yes, he needed oxygen shortly after delivery, but he wasn't admitted to the Special Care Baby Unit.
Doctor: How has his development been so far?
Patient: He has had global developmental delay. At 4 months, he had no head control. He started sitting at 2 years of age and began walking at 4.5 years. Now, he uses a wheelchair.
Doctor: What about his speech and cognitive abilities?
Patient: He spoke his first words at 7 years old. He has learning difficulties and attends a school for children with special needs.
Doctor: Has he been diagnosed with any conditions?
Patient: He was diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) at 5 years old, before recruitment to a study. He had little eye contact and restricted interests. He has also engaged in self-harm behavior like head banging and biting.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Has he had any other medical issues?
Patient: Yes, he suffered from a fractured forearm and vertebral wedge fractures. He was given a diagnosis of probable primary osteoporosis and has been suffering discomfort in his back and lower limbs.
Doctor: Has he undergone any tests for his osteoporosis?
Patient: DXA scanning was done before starting 3-monthly pamidronate infusions. It showed a reduced Bone Mineral Density (BMD) when adjusted for age and gender of -2.6 at lumbar vertebrae 2-4 and a total body measurement of -2.7.
Doctor: What about his joint health?
Patient: He has joint hypermobility and brittle nails. He was also diagnosed with bilateral femoral proximal anteversion and underwent a derotation osteotomy.
Doctor: Has he had any other physical issues?
Patient: Yes, he has ligamentous laxity and a leg length discrepancy. He also has a small scrotum, incomplete descended testes, left sided choroidal coloboma, and myopia.
Doctor: I understand. On examination, did he show any dysmorphic features?
Patient: No, he was not dysmorphic.
Doctor: Thank you for providing this information. We'll continue to monitor his condition closely and work on a treatment plan to address his various medical needs. Please keep me updated on any changes in his condition or behavior.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, my son has been having some issues and I wanted to discuss his medical history with you
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 14-year-old male with a history of global developmental delay,

Objective.Observations: Birth weight was 3.54 kg at 39 weeks via caesarean section for breech presentation. Developmental milestones were significantly delayed; he started sitting at 2 years and walking at 4.5 years. DXA scan results showed a Bone Mineral Density (BMD) of -2.6 at lumbar vertebrae 2-4 and a total body measurement of -2.7. He has been diagnosed with probable primary osteoporosis and is receiving 3-monthly pamidronate infusions. The patient also has joint hypermobility, bilateral femoral proximal anteversion (treated with derotation osteotomy), ligamentous laxity, leg length discrepancy, small scrotum, incomplete descended testes, left sided choroidal coloboma, and myopia.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is Autism Spectrum Disorder with associated global developmental delays and learning difficulties. Secondary diagnoses include probable primary osteoporosis, joint hypermobility, bilateral femoral proximal anteversion, and various other physical anomalies. The patient's complex medical profile requires ongoing multidisciplinary management.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current treatment with 3-monthly pamidronate infusions for osteoporosis. Monitor bone health closely and reassess the need for adjustments in therapy based on response and side effects. Ensure regular follow-ups with orthopedics for joint and bone-related issues, and with ophthalmology for eye conditions. Maintain specialized educational support and behavioral therapy for ASD and associated cognitive challenges. Encourage family to keep regular appointments and report any new symptoms or behavioral changes. Consider genetic counseling for the family to discuss the implications of his conditions and potential hereditary factors.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, sir. I understand you've been involved in butchering and skinning a cow recently. Can you tell me about the symptoms you've developed?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having some gastrointestinal issues like the other guys who worked on the cow. I've also had some bleeding, like melena.
Doctor: I see. It's important that we admit you to Lady Reading Hospital Peshawar for further evaluation and treatment. We'll need to take a blood specimen for routine investigations and additional testing.
Patient: Okay, what kind of tests are you going to do?
Doctor: We'll be sending your blood sample to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for detection of the Dengue NS-1 antigen, CCHF virus antigen, and genomic RNA. We'll use a real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay to analyze the sample.
Patient: Oh, I see. What will that show?
Doctor: The test will help us confirm whether you have an infection and identify the specific virus causing your symptoms. The CCHF-PCR test results have come back, and they show a positive result.
Patient: So, what does that mean? Do I have an infection?
Doctor: Yes, the positive result confirms that you have an infection. It's important that we start you on a treatment plan immediately to help you recover.
Patient: What kind of treatment will I receive?
Doctor: We'll be treating you with ribavirin and providing supportive treatment to help your body fight the infection.
Patient: Is this treatment effective? Will I be okay?
Doctor: Yes, the treatment is effective. With proper care and treatment, you have a good chance of surviving the infection.
Patient: That's a relief. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll monitor your progress closely and adjust the treatment plan as needed. In the meantime, please let us know if you experience any changes in your symptoms or if you have any concerns.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been having some gastrointestinal issues like the other guys who worked on the cow
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a male involved in butchering and skinning a cow, reports gastrointestinal issues and melena, similar to symptoms experienced by his colleagues. He expresses concern about his condition and seeks clarification on the tests and treatment.

Objective.Physical_Exam: The positive result confirms that you have an infection
Objective.Observations: The patient is scheduled for admission to Lady Reading Hospital Peshawar for further evaluation. Blood specimens are to be sent to the National Institute of Health for testing of Dengue NS-1 antigen, CCHF virus antigen, and genomic RNA using RT-PCR. The CCHF-PCR test results are positive.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF), confirmed by positive RT-PCR results. The presence of gastrointestinal symptoms and melena are consistent with this diagnosis.

Plan.Treatment: Immediate treatment with ribavirin and supportive care is initiated. Continuous monitoring of the patient's condition will be conducted to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or concerns during the treatment process.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you've come in for an evaluation of a pruritic plaque on your sacral region that's been present for a year. Can you tell me more about it?
Patient: Yeah, I started noticing it about a year ago. I had silicone oil injections in that area two years before it appeared. No one in my family has psoriasis.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Upon examination, I see yellowish firm verrucous plaques on the skin of your gluteal cleft. I believe these plaques are a lichenoid granulomatous reaction to the silicone. Have you received any treatments for this?
Patient: Yes, I had four monthly sessions of intralesional triamcinolone acetonide injections, and I also used a high-potency topical corticosteroid called clobetasol ointment once a day for four months. But there was no improvement.
Doctor: I see. I also noticed that the initial plaques have become red and a new 6-mm, erythematous plaque with a silvery scale has developed on your right buttock. The morphology of this new plaque is different than your presenting skin lesions. We need to consider the possibility of squamous cell carcinoma, psoriasis, or lichen planus. I'll perform a dermatoscopic evaluation to get a better understanding.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: Upon dermatoscopic evaluation, the new plaque shows a scaly surface with red globules characteristic of the papillary blood vessels observed in psoriasis.
Patient: So, what does that mean?
Doctor: Six months after your final triamcinolone injection, we'll perform a punch biopsy of the 6-mm plaque to confirm the diagnosis. The microscopic examination of the epidermis demonstrated confluent parakeratosis with neutrophilic microabscesses, regular acanthosis, elongated rete ridges, and a thin or absent granular layer. The upper dermis showed chronic inflammation consisting of lymphocytes, edema, and vascular ectasia with tortuous capillaries. These pathologic findings establish the diagnosis of psoriasis.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Additionally, there were abundant histiocytes with vacuolated cytoplasm throughout the dermis. Stains for bacteria, fungi, and mycobacteria were negative. Correlation of your history and these pathologic findings were diagnostic of a silicone granuloma.
Patient: So, I have both psoriasis and a silicone granuloma?
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. We'll need to discuss treatment options and follow-up requirements for both conditions. It's important to monitor your skin closely and report any changes or new symptoms.
Patient: Okay, thank you for your help, doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I started noticing it about a year ago
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a pruritic plaque on the sacral region, present for one year, following silicone oil injections two years prior. The patient has tried intralesional triamcinolone acetonide injections and clobetasol ointment without improvement. No family history of psoriasis.

Objective.Observations: Examination reveals yellowish firm verrucous plaques in the gluteal cleft, suggestive of a lichenoid granulomatous reaction to silicone. A new 6-mm erythematous plaque with a silvery scale on the right buttock shows dermatoscopic features characteristic of psoriasis. Punch biopsy confirms psoriasis with pathologic findings of confluent parakeratosis, neutrophilic microabscesses, regular acanthosis, elongated rete ridges, and chronic inflammation in the upper dermis. Histopathology also indicates a silicone granuloma with abundant histiocytes and vacuolated cytoplasm in the dermis. Stains for bacteria, fungi, and mycobacteria are negative.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Dual diagnosis of psoriasis and silicone granuloma. The psoriasis is confirmed by biopsy and dermatoscopic evaluation. The silicone granuloma is diagnosed based on the patient's history of silicone injections and histopathological findings.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to manage both psoriasis and silicone granuloma. Continue monitoring the skin lesions closely and report any new changes or symptoms. Discuss treatment options for both conditions, including the possibility of systemic therapies for psoriasis and options for managing silicone granuloma. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the conditions and the effectiveness of any new treatments. Educate the patient on the importance of skin care and monitoring for complications.
Plan.Follow-Up: Six months after your final triamcinolone injection

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Well, I've been experiencing progressive worsening of my mental function, dysphasia, and ataxic gait over the last six months.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your medical history related to these symptoms?
Patient: About five years ago, in August 2012, I was diagnosed with communicating hydrocephalus that was possibly caused by tuberculous meningoencephalitis. I had mental confusion and gait disturbance back then.
Doctor: How did they treat your condition?
Patient: I underwent a ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery at a hospital, and my mental confusion and gait disturbance improved almost immediately. They also treated me with antituberculosis medication for six months after the shunting operation.
Doctor: Did they find any evidence of tuberculosis in your tests?
Patient: No, the results of my CSF study were negative for tuberculosis. However, they made a provisional diagnosis of communicating hydrocephalus caused by tuberculous meningitis based on MRI findings of leptomeningeal enhancement in the basal cisterns.
Doctor: How have you been since the surgery and treatment?
Patient: I returned to work and had been followed-up regularly every six months at that hospital. My physical and mental conditions were stable, and I didn't experience any difficulty in work or daily activities.
Doctor: What happened six months ago that led to the current situation?
Patient: In December 2016, I developed slurred speech and mental confusion with intermittent disorientation to time and place within several days.
Doctor: Did you have any tests done for these new symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I had a CSF analysis and MRI of the brain. The CSF analysis showed a white blood cell count of 9 cells/μL, red blood cell count of 33,000 cell/μL, protein level of 4228 mg/dL, lactic dehydrogenase level of 224 mg/dL, and glucose level of 130 mg/dL. The MRI showed multiple linear and nodular leptomeningeal enhancing lesions scattered in basal and left sylvian cisterns.
Doctor: How did the new MRI findings compare to the previous ones from 2012?
Patient: The extent of leptomeningeal enhancement in the basal cisterns was markedly increased compared to that in the MRI examination done in 2012.
Doctor: Was there any indication of shunt malfunction?
Patient: No, the size of the ventricle was small, indicating that shunt malfunction did not occur.
Doctor: And what about your electroencephalography (EEG) results?
Patient: There was no abnormal spike activity in my EEG except for intermittent slow wave in my left frontocentral area.
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, it seems that there may be an aggravation of tuberculosis meningitis. We will need to discuss further treatment options to manage your condition.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Well, I've been experiencing progressive worsening of my mental function, dysphasia, and ataxic gait over the last six months
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a progressive worsening of mental function, dysphasia, and ataxic gait over the last six months. He has a history of communicating hydrocephalus diagnosed in August 2012, attributed to tuberculous meningoencephalitis, treated with ventriculoperitoneal shunt

Objective.Physical_Exam: Leptomeningeal enhancement in the basal cisterns
Objective.Observations: Current vital signs were not provided. Recent CSF analysis revealed a white blood cell count of 9 cells/μL, red blood cell count of 33,000 cells/μL, protein level of 4228 mg/dL, lactic dehydrogenase level of 224 mg/dL, and glucose level of 130 mg/dL. Recent MRI showed increased leptomeningeal enhancement in the basal and left sylvian cisterns compared to 2012. EEG showed intermittent slow wave activity in the left frontocentral area. No evidence of shunt malfunction was noted as the ventricle size was small.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a suspected aggravation of tuberculous meningitis, evidenced by worsening neurological symptoms and significant changes in MRI and CSF findings. Differential diagnoses could include other infectious or inflammatory conditions affecting the CNS.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan will include a thorough re-evaluation of the patient's antituberculosis treatment regimen and possibly initiating a new course of antituberculosis therapy. Further consultations with a neurologist and an infectious disease specialist are recommended. Patient education regarding the signs of potential shunt complications and the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen will be emphasized. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust as necessary.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 38-year-old unmarried woman, and I've been experiencing pain, redness, and blurring of vision in my left eye for the last 5 days.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any similar issues before or any other health problems?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypothyroidism, recurrent ulceration of breasts, hair loss, nausea, vomiting, and gastric pain. I'm currently on treatment for hypothyroidism, anemia, and esophageal reflux disease.
Doctor: Alright. Have you had any sexual exposure in the past?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Let me examine your eyes first. Please sit still while I check your vision and intraocular pressure.
(After examination)
Doctor: Okay, based on the examination, your best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye is 6/6, N6 and in the left eye is hand movement (HM),< N36. Your intraocular pressure (IOP) is 14 mmHg in the right eye and 16 mmHg in the left eye. The anterior segment examination of your right eye is normal, but your left eye shows keratic precipitates, anterior chamber cells 2+ with flare (SUN—standardization of uveitis nomenclature grading), and iris pigments on the anterior lens capsule.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What does that mean?
Doctor: Your right eye has a hyperemic disc with posterior placoid retinochoroiditis, and your left eye has dense vitritis with a hyperemic disc and punctate yellowish lesions suggestive of superficial retinal precipitates. I would like to advise some investigations to confirm the diagnosis.
Patient: Hmm, I actually did some investigations a month ago when I was diagnosed elsewhere as having viral retinitis. My white blood cell (WBC) count was decreased to 3980 mm3, and my erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was raised to 35 mm/h. The Mantoux test showed 0 mm induration after 72 hours.
Doctor: I see. Were you prescribed any medication?
Patient: Yes, I was started on oral valacyclovir 1 g three times a day, topical prednisolone acetate 1%, and oral corticosteroids 1 mg/kg weight. I've been using them for the last 2 weeks.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. You mentioned that you were lost to follow-up for a month. Have you noticed any changes in your vision since then?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing blurring of vision in my right eye for the last week and ocular pain in both eyes.
Doctor: After reexamining your eyes, I can see that the BCVA in your right eye is now 6/36. It's important to follow up closely with your treatment and to keep your appointments to monitor your progress. I will adjust your medications as needed based on your symptoms and response to treatment.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor. I'll make sure to follow up and keep my appointments.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any concerns or if your symptoms worsen. Take care.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I'm a 38-year-old unmarried woman, and I've been experiencing pain, redness, and blurring of vision in my left eye for the last 5 days
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 38-year-old unmarried woman presenting with pain, redness, and blurring of vision in her left eye for the past 5 days. She reports a medical history of hypothyroidism, recurrent breast ulceration, hair loss, nausea, vomiting, and gastric pain. She is currently on treatment for hypothyroidism, anemia, and esophageal reflux disease. She denies any sexual exposure. She was previously

Objective.Observations: Examination reveals BCVA of 6/6, N6 in the right eye and hand movement, <N36 in the left eye. IOP is 14 mmHg in the right eye and 16 mmHg in the left eye. Anterior segment examination shows normal findings in the right eye, but keratic precipitates, anterior chamber cells 2+ with flare, and iris pigments on the anterior lens capsule in the left eye. The right eye shows a hyperemic disc with posterior placoid retinochoroiditis, and the left eye shows dense vitritis with a hyperemic disc and punctate yellowish lesions suggestive of superficial retinal precipitates. Previous lab results showed a decreased WBC count of 3980 mm3 and an elevated ESR of 35 mm/h. The Mantoux test was negative with 0 mm induration after 72 hours.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is viral retinitis with complications including dense vitritis and posterior placoid retinochoroiditis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of uveitis or infectious retinitis. The prognosis depends on timely and effective management of the infection and inflammation.

Plan.Treatment: Continue oral valacyclovir 1 g three times a day and adjust dosages of topical prednisolone acetate 1% and oral corticosteroids 1 mg/kg weight as needed based on symptoms and response to treatment. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust treatment accordingly. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the medication regimen and keeping follow-up appointments. Consider referral to an ophthalmologist specializing in retinal diseases for further evaluation and management. Monitor for any worsening of symptoms and advise the patient to report any changes immediately.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I understand you were admitted to our specialized lung clinic for further treatment of ARDS due to influenza A pneumonia. Can you tell me about the symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been struggling with shortness of breath and coughing a lot. It's been really tough.
Doctor: I see. We've reviewed your records and it seems you're a healthy 60-year-old male with no comorbidities and you've never smoked, which is good. Due to your severe hypoxemic respiratory failure, endotracheal intubation was already performed prior to your admission here.
Patient: Yes, that's right. They did that to help me breathe better.
Doctor: After your admission, we took a chest X-ray and found an apical left-sided pneumothorax of approximately 2 cm, accompanied by a large subcutaneous emphysema. To treat this, we inserted two chest tubes, one on each side. After that, your left lung was fully expanded again, the subcutaneous emphysema resolved, and no air leak could be observed.
Patient: Oh, that sounds good. I'm glad the tubes helped.
Doctor: Unfortunately, on day 14, you developed a massive and progressive subcutaneous emphysema again, accompanied by a large air leak of about 5000 ml per minute on the left side. We had to insert a second and a third chest tube on the left, one in Monaldi's position (3rd intercostal space mid-clavicular) and the other in Bülau's position (5th intercostal space slightly anterior to the mid-axillary line).
Patient: That's quite a lot. I didn't realize it was so serious.
Doctor: Yes, it's quite concerning. On day 16, a chest X-ray and chest CT-scan showed a complete left-sided pneumothorax. A central venous catheter was placed on the left internal jugular vein, six days before the onset of the air leak. We believe that the air leak, pneumothorax, and subcutaneous emphysema are a result of barotrauma due to invasive mechanical ventilation.
Patient: I see. What are the next steps, then?
Doctor: Due to progressive hypercapnia and severe respiratory acidosis, we performed a tracheostomy and established a vvECMO (PLS Set and ROTAFLOW Console) on day 16, using an Avalon Elite™ Bi-Caval Dual Lumen Catheter. Blood gas analysis before the start of the extracorporeal lung assistance showed a PaCO2 of 88 mmHg with a pH of 7.30, and PaO2 of 90 mmHg.
Patient: I'm not familiar with all those terms, but I trust you're doing what's best for me.
Doctor: We're doing everything we can to help you recover. The tracheostomy and vvECMO will provide the necessary support for your lungs while they heal. We'll closely monitor your condition and adjust the treatment as needed. It's important that you continue to rest and follow our instructions to ensure the best possible recovery.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I really appreciate your help and expertise.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 60-year-old male with no comorbidities and no history of smoking, presents with symptoms of shortness of breath and coughing, which he describes as severe. He was

Objective.Observations: Upon admission, a chest X-ray revealed a left-sided apical pneumothorax of approximately 2 cm and significant subcutaneous emphysema. Initial treatment with bilateral chest tubes resulted in resolution of the pneumothorax and emphysema. However, on day 14, the patient developed massive subcutaneous emphysema and a large air leak (5000 ml/min) necessitating additional chest tubes. Subsequent imaging confirmed a complete left-sided pneumothorax. Blood gas analysis before vvECMO showed a PaCO2 of 88 mmHg, pH of 7.30, and PaO2 of 90 mmHg. A tracheostomy and vvECMO were established on day 16.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is ARDS secondary to influenza A pneumonia, complicated by barotrauma from mechanical ventilation resulting in recurrent pneumothorax, massive subcutaneous emphysema, and severe respiratory acidosis. The differential diagnosis would include other causes of severe respiratory distress and complications related to mechanical ventilation.

Plan.Treatment: The patient is currently on vvECMO with a tracheostomy in place to manage respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring of respiratory and hemodynamic parameters is essential. The treatment plan includes strict bed rest, ongoing assessment of lung function, and adjustment of mechanical ventilation settings to minimize further barotrauma. Regular blood gas analyses are scheduled to monitor the effectiveness of vvECMO. The patient will receive education on the procedures and equipment being used to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how have you been feeling since your extended right hepatectomy and bile duct resection with choledochojejunostomy for hilar cholangiocarcinoma?
Patient: Well, I've been experiencing some discomfort and pain lately.
Doctor: I see. After the operation, you had relapsing cholangitis due to anastomotic benign stenosis. We tried biliary stenting with PS, but it didn't improve the stenosis. That's why we decided to perform EUS-HGS with MS. Can you tell me about any symptoms you've experienced since then?
Patient: Yeah, I had cholangitis once about nine months after the EUS-HGS.
Doctor: That's correct. At that time, we found it was due to debris and granulation. We performed balloon sweeping to clear the debris and placed a PS into the MS. How have you been feeling since then?
Patient: I've been feeling better, but still have some occasional discomfort.
Doctor: I understand. Twelve months after the EUS-HGS, we replaced the PS with an MS. Since then, your hepatobiliary enzymes have normalized, and cholangitis has not recurred in 11 months. Now, let's talk about the EUS-HGS procedure. We punctured the B3 duct with a 19-G needle, which is called Expect from Boston Scientific. After that, we introduced a 0.025-inch guidewire, known as Radifocus, into the jejunum. Do you recall any discomfort or pain during the procedure?
Patient: I remember feeling some pressure, but it wasn't too painful.
Doctor: That's good to hear. We then dilated the puncture site with a 6-Fr diathermic dilation catheter, called Cysto-Gastro-Set from ENDO-FLEX. We changed the wire to another 0.035-inch wire, known as THSF from Cook Medical, and placed an 8 mm covered MS. Throughout the entire procedure, there were no adverse events. 
Patient: I'm glad to hear that everything went smoothly.
Doctor: Yes, it's good news. Now, it's important to monitor your condition and follow up with us as needed. If you experience any symptoms or have concerns, please don't hesitate to contact us. In the meantime, continue taking care of yourself and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all the help and information.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care and let us know if you need anything.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Well, I've been experiencing some discomfort and pain lately
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports discomfort and pain post-extended right hepatectomy and bile duct resection with choledochojejunostomy for hilar cholangiocarcinoma. He experienced cholangitis nine months after EUS-HGS, attributed to debris and granulation, and has occasional discomfort despite interventions.

Objective.Observations: The patient underwent EUS-HGS with metal stent (MS) placement after failed biliary stenting with plastic stent (PS) for anastomotic benign stenosis. Hepatobiliary enzymes have normalized, and no recurrence of cholangitis has been noted in the last 11 months. During the EUS-HGS, a 19-G needle was used for duct puncture, followed by guidewire and stent placement, with no adverse events reported.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is hilar cholangiocarcinoma post-surgery with subsequent anastomotic benign stenosis leading to cholangitis. The patient has responded well to the latest intervention (EUS-HGS with MS placement), with normalization of hepatobiliary enzymes and no recent episodes of cholangitis.

Plan.Treatment: Continue monitoring hepatobiliary function and symptoms of cholangitis. Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy lifestyle and provide education on recognizing symptoms of potential complications. Schedule regular follow-ups to monitor the stent and overall hepatic function. Ensure the patient understands when and how to seek help for any new or worsening symptoms.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. What brings you to the emergency ward today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been having abdominal distention, vomiting, and constipation for three days now.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let's proceed with an examination. On initial assessment, you seem dehydrated, but your vital signs are stable. Your abdomen is distended with general guarding and rigidity, and I'm not hearing any bowel sounds.
Patient: Yeah, it's been quite uncomfortable.
Doctor: I'll perform a rectal examination to check for any issues. The rectum appears empty with minimal fecal staining and no palpable mass lesion. After initial resuscitation, we'll do some imaging studies, including an ultrasound of the abdomen and a chest X-ray, to determine the cause of your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: The chest X-ray showed air under your diaphragm, and the abdominal X-ray showed a few air-fluid levels. The ultrasound revealed distended bowel loops with significant free fluid in your peritoneal cavity. Based on these findings, we've diagnosed you with a hollow viscus perforation and peritonitis.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious.
Doctor: It is a serious condition, but we will manage it promptly. We've conducted routine blood investigations and blood cultures. Your renal parameters indicate pre-renal failure, so we'll start you on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to your high leukocyte counts.
Patient: I see. What's the next step?
Doctor: We'll perform an emergency laparotomy to address the perforation and peritonitis. Intraoperatively, we found approximately 500 mL of fecal-contaminated peritoneal fluid which we cleared. There was a 1 x 1 cm2 rent in your rectosigmoid junction, and bowel wall thickening was present at that location. Distal to the perforation, your rectum was found to be collapsed. Fortunately, no pelvic deposits or growths were found.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: We performed a primary closure of the rent in two layers and thoroughly washed the peritoneal cavity. Afterward, a diverting transverse colostomy was done for manual bowel decompression. You'll need intensive postoperative care for a week to recover.
Patient: I understand.
Doctor: We'll start you on oral fluids on the tenth postoperative day. You'll be discharged after three weeks of hospital stay. During this time, we'll closely monitor your progress, and a colostomy closure will be scheduled six weeks after the primary surgery.
Patient: Thank you, doctor, for taking care of me and explaining everything so clearly. I appreciate it.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to help you recover. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports experiencing abdominal distention, vomiting, and constipation for three days. He describes significant discomfort associated with these symptoms.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals dehydration, stable vital signs, abdominal distention with general guarding and rigidity, and absent bowel sounds. Rectal examination shows an empty rectum with minimal fecal staining and no palpable masses. Imaging studies, including a chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound, indicate air under the diaphragm, air-fluid levels, distended bowel loops, and significant free fluid in the peritoneal cavity. Blood tests show high leukocyte counts and pre-renal failure. Intraoperative findings include 500 mL of fecal-contaminated peritoneal fluid, a 1 x 1 cm2 rent at the rectosigmoid junction, and bowel wall thickening.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is hollow viscus perforation with secondary peritonitis. The patient's symptoms, imaging findings, and intraoperative discoveries support this diagnosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdomen such as appendicitis or diverticulitis, but these were ruled out based on imaging and surgical findings.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent emergency laparotomy with primary closure of the intestinal rent and a diverting transverse colostomy. Postoperatively, the patient will receive broad-spectrum antibiotics and intensive care monitoring. Oral fluids will be reintroduced on the tenth postoperative day, and the patient is expected to stay in the hospital for three weeks. A colostomy closure is scheduled six weeks post-surgery. The patient will be closely monitored for signs of infection, renal function, and recovery progress during his hospital stay.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've had this slowly growing swelling and a dull aching pain in the right side of my face for the past two years.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any past history of trauma, surgery, or infection in the area where you're experiencing the swelling?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of that.
Doctor: Alright, let me examine the area. Hmm, I can feel a non-tender, cystic swelling of about 5x5 cm in your right parotid region, causing your earlobe to lift. Does the swelling become more prominent when you clench your teeth?
Patient: Yes, it does.
Doctor: I also notice that the swelling is not fixed to the skin or any underlying structures. Let me check your oropharyngeal and facial nerves... There seem to be no abnormalities. There is also no cervical lymphadenopathy. Let's run some routine blood tests and perform an ultrasonography (USG) of the parotid gland to get a better understanding of what's going on.
Patient: Okay, sounds good.
(After the tests)
Doctor: Your blood tests came back within normal limits. The ultrasonography revealed a cystic lesion measuring 5x6 cm involving the superficial lobe of your right parotid gland. We also performed a fine needle aspiration cytology on the lesion, but the results were inconclusive. I'd like to schedule you for surgery to address the issue.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
(After the surgery)
Doctor: The surgery went well. We discovered that you had a multiloculated cyst arising from the superficial lobe of your right parotid. We were able to excise the cyst in its entirety. You should recover well from the procedure.
Patient: That's good to hear. What did the histopathological examination show?
Doctor: The examination found that the cyst wall had a flattened outlining, with fibrocollagenous and proteinaceous material along with scattered lymphocytes and macrophages. The findings are suggestive of lymphangioma of the parotid gland.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: We'll keep you under medical surveillance for six months to monitor any local recurrence. However, the good news is that, so far, none has occurred.
Patient: That's a relief. Thank you for your help, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns during the surveillance period, please don't hesitate to contact us.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've had this slowly growing swelling and a dull aching pain in the right side of my face for the past two years
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a slowly growing swelling and a dull aching pain on the right side of the face for the past two years. The patient denies any history of trauma,

Objective.Observations: Physical examination reveals a non-tender, cystic swelling approximately 5x5 cm in the right parotid region, elevating the earlobe, not fixed to the skin or underlying structures. No abnormalities in oropharyngeal and facial nerves, and no cervical lymphadenopathy noted. Routine blood tests are within normal limits. Ultrasonography shows a cystic lesion measuring 5x6 cm in the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland. Fine needle aspiration cytology results were inconclusive. Post-surgical findings confirm a multiloculated cyst excised from the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland. Histopathological examination indicates lymphangioma of the parotid gland.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is lymphangioma of the right parotid gland. Differential diagnoses considered included other benign and malignant parotid tumors, but histopathology confirmed lymphangioma. The prognosis is generally good with surgical excision, though surveillance is necessary to monitor for recurrence.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent successful surgical excision of the cyst. Post-operative plan includes medical surveillance for six months to monitor for any local recurrence. The patient is advised to contact the healthcare provider if any concerns arise during the surveillance period. Further consultations with an oncologist or a specialist in head and neck surgery may be considered if recurrence or complications occur.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented with a huge tumor in your lower abdomen. Can you tell me how long you've been experiencing this issue?
Patient: Yes, I noticed it a few months ago, and it's been getting bigger.
Doctor: We performed some imaging findings, including computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging, and discovered a multilocular cyst tumor with a diameter of 27 cm. The tumor is composed of a solid part with hemorrhaging, and it seems that it has caused you to have massive ascites.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds really serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is quite concerning. Additionally, your preoperative serum level of cancer antigen 125 (CA125) is elevated to 237.3 U/ml, which is much higher than the normal range of less than 35.0 U/ml. However, your carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), cancer antigen 19-9 (CA19-9), and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) values are within their respective normal ranges.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: It means that we need to perform a series of surgeries to remove the tumor and affected areas. We will be doing a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral adnexectomy, omentectomy, lymphadenectomy, peritonectomy of vesicouterine excavation, resection of disseminated lesion of Douglas' pouch, and a biopsy of the colonic mesentery without leaving any residual disease behind.
Patient: That's a lot to take in. What happened during the surgery?
Doctor: During the surgery, we found massive hemorrhagic ascites of 4000 ml present in your peritoneal cavity. The ruptured tumor arising from your right ovary was firmly adhered to the sigmoid colon, transverse colon, mesentery of the small intestine, and peritoneum on vesicouterine excavation.
Patient: And how was my recovery after the surgery?
