Doctor: Your postoperative course was uneventful, which is a good sign. Histologically, most of the tumor showed undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, where tumor cells of various forms with strong nuclear atypia grew complicatedly.
Patient: What does the immunohistochemical analysis show?
Doctor: The analysis showed that the sarcomatous component was positive for vimentin, alpha SMA, and CD10, and negative for AE1/AE3, CK7, CK20, desmin, CD31, CD34, AFP, hCG, HMB-45, S-100, and factor VIII. The Ki-67 (MIB-1) index was 60%. The carcinomatous component comprised squamous cell carcinoma, and its immunohistochemical analysis showed positivity for AE1/AE3 and EMA.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me. What should I do now for follow-up care?
Doctor: You will need regular check-ups and monitoring to ensure that there is no recurrence of the tumor. We will also provide you with additional medical care and support as needed. It is important to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow any recommendations provided by your healthcare team.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all your help and guidance.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, I noticed it a few months ago, and it's been getting bigger
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reported noticing a large tumor in the lower abdomen a few months ago, which has been increasing in size. The patient expressed concern about the seriousness of the condition.

Objective.Observations: Imaging studies revealed a 27 cm multilocular cystic tumor with a solid component and hemorrhaging, originating from the right ovary and adhering to surrounding structures. Massive ascites (4000 ml) were noted. Preoperative serum CA125 was elevated at 237.3 U/ml (normal <35.0 U/ml), while CEA, CA19-9, and SCC levels were within normal limits. Postoperative histology indicated undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with strong nuclear atypia. Immunohistochemical analysis showed the sarcomatous component positive for vimentin, alpha SMA, and CD10, and negative for several other markers. The Ki-67 index was 60%. The carcinomatous component was identified as squamous cell carcinoma, positive for AE1/AE3 and EMA.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma of the ovary with a carcinomatous component of squamous cell carcinoma. The prognosis depends on regular monitoring and management of potential recurrence.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent extensive surgical intervention including total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral adnexectomy, omentectomy, lymphadenectomy, peritonectomy, and resection of disseminated lesions with no residual disease left. The postoperative course was uneventful. The patient is advised to have regular follow-ups for monitoring tumor recurrence and to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Additional medical support will be provided as needed.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, what brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing a rapidly-growing neck mass, dyspnea, cyanosis, and I've lost 20 kg in the past year.
Doctor: I see, that sounds concerning. Let's perform some evaluations to better understand your situation. We'll start with a pre-operation evaluation to check your euthyroid status, sTg levels, and Tg-Ab.
[After tests]
Doctor: Your test results show that you have euthyroid status, sTg levels at 7560 ng/mL, and negative Tg-Ab. We'll also need to perform a chest X-ray and CT scan to get a better look at your thyroid and lungs.
[After tests]
Doctor: Your chest X-ray and CT scan reveal huge thyroid nodular goiters, bilateral grouping lymphadenopathy, and diffuse infiltrating nodules with calcification over both lungs. To treat this, we will perform a wide excision of the bilateral thyroid mass with bilateral lymph node dissection.
Patient: Okay, when will the operation be done?
Doctor: The operation will be scheduled for April 25, 2017. During the operation, we documented papillary carcinoma, a solid variant sized 5.3 cm with lymphovascular invasion, extensive extrathyroid extension to adjacent organs and tissues, and perineural invasion. This is classified as T4aN1bM1, stage 4c. The tumor has invaded both recurrent laryngeal nerves, but is negative for BRAF V600E gene mutation.
Patient: What happens after the operation?
Doctor: Unfortunately, respiratory failure ensued after the operation, so we'll need to support you with a respirator. We'll also perform a tracheostomy to preserve a patent airway 3 days later.
Patient: And what about treatment?
Doctor: Since your sTg levels soared up to 36,300 ng/mL and you cannot be weaned off the respirator, we'll start you on lenvatinib 20 mg/d on May 11, 2017. Thankfully, you were able to be weaned off the respirator a week later, with your sTg levels dropping to 10,436 ng/mL.
Patient: That's a relief. What's next?
Doctor: We'll train you for independent care of your tracheostomy T-tube and schedule radioiodine 200 mCi treatment 3 months later. The radioiodine-avid lesion is localized over your neck and bilateral lungs. One month after that, we'll remove the tracheostomy T-tube since your condition has greatly improved.
Patient: How will my sTg levels be?
Doctor: Your sTg levels will remain stationary at around 2553~2982 ng/ml, based on levothyroxin suppression. We'll also maintain a low dose of 5~10 mg/d lenvatinib for continued treatment.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything, doctor. I feel more confident about my treatment plan now.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been experiencing a rapidly-growing neck mass, dyspnea, cyanosis, and I've lost 20 kg in the past year
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a rapidly-growing neck mass, dyspnea, cyanosis, and significant weight loss of 20 kg over the past year.

Objective.Observations: The patient's pre-operative evaluation confirmed euthyroid status with elevated serum thyroglobulin (sTg) levels at 7560 ng/mL (normal range: 1.4-29.2 ng/mL) and negative thyroglobulin antibodies (Tg-Ab). Imaging studies including chest X-ray and CT scan showed large thyroid nodular goiters, bilateral lymphadenopathy, and diffuse infiltrating nodules with calcification in both lungs. Post-operative findings documented a 5.3 cm papillary carcinoma, solid variant with lymphovascular invasion, extensive extrathyroid extension, and perineural invasion, classified as T4aN1bM1, stage 4c. Post-surgery, the patient experienced respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy. Subsequent sTg levels increased to 36,300 ng/mL, but decreased to 10,436 ng/mL after starting lenvatinib 20 mg/d. Current sTg levels are stable at approximately 2553-2982 ng/mL under levothyroxine suppression.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is stage 4c papillary thyroid carcinoma with extensive local and distant spread, complicated by post-operative respiratory failure. Differential diagnoses were considered and ruled out based on imaging and histopathological findings.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes continued administration of lenvatinib at a low dose of 5-10 mg/d to manage carcinoma. The patient underwent radioiodine treatment (200 mCi) and will continue with levothyroxine suppression therapy to maintain sTg levels. The tracheostomy T-tube was removed following improvement in respiratory function. The patient will be trained for independent care of the tracheostomy site and monitored regularly for thyroid function and tumor marker levels. Further consultations with oncology and endocrinology are scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the therapeutic regimen as needed.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. Can you please tell me your symptoms that brought you to the emergency department?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've had a fever and headache for the past 2 days. I've also been having sporadic episodes of projectile vomiting, talking irrelevantly, and feeling really disoriented for a day.
Doctor: I see. We've taken your vitals on admission. Your fever is 39 °C, heart rate is 104 beats per minute, blood pressure is 130/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 30/min, and your blood glucose is 140 mg/dl. Your Glasgow Coma Scale score is 9, with respective scores of 5, 2, and 2 for motor, eye, and verbal responses. There are no signs of meningeal irritation or focal neurological deficit. I noticed a scar on your forehead, near the anterior bi-frontal region. Is that from a surgery?
Patient: Yes, doctor. I had an accidental fall from a two-story building 23 years ago. I had a persistent CSF leak from my nose called rhinorrhea. I underwent a complete repair for the leak without any residual defects.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Your clinical examination was mostly normal, except for that surgical incision. We've conducted a computerized tomography (CT) scan, which showed cystic gliosis changes in your left frontal lobe, communicating with the frontal horn of your ipsilateral lateral ventricle. The CSF analysis revealed hypoglycorrachia, with less than 20 mg/dl of sugar and a corresponding blood sugar of 140 mg/dl. Your protein levels are elevated at more than 300 mg/dl, and you have neutrophil-predominant pleocytosis with total cells of 360/mm3 and 96% polymorphs. These findings suggest acute pyogenic meningitis.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What's the treatment plan, doctor?
Doctor: We've started you empirically on antibiotics and antiviral medication. You'll receive ceftriaxone at 100 mg/kg/day in two divided doses, amoxycillin at 100 mg/kg/day in four divided doses, and acyclovir at 45 mg/kg/day in three divided doses. Your initial peripheral blood WBC count was 14,760 with 85% neutrophils, and your serum lactate levels were 5.35 mmol/l. Your renal and liver function tests were normal. We'll continue to monitor your progress.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the explanation and care.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do everything we can to help you recover. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a 23-year post-traumatic brain injury survivor with a history of CSF rhinorrhea repair, presented with a 2-day history of fever, headache, projectile vomiting, disorientation, and irrelevant speech.

Objective.Observations: On examination, the patient's vital signs showed a fever of 39 °C, tachycardia with a heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 130/60 mmHg, tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 30/min, and elevated blood glucose at 140 mg/dl. Glasgow Coma Scale was 9 (M5E2V2). CT scan revealed cystic gliosis in the left frontal lobe. CSF analysis indicated hypoglycorrachia (<20 mg/dl), elevated protein (>300 mg/dl), and neutrophil-predominant pleocytosis (360/mm3, 96% polymorphs). Peripheral blood WBC was 14,760 with 85% neutrophils, and serum lactate was 5.35 mmol/l. Renal and liver functions were normal.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is acute pyogenic meningitis, likely secondary to the patient's previous neurosurgical history and current radiological and CSF findings. Differential diagnoses could include viral meningitis or other CNS infections, but the predominance of neutrophils and elevated protein levels support a bacterial etiology.

Plan.Treatment: The patient has been started on empirical antibiotic and antiviral therapy, including ceftriaxone (100 mg/kg/day in two divided doses), amoxicillin (100 mg/kg/day in four divided doses), and acyclovir (45 mg/kg/day in three divided doses). Continuous monitoring of vital signs, neurological status, and response to treatment is planned. Further consultations with neurology and infectious disease specialists are recommended to adjust treatment as needed and to manage potential complications. Education regarding the treatment plan and prognosis has been provided, with encouragement for the patient to voice any concerns or questions during recovery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I first noticed my left knee was swollen when I was 10 years old. I've had repeated arthrocentesis since then.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any surgeries or treatments for this issue?
Patient: Yes, I had arthroscopic surgery at age 13 and was diagnosed with benign TGCT. I've also had numerous synovectomies and radiation therapy for my left knee joint when I was 15.
Doctor: It seems like your disease has been quite persistent. Were there any other developments?
Patient: Yeah, my disease spread to my upper calf and posterior thigh. At age 32, my upper calf lesion was resected, and the tumor in my posterior thigh was treated with radiation.
Doctor: Did you notice any other symptoms or changes after that?
Patient: When I was 34, I had swelling in my inguinal lymph node. A fine needle aspiration confirmed malignant TGCT. Other staging scans showed a pelvic mass and a sub-centimeter pulmonary nodule.
Doctor: It appears your disease has become more aggressive. What treatments have you tried since then?
Patient: I received doxorubicin/ifosfamide and then gemcitabine/docetaxel, along with radiation therapy to my pelvis. My disease was stable for three months. Then, I had a left-sided above the knee amputation and excision of the intrapelvic masses.
Doctor: How has your disease progressed since the amputation?
Patient: Eight months later, enlarging pulmonary nodules were resected. I was treated with sirolimus (rapamycin) and remained disease-free for eight months until a pulmonary nodule and two inguinal masses were found.
Doctor: It looks like you were referred to our hospital in 2007. Did you try any other treatments?
Patient: Yeah, I was treated with sorafenib for four months and had a mixed response. Then, I started on sunitinib 37.5 mg daily.
Doctor: How did your disease respond to the sunitinib?
Patient: Interval restaging scans showed no evidence of progressive disease for 15 months.
Doctor: I understand that you had significant progression of a right-sided pelvic mass while temporarily stopping sunitinib in the perioperative setting of resection of painful metastatic nodules near the amputation stump (Fig. a, b, and c). Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. After that, my sunitinib was restarted in combination with sirolimus (rapamycin).
Doctor: How was your disease control with that combination?
Patient: My disease was under good control for eight more months until I had progressive disease in the pelvis and underwent hemipelvectomy.
Doctor: I'm so sorry to hear that. Unfortunately, you passed away at the age of 39, six years after the malignant transformation. Your family has been informed of your journey and they are proud of the fight you put up against this disease.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, who first noticed swelling in the left knee at age 10, has a history of benign and malignant tenosynovial giant cell tumor (TGCT). The patient underwent multiple interventions including arthroscopic

Objective.Physical_Exam: A pelvic mass and a sub-centimeter pulmonary nodule
Objective.Observations: The patient had multiple surgeries including arthroscopic surgery, synovectomies, resections, and amputations. Imaging confirmed the spread of TGCT to various locations including the pelvis and lungs. Fine needle aspiration confirmed malignant transformation of TGCT. Treatments included doxorubicin/ifosfamide, gemcitabine/docetaxel, radiation therapy, sirolimus, sorafenib, and sunitinib. The most recent scans showed no evidence of progressive disease for 15 months on sunitinib, but disease progressed after temporary discontinuation.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is malignant tenosynovial giant cell tumor (TGCT), with a history of benign TGCT. The disease exhibited aggressive behavior with multiple recurrences and metastases despite extensive treatments. Differential diagnoses considered over time included other forms of sarcoma and metastatic cancer, but confirmed by histopathology and clinical course.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan included multimodal therapy with chemotherapy, targeted therapy, radiation, and multiple surgical interventions aimed at disease control and symptom relief. The patient was on a combination of sunitinib and sirolimus at the last follow-up, with plans to continue monitoring disease progression and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on disease process, treatment options, and potential outcomes was provided to the patient and family to support decision-making and coping mechanisms.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 66-year old man with multiple liver lesions involving approximately 70% of your right liver and multiple nodules in the left lobe. You also have right portal thrombosis due to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis. Your CT scan from August 2012 showed these findings (Fig. a, b). Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I also see that you had a positron emission tomography (PET) with 2-(fluorine-18)-fluoro-2-deoxy-d-glucose (FDG-PET) that identified bone metastases in various locations, such as the right femur, right ischial tuberosity, left acetabulum, left scapula, and the third left costal arch. Additionally, a PET with (11)C-choline confirmed the hepatic and skeletal lesions and identified other metastases in the pelvic bones, rachis, and ribs. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what the tests showed.
Doctor: In October 2012, your serum AFP was measured at 1909 ng/mL. Based on the typical contrastographic pattern of the liver lesion by CT scanning and the elevated AFP level, a diagnosis of HCC was made according to European Association for the Study of the Liver (EASL) guidelines. 
Patient: Yeah, that's when I was diagnosed.
Doctor: In December 2012, you started systemic treatment with sorafenib 800 mg/bid. However, ten days later, the treatment was discontinued due to G3 skin toxicity, specifically Stevens–Johnson syndrome. Is that right?
Patient: Yes, I had a really bad reaction to the medication.
Doctor: I see that in January 2013, you then started metronomic capecitabine (500 mg twice daily, continuous administration), which was well-tolerated. How has that been for you?
Patient: It's been much better, I haven't had any issues with it.
Doctor: That's good to hear. In March 2013, a new CT scan showed a reduction in the number and size of the liver lesions with significant intralesional necrotic areas. Subsequent FDG-PET scanning in April 2013 showed the complete absence of pathological areas and, in parallel, your AFP level had fallen to 3.3 ng/mL. 
Patient: Yeah, it seemed like the treatment was working well.
Doctor: In July 2013, a needle biopsy of the principal hepatic lesion showed fibrous connective tissue with histiocytic inflammation but no tumour cells. This is a positive sign. 
Patient: That's great news.
Doctor: Finally, an abdominal US scan in January 2014 revealed the presence of a single hypoechoic lesion measuring 1.4 × 1. Have you experienced any symptoms recently?
Patient: No, I've been feeling pretty good lately.
Doctor: That's excellent. It's important to continue monitoring your condition and following up with your treatment plan. If you notice any changes or new symptoms, please contact your healthcare team immediately. 
Patient: Thank you, I'll make sure to keep an eye on things and stay in touch with my doctors.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's right
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The 66-year-old male patient reports a history of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis leading to right portal thrombosis and multiple liver lesions. He was

Objective.Observations: CT and PET scans from 2012 revealed multiple liver lesions and bone metastases. Serum AFP level in October 2012 was 1909 ng/mL, which decreased to 3.3 ng/mL by April 2013 after treatment. Recent imaging shows a reduction in liver lesions and a single hypoechoic lesion measuring 1.4 × 1 cm. Past severe reaction to sorafenib noted as G3 skin toxicity.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is hepatocellular carcinoma with bone metastases, managed with systemic chemotherapy after intolerance to sorafenib. The significant reduction in AFP levels and liver lesion size, along with the absence of tumor cells in recent biopsy, suggests a positive response to current treatment.

Plan.Treatment: Continue with metronomic capecitabine, maintaining the current dose of 500 mg twice daily. Regular monitoring through imaging and serum AFP levels is recommended to assess the progression or remission of HCC. Immediate reporting of any new symptoms or changes in health status to the healthcare team is advised. Regular follow-ups to monitor liver function and manage any potential complications of HCC or treatment side effects are essential.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you've been experiencing progressive pain in your right hip region for about a year now. Can you tell me more about it?
Patient: Yes, the pain has been getting worse over time and it's really affecting my daily life.
Doctor: I see. We conducted some tests to find out the cause of the pain. The X-ray images showed an osteolytic tumor in the metadiaphysis of your right distal femur with cortical bone destruction on the dorsolateral side. There was no matrix calcification.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: We also performed an MRI, which revealed that the tumor has destroyed the cortex and extended to the surrounding soft tissues. There was strong tumor enhancement after the administration of intravenous gadolinium.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the tumor is growing and affecting the nearby tissues. We performed a resection of your right distal femur to remove the tumor. The tumor measured 12 x 4 cm and on the cut surface, it appeared pale and fibrous, with an extension to surrounding soft tissue.
Patient: What did the histology report say?
Doctor: The tumor histology strongly resembled the desmoplastic fibroma diagnosed in a previous case, but with some differences. It was made up of bundles of moderate cellular tissue, with fibroblast-like, spindle cells in abundant collagenous stroma. However, there was evidence of invasive growth in trabecular bone and surrounding skeletal muscle tissue.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: We conducted a cytogenetic analysis which showed an abnormal karyotype: 47~49,XX,del(13) (q12q32),+ 1~2r,+1~2mar,1dmin [cp17]/46,XX [2]. This indicates an interstitial deletion of the long arm of chromosome 13 (q12q32), consistent with heterozygous loss of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene.
Patient: Is that bad?
Doctor: It's a concern, as the loss of this gene can increase the risk of cancer. With cancer hotspot NGS analysis, we found amplification of CDK4 (NM_000075.3) and an imbalance of the RB1 gene on chromosome 13.
Patient: What does that mean for my treatment?
Doctor: The IHC results showed that tumor cells exhibited strong nuclear staining for CDK4 and moderate nuclear staining for SATB2. RB1 expression was heterogeneous, not completely lost. This information will help us determine the most appropriate treatment plan for you, which may include further surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll do whatever it takes to get better.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will work closely with you to ensure the best possible outcome. Please do not hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, the pain has been getting worse over time and it's really affecting my daily life
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports progressive pain in the right hip region for about a year, worsening over time and significantly impacting daily activities.

Objective.Observations: X-ray and MRI findings indicate an osteolytic tumor in the metadiaphysis of the right distal femur with cortical bone destruction and extension to surrounding soft tissues. The tumor measures 12 x 4 cm, appears pale and fibrous, and shows strong enhancement post-intravenous gadolinium. Histology suggests a desmoplastic fibroma-like tumor with invasive growth into trabecular bone and skeletal muscle. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an abnormal karyotype with interstitial deletion on chromosome 13, consistent with heterozygous loss of the RB1 gene. Cancer hotspot NGS analysis shows CDK4 amplification and RB1 imbalance. IHC results indicate strong nuclear staining for CDK4 and moderate for SATB2, with heterogeneous RB1 expression.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is a malignant tumor of the right distal femur, likely a desmoplastic fibroma with aggressive features and genetic anomalies suggesting higher cancer risk. Differential diagnoses could include other primary bone tumors with similar histological features.

Plan.Treatment: The management plan includes post-operative monitoring and consideration of additional surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy based on ongoing evaluations. Referral to oncology for specialized cancer treatment and genetic counseling is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis, treatment options, and potential outcomes is crucial for informed consent and compliance. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor treatment response and manage any complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, Mrs. Johnson. I see that you were diagnosed with VMT in your right eye back in September 2015. Can you tell me what symptoms you were experiencing at that time?
Patient: Yes, doctor. I was having blurry vision and some distortion in my right eye.
Doctor: I see. According to your medical records (Fig. a), at your first presentation, your BCVA, or best-corrected visual acuity, was 0.5. Additionally, your right eye showed a macula pucker. The foveal thickness was 603 μm, and the adhesion diameter was 69 μm. After 47 days without any spontaneous resolution, your surgeon performed an intravitreal injection of 0.2 ml of 100% C3F8. How did you feel after the injection?
Patient: Hmm, I didn't notice any immediate changes in my vision, but I did feel some relief after the injection.
Doctor: That's good to hear. After 5 weeks, the OCT results (Fig. b) showed a separation of the vitreous from the macula in your right eye, which is a positive sign. However, it seems like your BCVA did not change. How do you feel about your vision now?
Patient: Well, it still feels the same, doctor. I haven't noticed any significant improvement.
Doctor: I understand. Although your BCVA didn't change, the foveal thickness in your right eye decreased to 270 μm, which is a positive development. This means that the injection was effective in reducing the thickness of the fovea, but it may take some time for your vision to improve.
Patient: Oh, I see. So, is there anything I need to do or follow up on, doctor?
Doctor: At this point, I would recommend regular check-ups to monitor your eye condition and ensure that there are no further complications. Additionally, if you notice any changes in your vision or experience any discomfort, please contact us immediately.
Patient: Okay, doctor. I'll be sure to do that. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome, Mrs. Johnson. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any concerns, and take care of yourself.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: Mrs. Johnson reports experiencing blurry vision and distortion in her right eye since September 2015, diagnosed as vitreomacular traction (VMT). She notes no significant improvement in vision following treatment but mentions feeling some relief after the intervention.

Objective.Physical_Exam: The foveal thickness in your right eye decreased to 270 μm
Objective.Observations: Initial examination revealed a best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 0.5 in the right eye, with macular pucker and foveal thickness of 603 μm. Post-treatment optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed vitreous separation from the macula, with a reduced foveal thickness of 270 μm. The BCVA remained unchanged at 0.5.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Mrs. Johnson's condition is consistent with VMT with partial response to intravitreal injection of C3F8 gas. The reduction in foveal thickness is a positive outcome, although BCVA has not improved, indicating potential for further intervention or ongoing monitoring.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to continue regular ophthalmologic check-ups to monitor the progression or resolution of VMT and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on symptoms that should prompt immediate consultation, such as increased visual distortion or pain. Encourage adherence to follow-up appointments to optimize outcomes and manage expectations regarding visual improvement.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 57-year-old woman with good performance status. Have you been experiencing any discomfort or pain recently?
Patient: Not really, but I've been feeling a bit off lately.
Doctor: I understand. We've detected a large right renal mass with adrenal extension and tumor thrombus extending to the right atrium in your recent tests. Additionally, there are enhancing liver lesions, which are suggestive of metastatic disease (cT4N1M1). You also have a pulmonary embolus and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the mass revealed clear cell renal cell carcinoma, WHO ISUP nucleolar grade 3.
Patient: Oh, that sounds concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it is. We started you on Apixaban 10mg/day for the management of the pulmonary embolus. Initially, we prescribed Pazopanib 800 mg orally once daily, but later switched to Nivolumab after you developed upper gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to a duodenal ulcer.
Patient: Hmm, I remember that.
Doctor: Interval imaging 6 months after targeted therapy showed a decrease in the size of the primary renal mass, but the thrombus extension into the IVC still persisted. There was also new hilar lymphadenopathy and segmental pulmonary embolism. We continued Nivolumab and 3-month PET/CT showed further reduction in the size of the renal mass with thrombus extension now to the level of the liver.
Patient: So there was some improvement?
Doctor: Yes, there was. However, there were new enhancing masses in the liver suspicious for metastases with subcarinal, precarinal, and bilateral hilar mediastinal lymphadenopathy. We initiated Cabozantinib in addition to the Nivolumab in view of the new lymphadenopathy.
Patient: How did I handle the new treatment?
Doctor: You tolerated the new regimen very well and were completely symptom-free with this therapeutic combination. New imaging with PET/CT showed no FDG avid lesions anywhere in the body, including the IVC thrombus, with a significant reduction in the size of the renal mass. An MRI Angiogram of the abdomen showed the IVC thrombus invading the IVC lateral wall and situated below the hepatic veins.
Patient: What's the next step then?
Doctor: Based on the imaging, we've decided to proceed with posttherapy right cytoreductive nephrectomy with IVC thrombectomy. We will stop the anticoagulant and perform bridging with Heparin prior to the surgery.
Patient: What can I expect during the surgery?
Doctor: Intraoperative findings may show a large renal mass with an infiltrating IVC thrombus in the retrohepatic location. Our surgical team will carefully remove the mass and thrombus to improve your condition. We'll closely monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Not really, but I've been feeling a bit off lately
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 57-year-old woman who reports feeling "a bit off" but denies experiencing any significant discomfort or pain. She has a history of clear cell renal cell carcinoma with a WHO ISUP nucleolar grade 3, which has metastasized to the liver and possibly other areas. She has experienced upper gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to a duodenal ulcer, attributed to previous medication (Pazopanib).

Objective.Observations: Recent imaging and tests reveal a large right renal mass with adrenal extension and tumor thrombus extending to the right atrium, classified as cT4N1M1. There are also enhancing liver lesions suggestive of metastatic disease, a pulmonary embolus, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. The patient has been on Apixaban 10 mg/day for pulmonary embolus management and has transitioned from Pazopanib to Nivolumab due to adverse effects. Follow-up imaging showed a decrease in the primary renal mass size, persistence of the thrombus in the IVC, new hilar lymphadenopathy, and segmental pulmonary embolism. Further imaging indicated new enhancing masses in the liver and additional lymphadenopathy, leading to the initiation of Cabozantinib alongside Nivolumab. Latest PET/CT scans showed no FDG avid lesions, and an MRI Angiogram confirmed the IVC thrombus invading the lateral wall below the hepatic veins.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma with IVC thrombus and pulmonary embolism. The patient's condition has shown partial response to the current therapeutic regimen of Nivolumab and Cabozantinib, with significant reduction in tumor burden and resolution of previously noted FDG avid lesions.

Plan.Treatment: The current plan includes proceeding with posttherapy right cytoreductive nephrectomy and IVC thrombectomy. Anticoagulation with Apixaban will be stopped, and bridging with Heparin will be initiated prior to surgery. Postoperative management will focus on monitoring and adjusting the treatment plan based on the patient's recovery and any new findings during surgery. Continued support and surveillance will be necessary to manage and monitor the patient's complex condition.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you have no prior medical history. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having trouble swallowing lately, like there's something stuck in my throat.
Doctor: I see, that's called dysphagia. We'll need to run some tests to determine the cause. Let's start with a routine chest radiography.
*After the test*
Doctor: The radiography showed some enlargement of the upper mediastinum at the sternal angle, indicating a possible arch anomaly. We'll need to perform a barium swallow to get a clearer picture.
Patient: Okay, what does that involve?
Doctor: You'll swallow a liquid containing barium, which will help us see the esophagus more clearly on an X-ray.
*After the barium swallow test*
Doctor: The barium swallow revealed an indentation of the esophagus on its right aspect. We'll need to do a computed tomographic angiography (CTA) scan to further investigate this.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
*After the CTA scan*
Doctor: The CTA scan showed the presence of a right-sided aortic arch compressing your esophagus, causing your dysphagia. The left common carotid artery originates first, followed by the right common carotid artery, then the right subclavian artery and the left subclavian artery arising from a Kommerell diverticulum.
Patient: So, what does this mean for me?
Doctor: Since the patient presented with dysphagia due to esophageal compression, endovascular treatment is contraindicated. You'll need to undergo open repair to address this issue.
Patient: I understand. What will that involve?
Doctor: You'll be taken to the operating room where we'll use selective lung ventilation and cerebrospinal fluid drainage to prevent complications like paraplegia. We'll perform a right thoracotomy in the third intercostal space, identify and dissect the distal aortic arch and right subclavian artery, and carefully dissect the posterior wall of the Kommerell diverticulum until the left subclavian artery is of normal diameter.
Patient: What will you do to prevent any injuries during the procedure?
Doctor: We'll surround the vessel with a silicone tape and use a posterior approach to prevent injuries from the Kommerell dissection adjacent to the esophagus. A simple side-biting division of the aberrant subclavian at the junction with the aorta will be considered unsafe, so we'll use graft replacement with left heart bypass instead.
Patient: What precautions will be taken during the procedure?
Doctor: We'll administer Heparin 1 mg/kg and establish a left heart bypass from the right inferior pulmonary vein to the descending thoracic aorta under mild hypothermia (32-34°C) to ensure a safe procedure. Aortic clamping will be done between the right carotid artery and the right subclavian artery for a secure anastomosis.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything, Doctor. I'm ready to move forward with the open repair.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll make sure to take all necessary precautions and provide the best possible care during your procedure.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports experiencing dysphagia, describing it as feeling like something is stuck in their throat. No prior medical history was noted.

Objective.Observations: Initial chest radiography indicated enlargement of the upper mediastinum at the sternal angle. A subsequent barium swallow test showed an indentation on the right aspect of the esophagus. Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) revealed a right-sided aortic arch compressing the esophagus, with vascular anomalies including a Kommerell diverticulum and an aberrant arrangement of the subclavian and carotid arteries.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with dysphagia due to external compression of the esophagus by a right-sided aortic arch and associated vascular anomalies. The presence of a Kommerell diverticulum complicates the vascular architecture, necessitating surgical intervention.

Plan.Treatment: The recommended treatment plan involves open surgical repair, specifically a right thoracotomy in the third intercostal space to address the vascular anomalies. Preoperative preparations will include selective lung ventilation and cerebrospinal fluid drainage to prevent paraplegia. Intraoperative measures will include the use of Heparin, establishment of left heart bypass, and mild hypothermia to ensure patient safety. Postoperative care will focus on monitoring and managing potential complications. The patient has been informed about the procedure and has consented to move forward with the recommended treatment.

dialogue:
Doctor: So, you're the second child of your parents, right? There's no family history of bone fragility or autism, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And your pregnancy was normal, with your mother delivering you by caesarean section due to a failure of labour progression, right?
Patient: Yes, that's what my parents told me.
Doctor: After delivery, you were treated in the Special Care Baby Unit for two days due to pyrexia. You were also born with left-sided calcaneus talipes equinovarus and right-sided developmental dysplasia of the hip. Your undescended testes were operated on successfully. Is that all accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see that you have been developmentally delayed. You started walking at 2.5 years of age and had a delayed onset of speech. You also had difficulties with fine motor skills and attended a school for children with special needs. Can you confirm this?
Patient: Yes, that's all true.
Doctor: You received a clinical diagnosis of ASD at 5-years old. Your parents also reported ritualistic behaviours, which led to a referral to Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services for an assessment of possible obsessive-compulsive disorder. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, they did.
Doctor: You have previously suffered finger fractures and a decrease in vertebral height. A DXA scan was performed to measure your bone mineral density before starting bisphosphonate treatment. The results demonstrated a reduced BMD with Z-scores of -3.4 at the lumbar vertebrae and a total body score of -2.5 when adjusted for age and gender. A bone biopsy also showed low turnover trabecular osteopenia, consistent with osteoporosis. Is this information accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's what the doctors told me.
Doctor: Additionally, you have been diagnosed with asthma and idiopathic generalized epilepsy. You've experienced intermittent neutropenia, which is thought to be a result of sodium valproate therapy. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Currently, you receive 3-monthly pamidronate infusions and take melatonin daily. You have also been prescribed midazolam, to be given in the event of a prolonged seizure. Is this your current treatment plan?
Patient: Yes, it is.
Doctor: On examination, I noticed that you have bilateral low-set ears, blue sclerae, and glasses due to hyperopia. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: We conducted trio whole exome sequencing and identified a de novo missense variant in the NRXN1 gene. This finding is important as it can provide us with more information about your condition and help guide future treatment options.
Patient: I see. What does that mean for me?
Doctor: This genetic variant could be associated with your developmental delays and other symptoms. It's important for us to continue monitoring your progress and adjusting your treatment as needed. We will also keep you informed about any new advancements in the understanding of this genetic variant and how it may impact your overall health.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the information and your help.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, that's correct
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a male with a history of developmental delays, reports being

Objective.Physical_Exam: Bilateral low-set ears, blue sclerae, and glasses
Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed bilateral low-set ears, blue sclerae, and hyperopia requiring glasses. Previous DXA scan results showed a lumbar vertebrae Z-score of -3.4 and a total body score of -2.5, adjusted for age and gender. Bone biopsy indicated low turnover trabecular osteopenia. Trio whole exome sequencing identified a de novo missense variant in the NRXN1 gene.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is Autism Spectrum Disorder with associated developmental delays and ritualistic behaviors. Secondary diagnoses include osteoporosis, asthma, idiopathic generalized epilepsy, and intermittent neutropenia due to sodium valproate therapy. The genetic finding of a NRXN1 variant may be contributory to the patient's neurodevelopmental and skeletal issues.

Plan.Treatment: Continue current regimen of pamidronate, melatonin, and as-needed midazolam. Monitor bone density annually and adjust osteoporosis management as necessary. Regular follow-ups with neurology for epilepsy management and pulmonology for asthma care. Genetic counseling is recommended to discuss the implications of the NRXN1 variant. Educate patient and family about the nature of his conditions and importance of adherence to treatment plans.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you are a 33-year-old gravida 3, para 2 female in your third trimester. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've got active left nasal bleeding and it's been bothering me for a while now.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. When did the bleeding start? Have you had any history of trauma or nose picking?
Patient: I don't remember any trauma or nose picking, but I've had a persistent left-sided nasal obstruction for about a month now.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. It looks like during your previous visit in June 2017, you had anterior nasal packing applied, and the bleeding stopped after two hours. Your hemoglobin level at that time was 9.9 mg/dL. Do you recall that?
Patient: Yes, I remember that. They gave me normal saline nasal irrigation and first aid instructions too.
Doctor: That's correct. You were also advised to come back if the bleeding recurred. It seems you returned to the ED ten days later with another episode of epistaxis, and your hemoglobin levels were 9.4 mg/dL. You were discharged and advised to follow up with otorhinolaryngology. Can you tell me what happened after that?
Patient: Well, I had to come back to the ED the same day because the bleeding started again, but this time it was of moderate severity. They used minimal anterior nasal packing and sent me home.
Doctor: I see. Then you returned to the ED the next day with active bleeding from your left nostril, and your hemoglobin level had dropped to 8.7 mg/dL. During the examination, it was observed that your right nasal cavity was clear, but your left nasal cavity had a large clot with moderate bleeding. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do. It was quite uncomfortable and concerning.
Doctor: I can understand that. A nasal endoscopy was performed, which revealed a large, red, smooth, and rounded mass in your left nasal cavity that was actively bleeding upon any application of pressure. The bleeding stopped with properly sized anterior nasal packing, and you were rehydrated with intravenous fluids. Obstetrics and Otorhinolaryngology (ORL) were also consulted. Do you recall that?
Patient: Yes, I remember that. They took good care of me and made sure the bleeding stopped.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. Moving forward, it's important to keep a close eye on your symptoms and follow up with your otorhinolaryngologist. If the bleeding recurs or worsens, please don't hesitate to come back to the emergency department. We're here to help.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your concern and advice. I'll make sure to follow up with my specialist and come back if needed.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and I hope you have a healthy and safe remainder of your pregnancy.
Patient: Thank you so much! Have a great day, doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 33-year-old gravida 3, para 2 female in her third trimester presenting with active left nasal bleeding and a history of recurrent epistaxis. She reports a persistent left-sided nasal obstruction for about a month, with no history of trauma or nose picking. Previous episodes of nasal bleeding were managed with anterior nasal packing and normal saline irrigation. She has had multiple visits to the emergency department for similar issues, with the most recent significant episode revealing a large, bleeding nasal mass upon endoscopy.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Your right nasal cavity was clear
Objective.Observations: Current examination is pending, but previous findings include a hemoglobin level drop from 9.9 mg/dL to 8.7 mg/dL over successive visits. Nasal endoscopy revealed a large, red, smooth, rounded mass in the left nasal cavity that bled upon pressure. The right nasal cavity appeared clear. Previous treatments included rehydration with intravenous fluids and consultations with Obstetrics and Otorhinolaryngology.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is recurrent epistaxis associated with a nasal mass in the left nasal cavity. Differential diagnoses could include benign or malignant growths, vascular malformations, or pregnancy-related nasal changes. The recurrent nature and associated mass suggest a potentially serious underlying condition that requires further investigation and management.

Plan.Treatment: Plan to manage the current episode with appropriate nasal packing and hemodynamic stabilization. Arrange for urgent follow-up with Otorhinolaryngology for further evaluation of the nasal mass, possibly including biopsy to determine the nature of the mass. Continue monitoring hemoglobin levels and provide supportive care as needed. Educate the patient on the importance of prompt medical attention for any recurrence of symptoms and ensure close follow-up with both Obstetrics and Otorhinolaryngology. Discuss potential impacts on pregnancy and delivery plans with the Obstetrics team.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 14-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with a congenital aneurysm of the right atrium while still in the uterus. You've been referred to our institution for surgical treatment. Can you tell me about any symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having frequent palpitations lately.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a physical examination first. Hmm, everything seems normal, but I do hear a systolic murmur grade 3/6 at the tricuspid area. We'll need to do some further tests to assess your condition. Let's start with an electrocardiogram and a chest X-ray.
Patient: Okay, doc.
(After the tests)
Doctor: Your electrocardiogram results are normal, but the chest X-ray shows enlargement of the cardiac area. We'll need to do an echocardiogram to get a better understanding of your heart's condition.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
(After the echocardiogram)
Doctor: The echocardiogram revealed aneurysmal dilatation of the right atrium and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Based on these findings, we need to schedule a surgery for you to correct these issues.
Patient: Oh, okay. When will the surgery be?
Doctor: The surgery will be on November 24th, 2016. It will involve a conventional cardiopulmonary bypass to allow us to access the right atrial aneurysm and resect it. The tricuspid valve appears normal, but the annulus is dilated, so we'll also perform a ring annuloplasty to correct that.
Patient: I understand, doc. I'm a bit nervous, but I trust you.
Doctor: Thank you for your trust. We'll take great care of you. The surgery should go smoothly, and with proper postoperative care, your recovery should be uneventful.
(After the surgery)
Doctor: The surgery went well, and your postoperative course has been uneventful. We've conducted a follow-up chest X-ray and echocardiogram, and both are showing normal results. You should continue to monitor your condition and report any new symptoms or concerns.
Patient: Thank you so much, doctor. I really appreciate everything you've done for me.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns in the future.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yeah, I've been having frequent palpitations lately
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient is a 14-year-old male with a history of congenital right atrial aneurysm diagnosed in utero, presenting with recent frequent palpitations. No other symptoms were reported.

Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur graded 3/6 at the tricuspid area. Electrocardiogram results were normal. Chest X-ray indicated enlargement of the cardiac area. Echocardiogram showed aneurysmal dilatation of the right atrium and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Postoperative chest X-ray and echocardiogram showed normal results.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a congenital aneurysm of the right atrium with associated moderate tricuspid regurgitation. The patient underwent successful surgical correction with cardiopulmonary bypass, resection of the right atrial aneurysm, and ring annuloplasty for the dilated tricuspid annulus.

Plan.Treatment: The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up to monitor his cardiac function. He should report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Postoperative care includes routine check-ups and echocardiograms to ensure the stability of the surgical corrections. Education on recognizing symptoms of cardiac distress was provided to the patient and his guardians.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having some trouble with my right eye. My vision has been getting worse lately.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any other health issues or eye problems in the past?
Patient: No, not really. I did have a mild flu-like illness a week ago, but that's about it.
Doctor: Alright, let's check your visual acuity. Your best corrected visual acuity is 0.5 in the right eye and 1.0 in the left eye. I'm going to perform some more tests to better understand your situation.
Patient: Okay, sure.
Doctor: Your anterior segment examination and intraocular pressure are within normal range in both eyes. However, the fundoscopic examination of your right eye shows splinter hemorrhages, optic nerve head hemorrhage, and cotton wool spots in the superior arcuate region. Based on these findings, you have been diagnosed with papillophlebitis.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: Papillophlebitis is an inflammation of the vein in the optic nerve head. We'll need to run some more tests to determine the cause. I'm going to perform a fundus fluorescein angiography to check for any ischemic areas.
Patient: Alright, go ahead.
Doctor: The angiography results show no ischemic areas, but there is hypofluorescence in the areas corresponding to the hemorrhages and hyperfluorescence in the optic nerve head. Additionally, optical coherence tomography reveals macular edema and intraretinal edema, as well as hyperreflective spots in the nasal fovea corresponding to the areas affected by the occlusion. We'll need to conduct some laboratory and radiological tests to determine the etiology of the papillophlebitis.
Patient: Okay, let me know what you find.
Doctor: After a week, you mentioned experiencing numbness, pain, and tingling sensations in both lower legs. Have you noticed any motor weakness?
Patient: Yes, it's been getting worse in both of my legs.
Doctor: Due to the severity of your symptoms, you were admitted to the neurology clinic for advanced examination and treatment. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spinal cord, as well as complete blood count, electrolytes, blood chemistry, urinalysis, and coagulation tests, including serum levels of homocysteine, protein C and S, partial thromboplastin time, and prothrombin time, were all normal. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and anticardiolipin G and M were also within normal range. A lumbar puncture revealed no pathology.
Patient: So, what's going on then?
Doctor: You have been diagnosed with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) and will be treated with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) therapy. This should help with your symptoms.
Patient: I hope so. Will my vision get better too?
Doctor: Yes, over the next three months, your symptoms improved, and your best corrected visual acuity in the right eye returned to 1.0 without any treatment for the ocular findings.
Patient: That's a relief. Thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will continue to monitor your progress and make sure you're on the right track to recovery. If you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to reach out.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, Doctor
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a middle-aged individual, presented with a chief complaint of worsening vision in the right eye. The patient reported no significant past medical history except for a mild flu-like illness a week prior. Recently, the patient also experienced numbness, pain, and tingling sensations in both lower legs, along with worsening motor weakness.

Objective.Observations: On examination, the best corrected visual acuity was 0.5 in the right eye and 1.0 in the left eye. Anterior segment examination and intraocular pressure were normal. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye revealed splinter hemorrhages, optic nerve head hemorrhage, and cotton wool spots. Fundus fluorescein angiography showed hypofluorescence in areas of hemorrhage and hyperfluorescence in the optic nerve head. Optical coherence tomography indicated macular edema, intraretinal edema, and hyperreflective spots in the nasal fovea. Neurological examination prompted by symptoms of numbness and weakness led to a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). MRI of the brain and spinal cord, along with comprehensive blood tests, were normal. Lumbar puncture showed no pathology.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with papillophlebitis in the right eye and Guillain-Barré Syndrome. The ocular findings improved spontaneously, and the neurological symptoms were managed with intravenous immunoglobulin therapy.

Plan.Treatment: The patient received intravenous immunoglobulin for Guillain-Barré Syndrome and was monitored for neurological improvement. No specific treatment was required for the ocular findings as they resolved spontaneously. The patient's visual acuity in the right eye returned to normal over three months. Continuous follow-up was planned to monitor recovery and address any new symptoms.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some enlargement in my right testicle for the past 2 months. I have a known G6PD deficiency, but no other significant symptoms.
Doctor: I see. Let's perform a scrotal ultrasound to examine the testicle. 
(After the ultrasound)
Doctor: The ultrasound shows that your testicle has indeed increased in size to 27.3 cm3, and there's diffuse heterogeneity. We'll need to do a computed tomography scan of your chest, abdomen, and pelvis to get a better understanding of what's going on. 
(After the CT scan)
Doctor: The CT scan revealed multiple lung nodules up to 28 mm and thoracic and retroperitoneal lymph nodes, which suggest an advanced germ cell tumor. We'll need to check your serum tumor markers to confirm.
(After the tumor marker tests)
Doctor: Your alpha fetoprotein level is 71.8 ng/mL, which is above the normal range of up to 8.0 ng/mL. Your human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level is 2,003 mUI/mL, much higher than the normal range of up to 5.0 mUI/mL. Lastly, your lactate dehydrogenase level is 546 UI/L, also above the normal range of 120 to 246 UI/L. Based on these results, it seems like you may have a germ cell tumor.
Patient: Oh no, what's the next step?
Doctor: The next step is to perform a right inguinal orchiectomy to remove the affected testicle. After that, we'll analyze the tissue to determine the type of tumor.
(After the orchiectomy)
Doctor: The pathologic report from the orchiectomy indicates that you have a nonseminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) in the form of embryonal carcinoma. The immunohistochemistry results show carcinoembryonic antigen, hCG, cancer antigen 125, C-KIT, and calretinin are negative, while placental alkaline phosphatase, AE1 to AE3, and CD30 are positive.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: Based on these findings, you have intermediate-risk NSGCT according to the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group classification. We'll need to start you on systemic therapy with bleomycin to treat the cancer.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for your help, doctor.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi, I've been experiencing some enlargement in my right testicle for the past 2 months
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports a 2-month history of right testicular enlargement. He has a known G6PD deficiency but no other significant symptoms.

Objective.Observations: Scrotal ultrasound revealed an enlarged right testicle measuring 27.3 cm3 with diffuse heterogeneity. CT scans showed multiple lung nodules up to 28 mm and enlarged thoracic and retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Serum tumor markers were elevated with alpha fetoprotein at 71.8 ng/mL (normal up to 8.0 ng/mL), human chorionic gonadotropin at 2,003 mUI/mL (normal up to 5.0 mUI/mL), and lactate dehydrogenase at 546 UI/L (normal 120-246 UI/L). Pathologic examination post-orchiectomy confirmed a nonseminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of embryonal carcinoma type, with specific immunohistochemistry markers detailed.

Assessment.Diagnosis: Primary diagnosis is intermediate-risk nonseminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the right testicle, specifically embryonal carcinoma. Differential diagnoses were considered through imaging and tumor markers before confirming the type via pathology.

Plan.Treatment: The patient underwent a right inguinal orchiectomy, and pathology confirmed the diagnosis. The next step is systemic therapy with bleomycin for the NSGCT. Further monitoring of tumor markers and imaging studies will be necessary to assess response to treatment and detect any metastasis. Patient education regarding the treatment plan, potential side effects, and prognosis is crucial. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and manage any complications from the therapy.
Plan.Follow-Up: To perform a right inguinal orchiectomy

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me what happened to you during the golf game?
Patient: Hi doc, I was watching one of the players take his shot at the 11th hole when I got hit by the golf ball. I was about 10 meters away from him at a 50-degree angle. The guy who hit the ball is a professional golfer and has played for over 10 years.
Doctor: Oh, that must have been quite an impact. How are you feeling now?
Patient: The pain in my lower leg is really severe.
Doctor: I understand. Let's check your medical, family, and psychosocial history. Is there anything relevant you'd like to share?
Patient: No, there's no significant history to mention.
Doctor: Alright, we'll perform an X-ray examination to assess the damage. Please wait for a moment while we get the results.
(After the examination)
Doctor: The X-ray results show that you have a displaced fracture of the proximal one-third of the tibia (Fig. 1, 2). We're going to treat this by inserting an intramedullary nail (Fig. 3, 4).
Patient: Okay, I understand. What should I expect after the treatment?
Doctor: You'll have postoperative follow-up appointments at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months, and then yearly. This will help us monitor your recovery and ensure that the treatment is effective.
Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor. I'll follow your instructions.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please be careful in the future and make sure to maintain a safe distance while watching others play golf. If you have any concerns or questions during your recovery, don't hesitate to contact us.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I'll keep that in mind.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Hi doc, I was watching one of the players take his shot at the 11th hole when I got hit by the golf ball
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient reports severe pain in the lower leg following an incident where he was struck by a golf ball while watching a game. He was approximately 10 meters away from the player at a 50-degree angle. The patient denies any significant medical, family, or psychosocial history.

Objective.Physical_Exam: One of the players take his shot at the 11th hole
Objective.Observations: Physical examination and X-rays were performed. The X-ray revealed a displaced fracture of the proximal one-third of the tibia. No other abnormalities were noted.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The primary diagnosis is a displaced fracture of the proximal tibia. Given the nature of the injury and the mechanism of trauma, the assessment focuses on bone integrity and potential complications such as delayed healing or nonunion.

Plan.Treatment: The treatment plan includes surgical intervention with the insertion of an intramedullary nail. Postoperative follow-up appointments are scheduled at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months, and then yearly to monitor recovery and ensure effective treatment. The patient is advised to maintain a safe distance while watching sports to prevent future injuries and is encouraged to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or questions arise during recovery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you have been referred to the general internal medicine service by emergency medicine for a 2-week history of worsening confusion. How have you been feeling?
Patient: Yes, doctor, it's been quite challenging. My confusion has been getting worse, and I've been experiencing memory issues and difficulty finding words.
Doctor: Were you independent with your activities of daily living (ADLs) and instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs) before this started happening?
Patient: Yeah, I was completely independent at my baseline 6 months ago.
Doctor: I understand your family has mentioned a cognitive decline that started with memory issues, word-finding difficulty, and unsteady gait. Have you also experienced agitation and hallucinations at night?
Patient: Yes, I have had those symptoms as well.
Doctor: In the 2 weeks prior to your emergency room visit, did your symptoms progress rapidly, making you too weak to ambulate and experiencing new incontinence of urine and stool?
Patient: Yes, that's exactly what happened.
Doctor: I see that your past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, asthma, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Is there any personal or family history of malignancy or dementia?
Patient: No, there's no history of malignancy or dementia in my family.
Doctor: Have you ever been screened for malignancy? Also, do you have a history of hunting or consuming game meat?
Patient: No, I've never been screened for malignancy, and I don't have a history of hunting or eating game meat.
Doctor: I noticed you are on medications like ASA, candesartan, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, glimepiride, iron supplements, multivitamins, and timolol eye drops. Have you been taking any over-the-counter medications, illicit drugs, or alcohol?
Patient: No, I haven't been taking any over-the-counter medications, illicit drugs, or alcohol.
Doctor: Your exam showed dry mucous membranes and a flat JVP. Your cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal exams were unremarkable. Neurologically, you have a slight upward gaze palsy and velocity-dependent hypertonia in the upper extremities. There were no fasciculations or myoclonus, and your reflexes and sensation were intact.
Patient: Okay, I see.
Doctor: Your white blood cell count is 2.7 × 109 (normal 3.5–10.5), your hemoglobin is 134 g/L, and your platelets are 196 × 109. The electrolytes and extended electrolytes were within normal limits.
Patient: I'm glad to hear that, but what does all this mean?
Doctor: It means we need to investigate further to determine the cause of your symptoms. We will conduct more tests and closely monitor your condition. In the meantime, please inform us of any changes in your symptoms or if you experience new ones.
Patient: Alright, doctor, I will keep you updated. Thank you.

Subjective.Chief_Complaint: Yes, doctor, it's been quite challenging
Subjective.History_of_Present_Illness: The patient, a male with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, asthma, and benign prostatic hyperplasia, presents with a 2-week history of worsening confusion, memory issues, difficulty finding words, agitation, hallucinations, rapid progression of symptoms leading to weakness, and new incontinence of urine and stool. He was independent in ADLs and IADLs 6 months prior. There is no personal or family history of malignancy or dementia. He denies use of over-the-counter medications, illicit drugs, or alcohol.

Objective.Physical_Exam: Dry mucous membranes and a flat JVP
Objective.Observations: Physical examination revealed dry mucous membranes, flat JVP, unremarkable cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal exams, slight upward gaze palsy, and velocity-dependent hypertonia in the upper extremities. Neurological examination showed no fasciculations or myoclonus, with intact reflexes and sensation. Lab results indicated a low white blood cell count at 2.7 × 10^9/L (normal 3.5–10.5 × 10^9/L), hemoglobin 134 g/L, and platelets 196 × 10^9/L. Electrolytes and extended electrolytes were within normal limits.

Assessment.Diagnosis: The patient's clinical presentation and lab findings suggest a rapidly progressive neurological disorder, possibly an atypical presentation of a neurodegenerative disease or central nervous system infection. Differential diagnoses include Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, autoimmune encephalitis, or a paraneoplastic syndrome, given the rapid onset and neurological symptoms.
Assessment.Severity: We need to investigate further to determine the cause of your symptoms

Plan.Treatment: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests including MRI brain, CSF analysis, and EEG to evaluate for neurodegenerative or infectious processes. Consult neurology for expert evaluation. Continue monitoring vital signs and neurological status closely. Educate patient and family about the need for further testing and potential diagnoses. Ensure patient remains hydrated and maintain safety measures to prevent falls due to motor instability. Follow up on test results and adjust treatment plan accordingly.
Plan.Follow-Up: We need to investigate further to determine the cause of your symptoms

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been diagnosed with cutaneous melanoma. Can you tell me more about my condition?
Doctor: Sure. Your biopsy results show that you have stage IIA cutaneous melanoma. The melanocytic lesion on your left posterior arm was found to be an ulcerated primary melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 1.75 mm and a mitotic index of 1/mm2. You underwent wide excision of the primary lesion, followed by a completion lymph node dissection (LND) of the left axillary basin. Your sentinel lymph node biopsy was initially deemed positive, but the histology from the LND showed capsular nevi within several regional lymph nodes, indicating a pathologic stage IIA, T2b melanoma. 
Patient: Hmm, okay. So, what happened next?
Doctor: You remained disease-free for three years until an in-transit metastasis was detected near the primary site. After the excision of the lymphatic metastasis, you were treated with adjuvant radiotherapy of 50 Gy in 20 fractions to the left posterior arm, followed by one month of adjuvant systemic therapy with high-dose interferon (IFN).
Patient: Yes, I remember that. But then I had another recurrence, right?
Doctor: That's correct. One year later, you experienced a second local in-transit recurrence. Positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) imaging and tissue confirmation revealed two to three metastatic melanoma lesions in your liver. Your hepatic metastasis was tested for the BRAF V600 mutation, but the result was negative.
Patient: Oh, I see. What was the plan for treatment after that?
Doctor: The planned treatment was to induce an anti-tumor immune response that could mediate systemic tumor regression, known as the abscopal effect. You received four doses of ipilimumab (anti-CTLA-4) at 3 mg per kilogram of body weight every three weeks, with radiation to begin after two doses.
Patient: Okay, and did the treatment work?
Doctor: After two cycles of ipilimumab alone, a PET-CT scan showed progression of liver metastases, with enlargement of the two previous liver lesions and the development of five new hypermetabolic foci in the liver. The largest measured 2.3 x 2.5 cm. Subsequently, you were treated with stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) to two of the liver metastases with a total dose of 54 Gy in three fractions.
Patient: That sounds intense. How am I doing now?
Doctor: It's important to continue monitoring your condition closely and follow up with your oncologist for any changes or concerns. They will be able to provide you with the most up-to-date information on your treatment and prognosis.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining my situation to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask. Take care, and I wish you the best in your treatment and recovery.
